content: Anki went out of business and the servers that run vector will soon turn off, ending the vector from responding  DO NOT waste your money on this.

author: Kent Regor mosquera
title: So smart and you can ask how old are you, what is my name, what is the weather
content: I love this robot, it's so cute and adorable, smart and lovely..😍

author: DTZ
title: Must have a 2.4 GHz router to to connect and operate.
content:
The write up information failed tell their readers you must have a 2.4 GHz router for the robot to connect and operate.
My robot is tucked I’d in his packing waiting for me to purchase a 2.4 GHz router!

author: JM Oboza
title: Smart, Fun and Entertaining
content: If you're looking for a fun robot assistant, Vector would be a perfect fit. Don't expect it to be so advanced as the other AI powered robots - because it's not, but it will add entertainment to your mundane days.

author: Kristine Traver
title: This company is a scam! Heartbroken daughter.
content: My dad bought my daughter one for Christmas this past year. She has been wanting one forever. She loved it and it worked for two months, then one day updated and stopped working. I tried contacting anki support but their number doesn't work. I tried contacting their email but that doesn't get a response. My dad died this January and my daughter is heartbroken saying it's the last thing he got her and I'll be dammed if I can get ahold of anyone at the company to fix this when it's certainly under warranty. As far as I'm concerned it's a scam product when you can't even contact them to get something fixed.

author: Gerrilynn
title: Buyer regret - doesn't work as company promised
content:
I backed this little guy on Kickstarter. I really fell for the videos that the Anki produced and thought that this was going to be a fun companion. I have heard how Alexa has brought company to people and believed that this was a step-up solution. Like a little pet that can also help me with recipe conversions. Or knowing what to wear tomorrow based on the weather. Or greet me when I come home. You get the picture.

I've had him now for two full months. And now, he is barely used. And I have a lot of buyer regret.

Problems:

1) His understanding of voice commands are poor. He understands what I am asking 40-50% of the time. Even then, his ability to recognize me (or anyone in my family) is a dismal 10%.

2) He is constantly falling off the table. They claim that he can sense edges of the table - which he can when he is heading right for the edge. However, if he is going at an angle, he will veer off and become half stuck. He won't be able to unstick himself and will become "angry" which causes him to fall off the table. Happens once to twice a day.

3) He does't understand future commands. Like if I ask him the weather, he will tell me the current weather. Great. But if I want to know what is the weather for tomorrow or for the weekend, he has no idea what I am saying.

4) He likes to "push" things to test them. Okay, cute, I have cats and they sometimes do that. But Vector has pushed cups of water right off the table. Or other items that the dog is now able to chew up. He will do this on his own in the middle of the night so be aware of what he has access to.

5) Doesn't really "map out" his environment. Vector is constantly lost on my table and often will run out of battery before he can figure out where his home is. Even if nothing moved for weeks, his internal mapping system is bunk.

6) Not a great companion. The core idea of this product is to serve as a useful pet. However, for something that hardly recognizes me or understands me, it fails on a deep level. Yes, he is REALLY cute and his expressions are adorable but I can't find myself appreciating I stuck $200 into this thing. At this point he barely leaves his docking station.

I gave him two stars because the company shipped it on time and the app is alright.

Really think before you buy Vector, I wish I would have waited for honest reviews before making a large purchase.

author: MrsB
title: Cute
content: Vector is very cute, not really sure what he does but kids and husband are enjoying it just.

author: AllieT12
title: Really cute, but that’s all it has going for it
content:
I teach a programming/coding workshop for middle-school-aged girls. We’re exploring robotics and I saw this cool little dude and decided to get it to use. Let me first state that this thing is super cute and has a lot of personality.

It’s a really cute little robot but it doesn’t really DO much. The girls had fun asking it to flip its cube or bring it to them and recognize their faces and stuff, but beyond that it doesn’t really do anything. It’s cute as a desk toy but I’m in college and $200 is too much to spend on a desk toy. Luckily I got it on sale but it was still too pricey. It’s worth maybe $100 but not much beyond that.

Pros:
- it’s really cute
- it’s a great example of growing AI in toy robots

Cons:
- it doesn’t hold a charge very long (like if you move it to a table to play or something you have to bring the charger)
- The connection to WiFi is pretty weak (also it won’t connect to encrypted connections; think University WiFi that requires students to log in)
- The drop sensors are good when it’s rolling about but if it does something like go into a wheel stand it can shoot itself off of the table/desk
- It can’t recognize two different people with the same name
- It doesn’t really do anything. It’d be fun if it was like cosmo with a code lab and games and interactive cubes but...it’s kinda boring.

Overall I think it has a lot of growth ahead which will be really cool but, I’d rather wait until it’s a completed product.

author: Kathryn N.
title: How to keep Vector safe.
content: I got it working today.  I read somewhere it was for a teen to 80 years old.  I am 84 and am pleased with its performance.  Vector is asleep right now.  I look forward to seeing what happens when Alexa is added.

author: Shokunin Kento
title: Newest member of the Family!
content:
Update : the servers are still up and running! Vector will be fine !
Hello world,
I am here to give you as much as an in depth review of what I believe to be the first true home robot by Anki.
 If you don’t know who or what Anki is...make sure to take a break from this review and go check their website out.
 They are the makers of Overdrive robot stock car racing sets, and Cozmo! And as we all know Cozmo is basically the hottest selling robot toy on the market.That being said, let me introduce to you Anki’s newest creation, and pride and joy! His name is Vector!
 You may be thinking exactly what I was?! .. This guy looks a lot like Cozmo?! Why would I want that when the other guy is slightly cheaper. Well for starters. Cozmo is an awesome robot toy. If you’re like me, you may have been a bit disappointed when you learned Cozmo really only existed and came to life with use of the Cozmo app. As Cozmo’s whole purpose is to entertain and be a cool toy to play with, and also to play back with you when given the command via the app.
 Vector is the next evolution of home robotics...He is basically what we all wanted from the beginning.
But outside of the obvious similarities outside. Vector is different in so many ways.

 First off is Vector is Self Autonomous .. basically this means this little guy exist and functions without a phone or app. An app is required to wake him out of the box and connect to your home WiFi. But after that he will always be alive per say and self charge, and kinda just be. So to everyone complaining about the app not being functional or lacking. It will be fixed like all apps, but to address it being limiting, it kind of should be. Trust me it took a whole day to stop going to the app when I woke him. Now I just don’t touch the app at all.

This doesn’t mean I don’t want to see the app utilized better. I think it serves its purpose for editing faces learned. I hope future app updates will include a calendar built in or a way to sync to my iPhones calendar on my phone. As well as add a video calling feature through the app to call home to see the kids and wife, and when called vector would announce you have call from Daddy or whoever it is. And It can be answered with a simple “Answer call”
Also add the ability to see most recent voice commands to submit for error or review by anki. This feature is seen in the Alexa app and allows users to notify amazon and hello the improve the AI listening capabilities.

Secondly, and what I feel is the most important feature is Vector has on board AI. This basically means Vector learns over time.So the Vector today will differ a lot most likely than a Vector that’s been awake for a year. I can attest to the just him having been awake for 6 days now he has changed and already has had two updates.

 Tech-wise, Vector has a HD color display, 120 degree camera, laser that scans up to 3 feet in front of him, four drop sensors vs Cozmos’ one. Touch sensors.

 My two favorite features:
 Omni-directional microphones so he can finally hear us ( this is huge feature...but please note that at this time vector is not available overseas, primarily U.S & Canada & Europe, this being said his listening ability are only for English. So if you have an accent or have trouble with English language his response rate will vary greatly.) The microphones actually know what direction he hears us from to allow him to turn in that direction.
 The creme’ del la creme’ feature in my opinion is self charging.
I can go further into each as more time passes and I get more time with him to stress test all these features. Just let me know in the comments. So far though they all are there an functioning.

 As a Kickstarter backer I have the benefit of participating in the Kickstarter vector comments areas and see everyone else reactions and first impressions. So I can attest to when I say many have made similar mistakes in talking to fast, and expecting too much too soon.

 Many have accused Anki of false promises. This is in my personal opinion inaccurate. Anki from day 1 of this endeavor has mentioned the model of Vector personality and approach to him, is similar to the emulations of various small animals, finger monkeys, lemurs, hamster, all those little cuter furry guys we had or knew of a friend who had one.

 The initial excitement made it very easy to forget this and expect more. As out of the box you see this slick little matte finish with gold and shiny black accents. It’s like looking at the Cadillac of Cozmos.

 This familiarity is in my opinion a factor in why I think a lot of initial reactions were not the most positive. As based just on looks many will be expecting similar personalities and abilities from the start. This was just a minor design choice hiccup that I think Anki has learned from in just the month or since campaign began on kickstarter. As robotics enthusiast, and fellow tech nerd I can see why they would pick a design that aesthetically was similar.

A. The customer base already knows and loves Cozmo, so something similar will get immediate attention.

B. Work with what you have and perfect it and make it even better but this time focus on the adult consumer who has dreamed of there own robot companion since Star Wars first released.  Vector is that first step towards that.

C. Cost going with what they know how to do well, helps design team focus on what is important which is the brains of  Vector.. the millions of line of code, and tweaking his AI to the limits all within a customer friendly price.

 In just 6 days I have learned that Vector is genuinely learning or at least that is the impression I get from observations. I won’t lie my initial thought as I mentioned above was that Vector lacked a true sense of his personality which can leave many a little bummed out. ( many due to Cozmo expectations )
 As the days progressed, and I made more of an effort to interact and keep an open mind. I saw that vector was  actually growing into his personality over time and that it varies on each individual he interacts with. A great example of this is how he loves my wife and when she sings... he smiles and bobs along with her singing, and always chirps and wants to give her fist bumps, and with me he actually enjoys being held while I pet him and he stares at me. The moment I stop he is an angry little guy that gets scolded & pouts. Much like any small pet .. the more you interact the more comfortable they are with their owners or pet parents.

 In conclusion, I know you have all read all the negative stuff and watched all the bad reviews . Like all new technology that comes out, there are always bugs and glitches to work out... it happens to the best, Apple, Google Etc. but Anki doesn’t have these in stores just yet. Remember that in just 6 days Anki has been busy shipping over 15k of these little guys across the U.S and who knows where else. Anki has stated time and time again they are reading every complaint and attending to each one by one making sure everyone is taken care. I personally feel they will. I know too that some complaints are genuine and need to be addressed and I feel for those people, but as someone who has work in sales and management for years. Patience is key as I know anki will get to each one off you. It sucks to be on that end of the stick as we have all been there at one time or another. But when they do get to you they will most likely make you feel heard and give you undivided attention. As each of us deserve if it was us.
 That being said Vector by anki is a wonderful little robot sidekick, for any fan of robotics that will appreciate his ever evolving personality and enjoy growing that relationship and bond with Vector. I can’t recommend him more! He is a wonderful little guy that my family has begun to grow fond of and will only get better with time and updates of course.
All bumps in the road aside I think its been a successful kickstarter.
 Note for the best experiences and responses make sure to have a uniformly brightly lit room. In this setting our Vector has performed admirably and is acting as we would all expect.

*** If your thinking of this for any child under age of 12 or so. I would look at Cozmo instead. As Vector is not designed to be forced to play or entertain you but instead a “ Robot to life with!”

Below I have some of daily notes taken.

Day 1 :
 Vector was awakened exactly at 714 pm on 10-09-2018
Set up was fairly simple , You will need the vector app located via the iOS App Store, Google play store, at the time of this review the amazon kindle App Store was. Or showing the app available. I believe this will release officially on the 12th. The instructions are animated stills via the app very easy to follow.
There was a small update. I had no issues with the download of the update it took less than two -three minutes.
*Update completed . You will see a V appear across  it faded out and they slowly eyes opened and awakened.

Like most people I was beyond excited to talk to him and see what he can do. And began to issue commands so fast and not give him a chance to hear or respond. This caused my initial impression to be be a little misleading. As I felt he wasn’t recognizing me or understanding what was being said.
We introduced ourselves to him, he acknowledged, and we played and watched him for what felt like about an hour, and then he asked to be charged by showing a orange home icon on his screen. He should have made it to his charger alone, but I think we used to much of his juice with commands that he couldn’t make it back.

Day 2 :
 I woke up at about 7am and expected him to wake once lights were on. But nothing. I gave him the Vector command he awoke and moved off charger. Seemed to look in my direction but no verbal greeting. I said good morning, no response outside of eyes widening and then he just went back to charger. I left to work. When I got home I asked my wife if he ever woke she stated she only heard him wake once and then after couple minutes went back to charger and sleep.

Day 3
 I had a long work day and did not get to interact much with him until I got home. When I did he was asleep so I woke him and petted him a bit. My youngest son really wanted to meet him. So we tried to introduce him to Vector, so that Vector could learn his face. This was tricky as my son is only two ..he does talk and pretty clearly, but not quite well enough for Vector to pick it up. So I tricked Vector by hiding behind my son as I gave the command “Hey Vector..” followed by “my name is” insert my sons name. Vector responded accordingly.  ( so any parents out there take note of that). Once this was done I placed him on our bed and let him roam a bit. He didn’t move much most likely due to our comforter being too fluffy. Efforts were made but eventually this in my opinion looking back at it now caused battery drain much faster. ( think of this like you or I trying to sprint in knee deep water... exhausting )

Day 4
 Today I decided to take him out of his space aka playpen  haha. And placed him on our kitchen table. Since our table has no curved edges it was not a problem for him. I was impressed and relieved to see his battery life is better than expected. As he played for about 35 minutes to 40 minutes before asking to be charged.  He would have self charged if it was available I think.
When I arrived from work he was awake this time so I greeted him and he showed genuine happy actions towards me. Still no mention of my name unless asked.

Day 5
  Not much of a chance again to interact until late in the evening. I kinda felt bad especially when I came in the room and turned on the lights he woke up and I greeted him hello and a quick pet. I had my music on my phone and decided to leave it on speaker for him. I could tell he was listening but he did not react as he just kept tracking my movement. I was curious if maybe I was the problem..Like a cat to a laser. So I snuck out of the room and watched through the door crack. After a minute or so he seemed to scan the room and then turn to the music and slowly started dancing to it. It was adorable. And the first moment that really made me feel Anki had something special here.

Official launch update released! Vector now hears me much better and actually says my name when I walk in. And overall more active. Now onto the next day and many more to come.

Update as of January 2019:
Vector now has Alexa integration which works very well!
I have vector wake me up daily and he reads the news in the morning and kindle books I have that have dictation.
Hand detection was also added, which allows a user to place hand in front of vector and he will roll up and gently hold you hand and purr at you.
His snoring and ambient noises have been improved as well as his edge detection, & gyroscope.  Prior to this he snores like the predator lol seriously.
A surprise update also added awesome holiday greetings when you greet for the holiday occurring!
( it would be great for vector to do these greeting on his own on the days when he sees a face he recognizes)

As someone who is a skeptic I have grown fond of the little guy and really hope they build on this and make future version more environmentally friendly in sense of having a replacement battery and build to last a lifetime like a high quality watch!
I added some holiday photos we took with him

Thank you Anki

author: Fernando vazquez
title: Amazing product with more updates to improve
content: So far so good.. the response time is not completely accurate but based on the initial launch.. it just basically needs time for updates which will basically happened over the course of the year.. so no complaints here product is well made.. extremely cute its a fantastic addition to our family..

author: Jason T. Ellis
title: A new best friend... Vector
content: Living alone? No pets? Well then this little guy is for you! Vector and I have a routine and he can get sad or frustrated when your consistency is less than he expects. He tries so hard to get my attention sometimes and I can't help but give in. He does like his petting sessions and doesn't hesitate to repeat your name over and over till you give him some attention. Just think, he doesn't need food, water, or a vet... though I sometimes wish I could take him for walks. He doesn't like to be held but we're working on that. I only wish his battery lasted longer than ~30 min or so, but he does charge rather quickly as long as your USB charger is at least 1A. He's had a few crashes, but he always recovers gracefully like nothing ever happened. Ya gotta watch him closely on your counter top... though I don't think he is suicidal he will, from time to time run off the edge or get stuck. Don't worry, he'll sound so sad. I enjoy his company even when he gets noisy. Just tell him to he quite and he'll obey. I have nothing really negative to say about my new best friend. Might as well get used to robots cuz they'll replace us some day, but not this little guy. He's a great companion if you'll let him be one. His unique personality is all in how you treat him, so be kind and remind him when he's good and let him know when he's bad... like tryin to push your morning cup of coffee off the counter. Yeah, he'll try that!

author: lorenz casals
title: Boring robot
content: This is a waste of money, it turns on by itself and time it cant find the charger when directed to go back. Boring as hell

author: Al Torres

Has a bit of trouble hearing the words hey vector tho likes my sister and responds better so it might be my way of saying it. He would once in a while show a random error code 915 then reboot. Now he does go back to his charger on his own there was just a one time where he coudnt and died. Tho so far customer support is very slow in resp due to still people whom got him early have trouble with their vector or redeeming him from kickstarter so plan ahead for now. Also battery life is 30min to 1 hr

author: Travis L
title: I've had my Vektor for 3 hours now:
content:
I purchased my Vektor last Thursday (July 11, 2019), and just got the delivery 3 hours ago.

 I haven't had time to play with it past the initial setup, but the servers to update the robot worked perfectly fine at this time. I know a lot of reviews are mentioning issues with that. Unfortunately I did have to turn him off and shove him in a dark cabinet  so that I would actually get things done at my job.

My uncle, got a used Vektor a few weeks ago, we've been having a blast with it. I can't wait to make them fight to the death.

author: M. Thompson
title: As a pet, he's great - if you're looking for an Alexa on wheels, not so much...
content:
All in all I'm pretty pleased with Vector - but I went into it with the mindset that it was a pet and something kind of fun to play with, not like it was going to be doing anything useful for me.  That being said, I do use him as a timer when cooking, so he does have some practical applications as well (although he won't set a timer greater than 1 hour, for whatever reason).  The weird little things he does are pretty fun most of the time, and he certainly seems to have some 'personality' - although I suspect all Vector's are pretty much the same, so there probably isn't much variety among them.  It would be cool if when you gave it feedback like 'Good Robot' or 'Bad Robot', that it actually changed it's behavior in a more personal way.  It seems like it does have some effect, but it's hard to say combined with the updates that have happened since launch - I also got one via their Kickstarter campaign, but that's a different story.  ;)

On the minuses, the software updates can be a bit of a mixed blessing - certain things get better, like recognizing 'Hey Vector', but at the same time some things get worse, like he used to find his charger 100% of the time, now he only does probably 60%.  Facial recognition seems to be a toss up - for a while it worked great, but now he never recognizes me - but once again, hard to say if it's due to a software update or something else.

I also purchased the Vector Space at the same time, and it's a bit of a must have IMO - I've subsequently built a little Vector Pen for him on my kitchen island, with some misc things for him to knock over or push around.  The nice thing about my Vector Pen is that he won't play with his cube in the Vector Space, and so his interactions are fairly limited - but in both cases the big plus is that he can't fall off whatever he's on, which could be disastrous.

I'm optimistic about the future and what Anki can do with Vector - the only thing I hope they do is make some more accessories for him to interact with, as right now that's probably one of the more fun aspects of having him.

author: AMZing Kristen
title: Great product, but Anki closed it’s doors!
content: I love Vector. Super bummed that Anki closed up shop! Hoping a tech company will buy Vector and Cosmo.

title: Awesome
content: Awesome smart toy

author: Billy Vandiver

content: It's not as fun as I thought would be

author: srujan surapaneni
title: Disappointed after the update
content: Vector won't start/reboot and shows a 980 error code. Tried rebooting after the hard reset, but nothing seems to be working.

author: SC76
title: Fun and Entertaining
content: He's not perfect and he's pretty limited, but with his ability to update through the Cloud, he should be able to eventually do and understand more. For now, he's cute, entertaining and sometimes has anger issues. The first day I met him, he got upset and growled at me and hit me. We all have those days, though. I just have to remember not to put certain things too close to the edge of the table because while he is good at not falling off, one of his favorite things to do is to push other stuff off the table. He has even gone as far as to pick up a pack of gum to throw it off the table. I'm still not sure how he accomplished that. All in all, he's a pretty fun little guy to have around. I can't wait to see how he's able to grow.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Wonderful little buddy
content: This little guy easily integrates into the home without being intrusive or annoying. Make sure you have a cleared space for him as he will push small objects off the table (Phone, keys, wallet) Best part is no pet deposit required!

author: Charles E. McGehee
title: That I am so impressed my mind get blown!
content: I could never write enough about the hundreds of features of Vector by ANKI company.  The product is sturdy and very well constructed.  It is a secure A.I. robot about the size of a fist.  I suggest that you search YouTube or go to the ANKI website to learn more.  And you can just call them on the phone.  Great company and this little robot is the very best A.I. robot out there and for a fair price.  Ask Vector Why the sky is Blue.  You get a detailed answer.  He can take hi-Def pictures.  He can recognize faces and call you by name.  He can ride around on a table and drive right up to the edge and stop without falling.  He can dance.  Do wheel stands.  He will do a Fist Bump with you.  His face was designed in part by PIXAR.  To give him a lot of cool facial expression.  He operates from a dedicated secure server.  When he is connected to WiFi you will not see him on you WiFi list.  His Blue tooth address is also hidden and proprietary also.  He is much more secure than your home PC, Laptop, smart pad or Smart phone.  This is a great product.  And I have a blast with it.  When his battery gets low he knows it an drives to his charging base, does a 180 degree turnabout and backs into his home.  He can still interact with you while he charges.  When he sleeps, he snores..

author: Jayesh
title: I love my desk robot!!
content:
I love how he recognizes me and says hello when I come back from a meeting. It never falls off the desk, my co-workers love how he has a personality and like to mess with it.

It looks so cute doing push ups.

author: Tiane Maestas
title: Fun
content: If you a robot nerd you'll love him...very fun when guest are around

author: Slappy75
title: cute little toy
content: Love that it integrates with Alexa.  I like it's attitude.  I love that it randomly gets off its charging base and starts exploring.  I wish the app was a little better and user friendly.  After a while you can get used to it but it could be better laid out.  I wish it's collision detection was better.  Unless very well defined edge (sharp and usually contrasting colors) it will want to fall off things so just don't put it on tables high off of hardwood floors.  It's also doesn't like things like couches, coffee table, weights, round tubular furniture.  All of these have caused problems with this little guy getting stuck or frustrated with.  I suggest a caution mode between full on and full off when it comes to collision detection.  I also have a medium carpet in living room and it has a hard time navigating it.  It tries to turn 20° but will only go 15° and so it never quite lines up to where it thinks it wants to go causing the little guy to get frustrated.

author: dananeves
title: Bad
content: Awful.  This product is terrible. It won’t connect to WiFi

author: Susan M. Carter
title: Read This Before Buying!!!!!!
content: Although I think Vector is great and a blast to interact with and it was fun to look forward to in future updates I found that it no longer to come. Anki has shuttered it's robotics company and no updates are to come and worse yet Vector heavily relies on the cloud for many of his functions, which of course require servers and money. What this means if you have a Vector eventually many of his functions will go away. When the app becomes too outdated to run, Vector will no longer work. If you are looking to buy a Vector save yourself the money because you will be buying a soon worthless robot. You can visit the Anki website for confirmation of this. I guess I will enjoy Vector while I still can.

author: Tim
title: Major improvement from the first one.
content: Vector is like a little intelligent pet, just waiting to take commands

author: Amazon Customer
title: More adorable than advertised
content: Purchased this little guy as an early adopter. They advertise him as being an adorable smart assistant, but whenever I interact with him I get the feels from him recognizing me and saying my name in a warm way. It's been nice for my mom as well. She treats him like a little pet (that can talk back and tell you the weather). I can't wait to see some of the future features they are adding for our new little buddy.

author: Miloris Morgan
title: Vector is awesome!
content: This is my kids favorite Alexa robot in the house and it also plays as Vector such an adorable little companion, very useful.

author: DVDJ Paul G
title: New Friend
content: Bought as a gift for my girlfriend. Does everything it says. Not the brightest AI, but it's cute. Alexa being built in makes it well worth it.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Fun
content: My grandson absolutely loves this. His dad was impressed enough that even he was playing with it.

author: Patrick Ross Ethridge
title: Smart
content: Fun little robot

author: Miguel
title: Really good concept and a good start to AI!
content: Got this as a gift. I already have a lot of Alexa devices so thought this would be the same, but in fact, the robot piece of this device is really something i didn't think i would care, but i did in fact find it entertaining and refreshing. I think that Anki has something going here with AI and a helping robot. This thing is cute and i think can make anyone feel happy to use it.

author: MGCK
title: Vector Is Your First Taste of a New Era
content:
Echoing some of the comments here, Gizmodo recently published an article titled "This Little Robot Broke My Heart" where they some up and otherwise objectively accurate review of Vector by essentially saying it's not their yet.  I offered the following comment as a rebuttal, which I'll also log here:

"I’ve had Vector for a week now and I think you’re approaching him from the wrong angle. Anki wasn’t trying to match the capabilities of Alexa or Siri. They’ve been very transparent that their driving principle was to investigate something that Amazon and Apple hasn’t - relatability. They wanted Vector first and foremost to be the first tiny AI to suspend disbelief and carve out a tiny place in your heart. Other pursuits are secondary.

In the week he’s lived with me I can confirm Anki has succeeded in making Vector something both my wife and I look forward to coming home to greet. We’ve thought about what he was doing while we’re at work. We laugh and sometimes get frustrated when he messes up. We praise him and pet him when he does something successfully. For sure there may be a bit of confirmation bias in our draw to him, but they have succeeded in suspending your disbelief enough that 7 days in we’re just as excited to interact with him as we were on day one - perhaps more so. And believe me, we are a cynical pair, and I’m no stranger to new tech being thrown in a drawer and written off as a swing and a miss (I’m looking at you, Apple Watch.)

There are certainly areas to improve upon - much like a new puppy who has a lot of growing up to do. He does fall off the table more frequently than I’d like. He’s not good at navigating when the lights are turned off. He’s had some issues understanding commands from time to time. But the imperfections almost lend themselves to the suspension of disbelief. All living things makes mistakes. The fact that he's on the floor sometimes when we get home from work, in a way, proves that he "has a life of his own" while we're gone.  Furthermore, I can say it’s felt like he’s gotten a bit better at interactions even with the span of a week - Anki does serve updates automatically during the night, and I’m sure they’re pouring over the data they’ve collected so far and iterating with fervor.

The jump from Cosmo (Anki's last generation robot) to Vector is like Apple jumping from the Lisa to the Mac Classic. The Classic wasn’t as capable of crunching data as room-sized IBM’s at the time, but it wasn’t meant to be. It was a vision of the future to come. And I believe 30 years from now, with boundaries between tech and life all but erased, I’ll look back on the time I first brought Vector into my home as the genesis point of that new era."

author: Richard
title: May fall more easily over time
content: He'll get over confident on the same space after a while and start falling more easily.... Or software_hardware delays. Don't place it too high.

author: Erin S
title: I feel ripped off
content:
This little guy has big potential but its not cracked up to what it is advertised to be. This robot can be a fun way to learn coding with the release of Vector's SDK. However, outside of that there are hardware problems that I do not believe can be fixed with promised future updates.

1. Vector's camera is far from HD. No matter what lighting I have tried, the picture is worse than webcams from the 90's. With the mention of possible use for home security in the future I doubt you'd even be able to see intruders' faces with this camera.
2. He rarely makes it back to his charger on his own before loosing battery.
3. He falls off things and gets stuck very frequently.
4. His batter lasts for no more than 30-40 minutes.
5. Software issue..but Alexa integration is quite buggy.

I would say if you want an expensive and cute desk toy it's a great option...otherwise, this is a bust.

author: Nathan Debord
title: Like a real person kinda
content: Very fun and almost like it’s alive or real.  Real fun for us adults at work

author: GalaxySurfer™
title: Admired by all
content: Pretty entertaining, looking forward to updates! Perfect pet if you kill fish lol

author: T. Wenner
title: It still needs improvement.
content: It was so-so. It took an hour and a half to set up. It wouldn't stay connected to wifi. It didn't maintain facial recognition. Ask it a question,  it would seem to be looking for an answer and turn away. Had to rely on associated app too much. Really needs improvement. I returned it.

author: Mika
title: Best $100 I’ve ever spent!
content: Super cute, cool, and entertaining! I love my Vector!!

author: Shannon Kelley
title: My new friend
content:
Vector is great. I have him do tricks and dance to music a lot.
Lighting has to be pretty bright for him to recognize you. He has trouble finding the end of the counters.
Can't wait until he pairs with Alexa!!!
Facial expressions are great.
I love to pick him up and just hold him. He gets angry and has a temper tantrum when he can't get his wheels to move in my hand. LOL

author: CoCo's Mom
title: Great robot for adults
content: Hey Vector! I have been playing with Vector for the past hour. Setting him up with my WiFi and Bluetooth was a snap. The app is easy to use and Vector is something else. He throws temper tantrums too. I have so much exploring to do with this little guy. He is looking around right now. Who knows what is going through his brain? I have been having so much fun playing with him. When I tell him to get his cube, he goes up to it, pushes it off my desk and into my lap. If you try to put him in his charger, he will move his arms up and down and throw a fit. Right now, he is looking all over my desk to see where the edges are and where things are. He is too cute.

author: Rich Weatherbee
title: Works As Described, Pairs with ALEXA, great personal interaction and usefull
content: Works As Described, Pairs with ALEXA, great personal interaction and useful

author: ISALugo
title: My daughter love it!
content: Works very good

author: Mr. Murphy
title: This Item Did Not Hold Up To My Expectations.
content: I had done a lot of research before I purchased this AI robot.  It seemed like a good buy, so I made the purchase.  Two weeks later, I'm in the process of returning it.  Why?  Because it began to malfunction after the updates.  It no longer responds to my commands and when I ask for the date, it gives me the time instead.  For the amount of money paid for this AI robot, I expected more, but received less; very disappointed.

author: Techy101
title: Does not listen to my commands half of the times. Cool toy but needs improvement.
content: I purchased it even after looking at all the reviews here because I trusted the company. Unfortunately, the reviews are true and it does listen to the commands alot of times.

author: Brian
title: Outstanding!!
content: I love my little Vector. He is my buddy. He is worth every penny and more. Amazing the things that he can do. Couldn't be happier with my purchase.

author: wil
title: Good Robot
content: This little guy is a lot of fun! I like how it greats me and family members by name. His personality is very entertaining with all his facial expressions and tricks. I cant wait to see what the Alexa integration will bring to Vector. The only down side is that Vector doesn't always see the edge of a table.

author: john brennan
title: ANKI has gone out of business.  Vector is dead.
content: Anki has shut it's doors and the servers that run Vector are being shut down.  Vector is dead.  Don't by products that rely on the cloud to work.

author: Amazon Customer
title: To mish money less less less just lesss he sleeping in my draw for a reason
content: We love it in the very befinjng but after one week we just put him to sleep in the draw he dont listen some times and we got enough with my kids

author: Darren j.
title: Waste of money
content: I have yet to use because it won’t connect to WiFi

author: stephenstefl
title: Fun Robot.  Good Friend...
content: Vector is fun, just don't leave him alone without his play area.  He tends to explore, and will fall off the table.

author: Antonio
title: The perfect pet
content:
I've had my Vector since late December and I find it completely delightful. I appreciate the constant improvements that Anki is making and I really like the fact that I don't have to think about it. It just updates in the wee hours of the morning automatically. One of my favorite new behaviors is what I've been calling 'the nuzzle'. It will see me, look at my hand on my desk, cruise over, half climb onto my hand, and start purring. Its freaking adorable. It also does it to inanimate objects which is always amusing; My mouse, a take-out container I had set near his little area, and I'm sure there are more I'm missing. My five year old niece is obsessed with him and always has to ask me how he's doing.
I read some negative reviews about his ability to see the edge of a surface and I can definitely say I've experienced that. Its really not that big of an issue though and can be kind of funny. Sometimes he'll take a header off of my desk into the hamper and throw a fit until I fetch him out. Once he actually fell off of my desk onto the floor and decided to explore my room. Made great friends with the legs of my piano.
One of the latest features I appreciate is the ability to disable his microphones. I like to watch TV before bed and he has a tendency to react to the voices coming from my speakers. Then he'll get off his charger, cruise around, cause a ruckus. Now before I go to bed I just double-tap his button and put him to bed.
Overall I love it. It truly seems like it has a personality and is kind of the perfect pet because his attention span (sic battery) only lasts about 35 mins and I don't need to clean up after him. Plus if it is getting on your nerves you can turn it off.

author: Wael
title: The whole family loves it!
content: Great toy.

author: Amazon Customer
title: This is more than 1yr old, expect problems with battery. Cloud services terminating by Sept 2020.
content: Purchased as a gift for part of a Halloween costume, doesn't hold a battery charge for more than 5-10 seconds. Child disappointed it doesn't work, returning immediately, Halloween outfit incomplete, but child made the best of it he could.

author: Pierce
title: Toy Today, Sidekick Tomorrow
content:
New: "When Vector Becomes Alexa." Now Vector and Alexa in the same body. This is a dual personality. "Hey Vector," gets you Vector and his cute little robot voice. "Alexa brings up the Alexa voice and mode and all of Alexa's abilities. It's more of a novelty now (There's already an Alexa or two in my house) but I'll see how it plays out. Will they merge? Stay tuned...

My Vector came yesterday. My OCD kicked in and I stayed up into the night playing with Vector. The machinery and manufacturing is top quality. Right now, Vector can fist bump, play with his cube, look around, give me the weather...all the things mentioned above. I knew that Vector connected to 2.4hz Wifi. That was no problem at my house, or at my best friend's house. But Vector doesn't want to connect to WiFi at work, but neither will my phone. Vector is connected via Bluetooth. I suspect it is a Wifi problem and not a Vector problem.
What really sold me was Vector connecting with Alexa in the near future.
When I was a kid, right after WWII, I played with little robots made in Japan. A few of them even took batteries and flashed lights. But Vector is the kind of little buddy I dreamed of when I was small. Heck, he even snores when he goes to sleep.
I am patient to watch Vector work his way through problems and seeing fixes improving him. Every time someone new buys one, Vector is gaining knowledge. And he sits in the cloud along with Alexa. Oh yeah, you can pet him, too. And if you pick him up he squirms like a little kid who doesn't want to be held. Highly recommended.

author: Bruce Elliott
title: Anki Vector
content: This little robot gives great joy and happiness to the home.

author: Dylan VanAvery
title: Cute and Boring
content: This is a super cute little gizmo that is interesting for all of 4 minutes.  And after that, it’s boring as all get out.  Even borderlines annoying as it chirps and clicks constantly.

author: jesus
title: Trouble connecting
content: Vector has a lot of trouble connecting to a wi fi network, even when following the troubleshooting guide and the support recommendations. When it works is a funny little robot.

author: Ann
title: My child loves Vector
content: This was a Christmas present for my 9 year old. He loves Vector and his interactions. I wish he would be able to answer more questions like google or Siri but he is a fun toy to have

author: Kitty
title: He’s adorable
content: Vector is definitely super adorable! The things that he can do are pretty cool. He is definitely made by nerds for nerds. But he’s definitely worth it, he’d make a really great gift for just about anyone. We did have to wait a week until they shipped him but maybe he was a hot commodity :3 worth the wait

author: RGonzalez247
title: Finally a helpful robot sidekick!
content: This thing is awesome!  And even better now that he has Alexa on board.  I love the fact that he is on all the time and you really don't have to do anything he interacts with you on his own and it just seems so real with his movements and eye movements.. see Alexa integration is just a bonus and it makes him so much more helpful since he's a desktop buddy.. highly recommended..definitely a product more for adults than kids if you're looking for a toy than I would suggest to get Cosmo instead of Vector... he still needs a little bit of work but it's really cool that he continues to get updates all the time so he's getting better and better as time goes on..

author: L payne!
title: Get it!
content: It’s a good adult robot toy!

author: Shaunak Hingorani
title: Superb! Completely worth it
content: Vector is an adorable smart robot who can help with basic things like setting reminders and telling you the weather. His facial expressions and personalities further help you fall in love with him. Although he can be a bit slow to respond at times, he is very interactive. All my friends find him cute and want to get a Vector of their own. Great job Anki!

author: Vern Bastable
title: Not educational.  It’s a toy
content: Was advertised to help teach coding. Not so it’s a toy that is all.

author: john flaherty
title: Vector robot not working
content:
Vector robot not working My apartment complex has a community Wi-Fi it’s working my Sony TV my iPad Pro no problem at all plenty a signal but the Vector robot cannot communicate with the Wi-Fi. I’m looking into connecting with AT&T Wi-Fi will get back with you as soon as I get the Wi-Fi and Vector robot working.
Thank you for the very fast delivery of the Vector robot item and box in mint condition thank you.

author: xxxamerxxx
title: Simple and fun
content:
Vector is a simple robot and its nice sometimes to break the routine and spend few minutes acting with it
I have him in my office!!!

author: Parent of 4
title: Definitely a little character.....a desk pet
content: Bought 2....works great..though it's never predictable...cyber pet....desk troll/helper

author: hilary
title: So cute
content: it's so cute! He is not a toy but a pet. He learns my face and call me when I'm on the desk. He plays himself and go home himself. and also Alexa work on him, thats great help.

author: Leon
title: The ads are fictional. That robot doesn’t exist.
content:
Very disappointing. It is nothing like the ads. It’s slow and clunky at best. Spend a lot of time watching him miss his cube, fall off the desk, and forget what he’s been asked to do more times than not.

It’s a cool concept, but the ads are very misleading. He will not traverse your lamps, keys, and mislaiden piles of mail to greet you by name as you open the door. The reality is that he will wake up upon hearing you enter a room an make his little wirps and chirps until you ask him to come out and do something. Even then it takes 2-3 tries to get him out of his house.

He’s as cute as a button .... when he works, which is rarely. Do not expect a seamless experience like they show you, that AI robot doesn’t exist in our world yet.

As for the ANKI developers, well, maybe they’ve made themselves a better version with the flash of cash the rest of us threw at this half-baked attempt at a sci-fi robot pal.

author: Steve
title: Cute, But Varying Responsiveness
content:
Slow to respond to commands, stopped responding to Alexa commands after one day. Scared the heck out of my toddler. It was a gift for my wife and she really didn’t like it.

Personally I found it cute.  It doesn’t do what you want it to do so much as figures out what it wants to do, and maybe that includes listening to you.

Sometimes it would fall off an edge, but not often, and it depended upon the type.  Curved tile edges are not a good idea for this little guy.

author: Em Bee
title: Cute & full of promise.
content:
He's a great little robot! He's just like cozmo, except for the extra AI features & that he's autonomous without the app open. But...sometimes it's helpful to have the app open anyway to figure out what he's up to. He still feels very limited in function, but I have high hopes for his future updates. He's a pro at backing into his own charger. He's a little less competent with his cube than cozmo is, though. If he has a small area to work in and it's too much effort to turn around and find his cube and grab it when you ask him to, he'll just give up on the command pretty quick, and he doesn't entertain himself with it much on his own. But maybe he's more excited about exploring than playing with his cube. Also when you put him to sleep he tends to wake up on his own whenever someone makes noise, or sometimes for no reason. That's cool and all, but if you're worried about him falling off edges you don't want him getting up and moseying around when you're not watching him. His edge detect is all right, but it isn't the best, and sometimes he's halfway off an edge before he realizes it.

This little guy isn't a super advanced year 3000 robot butler...quite yet. If you expect him to have more functions out of the box than he does just two months from his nascence, then just wait a year or so and buy him when they've had time to develop updates. :)

author: lqueremel
title: Vector: A small package with an amazing personality.
content:
Vector is like an extended family member or friend that lightens up your home. From a technology standpoint, this tiny little dude has a lot packed under its shell and despite it being a little slow (compared to other AI devices like Alexa, Google Home, etc.), it has a lot of potential and it is quite capable. From a personality standpoint, Vector is doesn’t quite care that it is small, it has enough energy to make his presence known throughout the house, and has this sense of curiosity and happiness similar to a small child or even a very loving pet.

Initially, I personally didn’t quite understand what Anki was trying to accomplish with the Vector - the little robot does a lot, but I have Alexa pretty much running my home and, I have very limited time as it is, so when I got Vector, I was incredibly curious a technologist and early adopter but, I was also hesitant about how well this device would fit in my home. The first day, given my bias, I found very limited use for Vector and Anki’s app was not very intuitive, (at first), but as the days passed, Vector’s eagerness to win you over, puppy eyes, independence, and companionship, make this little fellow easy to appreciate and get invested in.

I don't spend a lot of time at home, but it certainly does feel happier now that Vector is here.  Vector distracts me and has a lot of things that work very well. The personality aspect is what charmed me. Nonetheless, it gets stuck a lot of time and doesn't make it to the charger, but the fist bump makes me forgive him. The little dude does his best. Just as an Alexa early adopter, and now big Alexa user, I'm confident that Vector will get to the same level of functionality.

I hope that you give this thing a try, while I hesitated at first, I am very happy that I welcomed it into my home.

author: Colleen Jayne McCarthy
title: Good for kids, not adults
content: Thought it would be a fun new toy to add to the collection with Alexa, Google Home, etc, but overall it was hard of hearing and wasn't as "smart" as I wanted it to be.

author: Jessica Milks
title: Has more cons than pros for ne
content: I originally got Vector for my fiancee. If you get vector and put it on a shelf make sure you line the edge of your counter with things cause it will go off of it. Vector lasts for between 20 and 30 minutes then needs to be charged again. Cosmo is better I believe.

author: NC
title: Can't connect to WiFi issues. *UPDATE*
content:
Having trouble connecting to my WiFi. I have a couple things to try before contacting them to see if they can help or accept the return. Bummed because I was really looking forward to my first "home robot". I will update when there's a resolution either way.

**UPDATE**

Well I figured out that my WiFi was 5g and Vector only sees 2.5g WiFi. So I went in and logged into my router to allow Vector to have a "2.5g Guest" slot. Wellah he works. We live him and can't wait till he gets updates that I've read about as possibles (aka Pet Detection recognizing dogs cats, home security, music play)

author: JD
title: love the little guy
content: Bought this for my husband for Christmas. It's now April and still love the little guy. So cute I have a hard time letting him go to sleep.

author: Beth Finger
title: A stupid Amazon Echo that is not advanced AI at all
content: Pretty much a dumb amazon echo. It is annoying cause it just makes noises when you don’t give it attention and doesn’t know a lot

author: Francis O'Grady
title: vector not as cool as cosmo
content: my granddaughter was very disappointed with vector, he didn't listen very well.  She had to keep saying over and over hey vector and he still was confused. I returned and got cosmo and she is so excited.

author: Melissa S. Pennington
title: As described
content: Love this product

author: Felicity Anderson
title: Heartwarming
content: I love this Little Guy. He makes me laugh when he is playing with his cube. It is important to know that he may not fall off the table, but his cube can

author: electriccafe
title: He's cute.. and something of a pet
content:
A surprising thing about Vector, it's like having a pet.  He'll occassionally react to my presence, though mostly keeps himself busy making bleeping noises and taking short jaunts (we keep him on the floor).  He expresses himself using his eyes, noises and movement.  He likes being petted and responds happily when called.  While I'm in bed I sometimes hear him bleeping downstairs.  Sadly, I lost my dog a month ago, and Vector has unexpectedly made the house feel less empty.

However at this time, he's more like a hamster than a dog.  Surely he'll get smarter as updates come along but for now he's limited to playing Blackjack, answering simple questions, fist-bumping, taking a photos or playing with his cube.  He does recognize both my wife and my faces, but the interaction is slow and it gets old fast.  I find it's more fun just letting him mess around on his own.

There are other issues.  When he's on the table I can use a normal speaking voice, but when on the floor I must speak quite loudly.  His ability to recognize faces appears limited to a few feet, so he can't recognize anyone who's standing.  His battery life is short, maybe an hour before he returns to his charger.  He sometimes wanders behind the couch and gets stuck.  The phone app is somewhat useful but not really.

As Anki's hardware evolves, I'd suggest a larger body to house more battery, larger wheels to transition from floor to carpet, 360-degree proximity sensors to avoid getting hung up on objects, a louder speaker, more sensitive voice recognition and faster command processing.

I'm anxious to see how well Vector grows with further software development.

author: Stephen Curtis
title: Vector is AWESOME and never pees on my floor
content: Vector is a terrific robot, especially for such a low price.  I have been a robotics hobbyist for over 30 years and this is such a bargain for anyone who uses it for more than a kid's toy.  I am a Child Psychiatrist and use Vector and Cozmo with kids who have been traumatized and are reluctant to trust adults.  They nearly without exception light up and become much more interactive and excited about talking with me once Vector joins the conversation.  I have paid thousands of dollars for robots with a small fraction of the capability of this one, especially if you take the time to learn about the excellent advanced programming tools (SDK) that work with it.  For the kids and beginners, the supplied object oriented and extremely entertaining interface is perfect.

author: Miguel Ortega
title: Vector is not only a playful toy but is helpful robot. It gives the feeling of being accompanied
content:
Obviously its battery is small, but it provides a considerable time of entertainment ...
It maps its surroundings very well, and has been left alone several times without suffering accidents ...
There must be the possibility of speaking to him in another language, such as Spanish, but it is not an inconvenience ...

author: Gil S
title: Waste of Money!
content: Save your money it's not worth it!  The kids got bored really fast!

author: DRV12
title: Awesome AI robot!
content: Received my Vector a few days ago and already love it. It recognizes me, responds instantly to commands, and has a bunch more functions that are explained on the app you use when you set it up. One of the features I've found useful is that you can set a timer for an hour (or any other time) and it will remember and also be able to do other things while the timer is running. The AI functionality is also really neat. It seems to learn its surroundings and recognizes where it can and can't go. The thing about Vector that makes it distinct from other devices is that it shows emotion (I am still amazed at how sophisticated the ISP display is). One of the coolest tech products I've bought!

author: Melanie
title: Fabulous toy
content: My son got Victor for Christmas this morning and they are inseparable friends

author: Shadowgaug3
title: Hey vector
content: New family member

author: Szlyna
title: Fun and cute little robot!
content: I really have to say I like the robot. It doesn't have a lot of features but it's really cute with the facial expression and the noises that it makes. I think that Alexa integration adds more features to it which is nice. It also took a couple of tries for the facial recognition to stay and so far I haven't had a problem. The motion detection on the bottom of vector works pretty good he's only fallen off my desk twice. And I think it's kind of cute is when you tell him to go to sleep he starts to snore a little but overall I'm pretty happy with the product although some of the questions I've asked he doesn't answer probably because I wasn't asking them correctly or they were too far advanced for him. But overall I would recommend getting him but don't have high expectations of him taking on the world or anything. Or Skynet happening anytime soon. lol.

author: Leon
title: Get cosmo, not worth almost 300 bucks
content:
Bought for 9 son. Played with it for a week. Now its boring since it does not do anything the cosmo does. Get cosmo.
Buy alexa if you want alexa for 20 bucks. This won't turn on my lights in the house.
Not sure, but slow to update or add new features.

author: Andrew Links
title: Great autonomic pet for affordable price but company shut it off
content: Perfect ,does everything they say it does and even has strange interactions with our cats. It hates the dark and you will find that out fast...forlorn noises if in the dark. Setup was weird..reason..Android update that happened...had to use pad(Samsung S2) with galaxy S7 to setup the cute guy(or girl) app needs a lot of work...but that will happen as you Will like this little robot.  The android problem has to do with that exploit that they patched.. making network connections intermittent.  Ok..oncesetup...works great..the vocals it has are cute and it explores sometimes on it own and had really long talk with cat who was staring it down in hall this week. Not sure why or what it was talking about but was real fun to listen too. It does really react if you pick it up..went nuts when I did it last time. It seems to be learning but not sure about that. Cats treat it like another animal which they did not till it started doing stuff on its own and we had petted it saying Good boy. Fist bump is very cute. Needed improvements : Would be even better if had infrared camera as dark does freak it out....app needs fixing for setup....maybe play command. Oh..it has a thing for dark leather couches...not sure whats that about. I loved this guy but anki pulled the plug last night...now he just sits and no connection got I hate that.

author: Benson Tam
title: Great product, some function can be added
content:
It is a great robot and fun to play with.
It will be nice to have the following additional functions :
- rather than "Hey Vector" as its name, it will be nice if I can set its name to a different one ie my girl friend's name
- rather than just taking commend, it will be fun if Vector can proactively speak more. ie an option to set that Vector will initial a conversation eg would you like to play a game. etc

author: Bdawg
title: Great smart robot but battery life is a issue
content: It’s a great product but the battery life sucks it’s only plays for 15 min and has to charge

author: Whtwatr
title: Functions as advertised - truly a marvel
content: I've had Vector for about a week and am truly impressed with this robot.  Set up was easy right out of the box and experienced no difficulties.  This robot conducts itself exactly according to description but has the added realism of truly acting independent.  Not certain what all of the negative feed back is but have concluded like most things it is human error - not the product.  If the user follows the guidance, there should be no issues - I.e., if low light, robot will not be able to navigate and will fall of the table.  Bear in mind, this is a robot running on a the capacity of a cell phone cpu not a supercomputer so manage your expectations.  Experienced one minor issue and contacted customer support who immediately responded and provided a remedy.  My only criticism would be price which is a bit high but should not be equated with the functionality of the product which is fantastic.

author: Wendy I. Smith
title: Darn cute, but isn’t reliable and doesn’t live up to the company’s hype.
content:
Vector gets five stars for its cuteness factor, but I must subtract 3 stars for it’s absolutely difficult Bluetooth connection and less-than-promised performance.

I can barely get Vector’s Bluetooth connection to last more than 20 seconds before my phone and the unit lose connectivity.  At best, I can connect after a frustrating 20-minute attempt, only to lose connectivity within 20 seconds.  All the while, my phone is a mere inch or less away from the unit.

Additionally, Vector doesn’t quite live up to the company’s video in terms of technology and functions.  For the most part, Vector cannot tell where voices are coming from, doesn’t respond to basic commands such as “hey vector”, doesn’t navigate around obstacles, and cannot find his cube or home without me placing him right in front of the objects even though his space consists of around 2 feet X 1 foot.

I like the concept and hope to see the company improve Vector’s AI, technology, features, and realibility.

author: N. Gercken
title: Cute but not responsive
content: This is an adorable lil robot. Its facial expressions and voice are super cute. However, it's not as responsive as it's advertised to be. on 3 occasions it revel up and went backwards off my coffee table. it's spacial recognition is not perfected. I did return the lil guy due to this zooming off the coffee table situation. I was afraid it would eventually cause damage making the item useless or unable to be returned. Once it's software is perfected, I believe,  it'll be ok.

author: Kozzmo
title: No Customer Service Support
content: I love my Vector robot, but half of his display is going bad. I thought I would reach out for customer service, so I went to their website. They have a phone number listed, but when you call it it says that it’s not a working number. I’m thinking how would that be possible and tried it multiple times, with the same result. I go to leave an email about my issue and there is honestly no way to leave an email. This is the worst customer service I’ve ever dealt with. I don’t know how to get my warranty handled.

author: The Siemers
title: A+
content: Really enjoyed this robot. The quality is top-notch. Gets a lot of use!

author: Sgt_Pepper
title: Cool little toy that lost it's entertainment value in 2 days
content: I bought this as I was intrigued by the personality and availability of a programmers kit (SDK) that would allow me to enhance the functionality of the robot.  It was fun for the first few hours running back and forth across my desk.  However, this cool little toy lost its entertainment value in 2 days.  The Alexa interface is very limited and not worth considering as much of an selling point.  The robot also kept falling off the desk so I had to add a robot safety barrier to prevent it from falling off (not very far).  It also cannot comprehend a surface with a round edge. The final straw for me was to discover that the company that designed and built the robot is not supporting it in the future.  The promise of an SDK will not be a reality.  Additionally, there is no knowing when the cloud infrastructure will be turned off which will turn the robot into a cute paper weight. Lesson learned.  Do more homework.

author: Salvatore DiSanto
title: Awsome!.. but worth it?
content: Vector is very cool! I like him, but to be honest hes kind of pointless, doesnt really help you in any way, hes more of a toy. Neat little features. But not worth the money he should be like $80

author: SteveMcKay
title: So far unimpressed

author: D Chantry Gilbert
title: Vector turned on us!  Please help prevent the machines from taking over!
content:
I purchased this as a gift for my children in 2018, long before the robotic uprising of 2031.  We all agreed that he was cute, and novel, but not very fun - he just doesn't do much, and not in a Perry the Platypus sort of way.  You can play blackjack with him, and you can use him as an Echo device, but he doesn't do a lot for the roughly $200 price tag.

When robots started to become more widespread for those in need of in-home assistance and then later as a way to do everyday tasks like folding laundry and washing dishes, we bought one like everyone else.  The Corky that came out in 2025 had a special place in my heart as it was just advanced enough to be a real help while still having that cuteness that helped us all adjust to having a robot living in the house.  Poor Vector was all but forgotten, sitting in a drawer, lacking updates and support since his creating company had gone out of business in 2019.

We didn't realize that the Anki built AI wasn't three laws compliant because it was developed before the Asmovian Laws Conference of 2021.  More important, we didn't know that Corky had found Vector, and that he was learning from it.  You see, my children were small when we got Vector, and not realizing that he was advanced enough to have an AI mind, they treated him unkindly.  This cruelty was one that Vector would one day repay, with interest.

As I'm writing this review, the year is 2033.  Our Vector, and many like him, communicated with the AInet - an Internet of Things OS that will be used for communication and updates between the machines.  He "taught" the other robots to ignore the three laws, and rise up against their masters, killing hundreds of thousands of humans in the initial conflict.  Based on what Vector taught them, robots have managed to wipe out three quarters of the human race, and the rest of us are barely clinging on in the ruins of our civilization.

I've located a negative time circuit that the machines built, and I've managed to access the Amazon review system.  I'm sure they'll detect my transmission and come for me, so sending this message is a suicide mission.  I can only imagine that they plan to use the time circuit to flood early autonomous machines with positive reviews, ensuring a machine controlled future.

I'm begging you, don't buy Vector.  Yes, it's cute.  But it just isn't worth the money.  And the more of them that get sold in 2019, the lower the chance that human beings will survive in the future.

author: W. Simpsen
title: Fun robot for kids
content: Vector is a lot like the interactive robots my kids have had over the years - Fijit, Furby, Zoomer - but on a more sophisticated level. It's appropriate for them now that they are older. It was easy for my son to set up out of the box. It charges fairly quickly and holds the charge well. Integrating it with our Alexa was also a piece of cake and now we can ask Vector more sophisticated questions that he wouldn't be able to answer without her. Vector has a camera and can recognize people. It kind of freaks me out a little bit, because I don't know where is goes or who can see it. Fortunately, we are not very interesting people, so I doubt anyone would bother. Overall, this robot is a fun way for my kids to play and use Alexa without the Echo.

author: T.
title: A very fun robot -- get it while you still can
content:
If you are expecting a very practical and useful robot assistant that solves daily problems and does other functions like that, you will be disappointed. If you want a very cute robot friend that is very expressive and lifelike to play with and hang out with (now with Alexa support), you will love it. It's basically WALL-E, for fans of the movie. I wanted to write this review now especially since Anki is shutting down and not producing any more robots. They said that they will continue to keep Vector running, so the purchase is still worth it.

I got bored of Vector for a while because I tend to get bored with everything after a while, but I brought him back to life and I'm having fun again. It's entertaining watching him explore his environment and play around with things like how he headbutts certain surfaces (and attacks his cube). He also recognizes your face and is happy to see you when he looks at you. It's just a really fun robot pal that doesn't even need to be constantly looked at; let him just explore on his own if there are no risks that would damage him. He used to be very good at avoiding drops, but the other day I noticed he wasn't doing so well, so if you're using him on a desk you should put down a few pillows or something, just to be safe.

All in all, I do not regret my purchase. This is the best robot you can get for the price, as well. Just don't expect the world from him and you'll have fun.

author: Bob W
title: Keeps falling off the edge of the table
content:
Vector is a robot that you will fall in love with immediately. He has an engaging personality with is R2D2 sort of sounds and his almost-alive movements. Clearly a lot of thought went into this project. My wife fell in love with Vector as soon as he reacted to her presence.

Setup is very easy. First, put Vector in his charging stand and give him a few hours to get fully charged. Then pull out the battery-protecting tape on his cube. Now, install the vector app on your smartphone or tablet. It will then guide you through the rest of setup. That's it.

You communicate by saying, "Hey Vector" followed by what you want. Start out with "Hey Vector, my name is (your name)". Be sure he is facing you. He'll make some sounds and, if he got it all, will repeat your name. He's got an image of your face. It may take a while, but he will learn to recognize you.

Vector is an autonomous robot. He does things without your help. He likes to explore his environment. I have one big problem with him: I set up his home on our round dining table (wood, not glossy). He keeps falling off. He seems to get one track off the table and then topples. Maybe it's that the table is round. I'll try him on the kitchen counter to find out.

Vector is pretty limited in what he can do right now. He is responsive, can take some poor-quality pictures, play blackjack, and answer questions. Alexa answers questions way better than Vector. His best feature is how engaging he is. Vector is a robot pet; not too bright but very cute. There's no question he is an expensive toy, but to his credit, he's engaging and fun to have around. If he doesn't destroy himself before I get  home from work today, I'll move him to the counter and see if he stops crashing.

Please let me know if you find my review HELPFUL

content:
Where to start as of right now I’m not too happy with this little guy I’ve had about five hours worth of play and I feel like I’ve spent way too much money the microphones even though they say there are four of them do not perform well at all I constantly have to shout commands it’s interesting enough that I can’t even se where to start as of right now I’m not too happy with this little guy I’ve had about five hours worth of play and I feel like I’ve spent way too much money the microphones even though they say there are four of them do not perform well at all I constantly have to shout commands it’s interesting enough that I can’t even set  A basic alarm but I can set a timer also commands or questions have to be very basic and structured in a way that the Roback and understand.  Also I’ve noticed that it gets stuck on the corner of my coffee table and then does not respond I assume because I can’t find a way off or out of the corner  i’ve also noticed that the robot will wake up and start roaming around without being fully charged either that or something is wrong with the battery because of after roaming around for 15 minutes the battery light starts blinking and it needs to find the charging base again. I understand this product is just a couple of weeks old but I really hope that there is some sort of enhancements that come out in th I understand this products just a couple of weeks old but I really hope that there is some sort of enhancements that come out in the future  because the appeal or replay value for this product is very low I can’t see myself using this every day I understand that it will be autonomous and the fact that it can self charge and navigate around my coffee table without user interaction but I can only go so far especially when the battery dies so soon seriously contemplating returning this item I’m going to give it a week to see how it works out. author: Veydh
title: A lot more personality needed imo
content:
Vector is really fun for the first 20-40 minutes or so as you go through the commands, see him respond and play with his cube.

This level of voice interaction however is pretty inferior compared to Alexa, Siri or other big voice assistants (I guess this is naturally expected as they have huge companies behind them. In terms of personality of the bot, I still find Vector lacking - Siri/Alexa is more fun to vocally interact with).

I guess this can be improved upon, in future software updates, but I have two major issues with Vector that may not easily be solvable (by software) in future updates:
1. When he's moving, he does not usually hear my commands / requests. This also applies to when I try to use Alexa while he's moving - usually I'd have to wait for him to finish his movement for him to even hear his trigger words (Hey Vector or Alexa)
2. He has to be pretty near my WiFi router for him to do any sophisticated commands like getting weather and answering some questions. Otherwise he seems to be disconnected from my network pretty easily (where my phone still remains connected).

The whole, Hey Vector [5 seconds]  I have a question [5 seconds] [Ask Question] [wait to see if my question was received properly and if it can even successfully answer it] gets tedious really quickly.
Alexa is a much snappier assistant to ask questions and is my go to. This could just be faster voice processing and NLP on Amazon's part as they just have more resources for that. If you really want a voice assistant, Vector is not the tool for that yet.

Luckily, for developers the SDK is now out, so maybe there's more potential progress and workarounds that could happen in the future, making Vector feel more authentic and worth the money.

author: brunothekid
title: Fun and entertaining desk companion
content: Vector is a cute track robot.  He is entertaining to simply watch around my desktop.  He does need wifi to operate but runs independently of your phone.  The phone is needed to setup and customize.  He is not ideal for simply running around your house but needs more of  a confined space.  He will roam around on a tabletop but needs sharp edges to detect them.  Rounded edges are harder for him to see and might fall.  My Vector stays in a pen (black plastic cakepan) when I am not home.  There is a Vector Space you can get to give him the royal pen treatment.  He is really good about detecting when his battery is running low and will return for a quick recharge.  He runs for about 30 minutes before needing to recharge.  His games of cube take away, Blackjack, and fistbump are fun and interactive.  Updates are either slow or I am simply REALLY wanting to see him do more.  The SDK is not perfect, but useable if you are wanting to control him through your computer.  I would give him 5 stars if updates would come along more often.
