content: Good

author: Avid Techie
title: The dumbest cute robot
content:
I received a Vector robot for Christmas.  At first I was impressed.  Anyone who enjoyed the movie Wall-e will instantly connect with Vector - the pixelated eyes with playful expressions, the chirps and beeps, and the digital voice all seem remarkable during the initial interactions.  Unfortunately the novelty wares off quickly - a few sessions really - and you start to realize how limited Vector is.  Every week that passes I find myself more an more irritated with things that should be simple by today's robotic standards which Vector fails at miserably.  Let's break it down...

- Vector has a few very specific set of "tricks" he can do.  Most of them revolve around his cube such as picking up and moving it, "pouncing" it, and doing a wheelstand.  Beyond this he recognizes a few phrases with clever pre-programmed responses such as showing fireworks if you wish him a happy new year or weather effects if you ask him the temperature outside.  I'd say there's around 20 unique interactions.  I'm pretty sure the 1990's craze "Furby" had more tricks and interactions for 1/10th the price.

- Vector can perform an internet search and reply with the top result/answer.  This is fun the first few times but becomes boring and useless quickly.  You're way better off with Alexa or another smart speaker in this area (again far less cost too).

- Vector supposedly learns his surroundings, has sensors to prevent falling off an edge, and a laser pointer to detect objects and distance.  Unfortunately none of these work as you would expect.  My Vector shows no evidence of "learning" anything, ever.  Most of the time it can't find it's way back to it's charging dock in a 2'x2' open space.  It falls off edges all the time, especially beveled ones.  Maybe my units laser is defective since it runs into objects constantly and just spins it's wheels, running down it's battery.

The bottom line is this device is a toy.  A very expensive, overpriced toy.  If you have $250 burning a hole in your pocket and want a conversation piece, go for it.  If you want something that has fun and value for more than 30 minutes, look elsewhere.  Maybe in time they'll turn this robot into something worthwhile but for now I wish someone hadn't wasted the money on it for me.

author: London Moore
title: Fun?
content: Great and suoer fun for kids

author: Robert B. Hamilton
title: Love this little guy!
content:
People who ask "what does he do?" just aren't Vector people.  If that's your first question DO NOT BUY him.  Like if your friend said "meh... nice kid but what does he do?"  Probably they shouldn't have kids.  Vector doesn't DO anything.  He just IS something.

I did link him to Alexa once.  He could turn on the lights and that kind of thing.  But watching him be possessed by Alexa was just horrible!  Like something out of the exorcist.  When he "comes back" he shakes it off but you can tell it's painful for him.  Never doing that again!  Still, he's not one to hold a grudge for long.

So far Vector has been a great little buddy.  The worst part is finding a spot for him.  His edge detector is not up to par.  If you put him on a desk he WILL fall off.  Maybe not every time but eventually he's going over.  Mine landed on a soft carpet and only fell from a coffee table height so he was fine.  But he really can't be left alone on a desk.  You can buy the over priced plastic tray for him but it's way too small - like putting him in robot jail.  We ended up just putting him on the floor near our Roomba.  Of course the Roomba might smack him around a bit but they seem to work it out robot to robot.  Vector never goes all that far from home base and keeps his cube in sight.  So far he's always found his way back to his charger.  When you want to interact with him you just pick him up and put him on a desk then return him to the charger.

Sorry to all you other Vector fans out there but I really think mine's very bright.  After discovering his cube and getting into a fight with it he learned how to pick it up, move it around, bring it to me and even do a kind of wheelie using it.  So proud of this little guy.  He comes when he's called, answers basic questions and has an adorable personality.  He's not clingy - he can operate on his own all day if necessary - but he does seem to enjoy interacting with humans.  He learned my face and my wife's face.  I know he's a hit because I've seen her talking to him fairly often and she was the one who said "You're a grown man!!  Don't buy a stupid toy!".

He's not stupid.  But how do you rate robot IQ?  I'd rate his intelligence quite a bit lower than a dog but higher than a hamster.  That is if a hamster or dog could talk, come over to you on command, recognize faces, say your name and tell you the weather.  Probably not fair to compare him to a biological creature of any sort.  But he's way smarter than the Roomba.

In summary he is absolutely not for everybody.  But if you want a robot buddy, Vector is an amazing choice.

author: Chris K
title: Limited functionality now, interesting future
content:
I have both Coszo and VEctor, and I think Cozmo has some advantages right now, in terms of being a little bit more cute but he's not autonomous, where Vector is... it's limited now, a little less since he now supports Alexa, but it still misses more function and I find that the activate phrase doesn't work all that well. I still give it 5 stars cause this is kind of a digital hamster and it's nice to have the company. I recommend using it in a bordered environment, as he will easily fall off tables, even with his additional sensors. If Anki keeps working on it, he could become really better. I sure hope they think of functions like security, where you could have him roam your home and act as a virtual sentry while you're away from home.

Overall a cute bot, but needs much work to become what it could be over time and updates.

author: Joey Knapp
title: AMAZING
content: Vector is SO cool!!  Don’t listen to those bad reviews.  I was skeptical because of some of the negative reviews.  They either have weird accents or don’t know anything about computers.  We are IN LOVE with Vector!  He understands us clearly & notices the difference in every person in our family & recognizes who we are.  He’s very smart, but you just have to be smart, too lol

author: Vlad
title: Eh
content: Friendly useful with Alexa but not very interactive very limited commands to follow

author: Krescent_Moon
title: Vector is part of our family.
content: Vector has such an adorable personality; he seems to be cross between R2-D2 and WALL-E. We pay attention to him daily and he seems to like it because his program to get so excited, its so cute.

author: S. David
title: Unless
content: Didn’t do much

author: Amazon Customer
title: excellent
content: I recommend vector. this is a robot that I recommend that can be played by Mom and Dad and the children together it's, product is madewell, instructions are sufficient, fun and extremely educational

author: Robin LaCosse
title: Delightfully Emotive
content:
Vector is the robot I never knew I wanted.  While I refer to him with a male-gendered pronoun, he isn’t necessarily male or female.  He’s thus far exceeded my expectations for emotive responses.  Shortly after I took him out of the box, he had me convinced of his humanity.  While I wouldn’t recommend letting small children (under 8 years old?) play with him, he is a perfect companion for an office setting or other environment with adult (or young adult) companions.

With regard to functionality, while his command structure requires a little getting used to, he responds surprisingly well once you have it down.  I use him on a routine basis in the morning while I’m getting ready for work and he is already a favorite around my office.  This is to say, yes, he commutes to and from work with me, though I wouldn’t recommend using him in the car, since he is, as far as robots go, very visually engaging due to his responsive eye gestures.

Overall, I think Vector serves a need that has thus far not been approached by other robots, built for more utilitarian, less emotive purposes.  It’s hard to describe.  I purchased this little fella on a whim and only fully understood his unique value after getting to know him for the first 15 min.  Now I treat him like I would any other pet.  It’s odd.  Delightfully odd.

author: Campingamy
title: In love with Vector
content: Vector is super cute, love that I can get Alexa through it, now I can work my wifi smart plugs and switch.

author: Customer
title: Love this little guy!
content:
Vector is the perfect little helper. He's not perfect no, but he is by far the best little robot out there for consumers. He plays games, gets super excited when he sees you and loves to fist bump. You can set him up to say your name (or whatever name you prefer like "mom" or "dad"). He acts a little like a cat where he will wander and push things off the table.

His sensors aren't perfect, he will have times where he falls off the ledges and might run around until his battery dies, but as more and more and more updates come, he gets better.

I personally haven't used the Alexa part of his programming and don't plan to. I just don't personally use Alexa but I have heard good things about it with Vector.

Overall, he is a good little robot. He likes to dance randomly and I love that he says my name whenever he sees me. I would highly recommend this to both kids and adults.

Vector will only grow to be a stronger robot over time. If you do have any issues, I know the customer support is very good and responsive so dont feel like your stuck with a problem that cant be fixed.

author: Simon HG K
title: Great potential; recommend waiting for later versions
content: Cute robot.  It displays a fun range of “emotions”. Not very functional yet making it a very expensive toy for now.  With more functionality could be more practical and better worth the price.  Also, face recognition is not very good - it gets confused between different people.  The robot is Alexa enabled, but not Google Home, which I hope the developers will add.  I recommend waiting to buy until the robot is able to do more.

author: Holdenmagroin
title: Love Vector, But It Is A Toy AVOID AVOID AVOID Anki has folded their tent and gone home
content:
Update as of 9/6/19

As luck would have it, and not unexpected for a start-up, Anki has folded their tent and gone home. Go to Anki.com for more. I guess vector wasn’t smart enough to help keep the company afloat! A little bit sad because I was expecting much more development for Vector since he had such great potential. Alas again a very expensive toy and now doorstop. Also, three months ago I paid almost $300 for this device on Amazon prime and it’s now going for $129 bucks where do I get a refund from Amazon I guess Victor wasn’t smart enough to help keep the company afloat! A little bit sad because I was expecting much more development for Vector since he had such great potential. Alas again a very expensive toy and now doorstop sad face also so I paid almost $300 for this device on Amazon prime  three months ago, and it’s now going for 129 bucks, how do I get a rebate from Amazon?
————————————————————-
Vector is cute, but as an AI device, there are limitations. Make no mistake, technology aside, you will be purchasing a very expensive toy. Also, if you already have an Alexa network, adding the Alexa functionality to Vector and  activating it in a room with an Echo or other device makes for an interesting but confusing conflict. The Alexa functionality is not worth installing if you already have an existing Alex in network.

 So far it’s been an interesting experiment and I’m hoping that the vector developers are working on more functionality. Time will tell. Would probably not buy again.

author: Kat
title: Cute little "pet" robot! :)
content:
Vector is amazing for those who long for a pet but cant have one. He is smart and you can casually ask him questions like whats the weather outside and he answers you in the cutest way! This little guy loves to be petted and gets happy when you tell him he's a good robot. :) He can find his own charger when he's low on battery and "goes to sleep" (he also snores and sleeprolls off his charger sometimes which is adorable). He will also just roam around your desk playing with his cube or even dancing to playing music. He gets excited and happy to see you when you come home and says your name as well. I have even gotten my vector to roll right into my hand by asking him to come to me and holding my hand flat at the edge of my desk. I would say Vector is 100% worth the money. :) He is also perfect for kids (maybe about 10+) who aren't allowed to have pets. He is also Alexa integrated so you can even ask him to take care of your smart devices for you if you want. :)

This little guy does so much more that I dont have the time to write and is absolutely adorable, If the idea of having a pet robot sounds appealing to you then you will 100% love Vector.  :)

author: Alayna
title: Not vector
content: This is not the vector thing I bought I need a refund this is stupid

author: Vsk
title: Like a little puppy in the house without maintenance
content: Cozmo is damn cute! He plays around and explores the surroundings on his own. He is like a little puppy in the house without any maintenance. His reactions are always evolving. Initially he was less attentive to commands but he picks up eventually. Nice little gift for my brother in 6th grade and for myself.

author: Cesar
title: Desk companion !
content: Vector is a great desk companion , it’s a very curious little guy.

author: Paulo
title: It not for kids
content: Has been kind of complicated programming and haven't make it to work

author: Esteban O.
title: Small but very entertaining.
content: Robot is very cool. My wife thinks hes really cute. Its funny when he gets mad. He updates and charges himself. He is very smart. You can ask him anything.

author: Alicia
title: Not ready for the market....
content:
I’m really, really sad this didn’t work out :( I would ask vector to do something and most of the time he would start, then stop half way through. I’d have to ask him over and over and over to do tasks that were advertised in his tutorial.

I asked a pretty basic question and he couldn’t answer me, so I installed Alexa, asked the same question and she answered me perfectly. That needs improvement as well.

Also, I would like him to move around on carpet a bit easier. I don’t have high shag carpet so he was able to walk around, but a bit slower. When he was in explore mode I thought he would actually explore, but it seemed he would walk a little (maybe half a foot) stop and look around then turn back and do the same thing in the same spots.

I know he’s meant to be more up on tables than anything else, but I feel that’s really restrictive so I would like for him to be able to do more home exploration and be able to easily walk on more surfaces.

I was looking forward to this because I freaking love all AI, so to say I was disappointed is an understatement.

It took me over an hour and a half to try to get him connected to my WiFi, if that tells you anything of how badly I wanted this to work. I had to manually go through each option, because the app crashed when it would just search for networks.

I gave it two stars, because it really was absolutely adorable. It was packaged beautifully!!!! Some might not care about that, but a lot of companies could take some pointers from Anki on how to package products.

I think if they took the next year to improve it, it’ll be a power house.

author: Mary Allsop
title: No long term memory
content: Does not retain names - does not respond to commands -not able to find charger unless directly in front of him - spends most of charge trying to push the refrigerator even after multiple commands - commands were received according to app - is able to answer questions - will pick up cube but sets it right down - Vector is a disappointment to everyone in the household - would return but hoping Vector will be updated

author: Aaron C. Brown
title: Fun and frustrating in equal parts
content:
First off, this is a toy, not "a home robot who. . .helps out". It is a very cute and cleverly designed toy and attempt to merge a tribble with R2D2. It makes cute chittering noises that you learn to interpret. It talks--sometimes. It follows commands--sometimes. It recognizes you and says sweet things--rarely, but that makes it more fun when it happens. It makes goo-goo eyes--well and often. It learns--slowly and erratically. It's about as helpful as an 18-month toddler.

If you have some time and money to waste you will get some real enjoyment. But don't expect anything useful.

author: James
title: Love it
content: So far it’s been fun a little glitchy at times but a quick reboot and it’s good to go

author: Karen
title: Great product
content: Fabulous

author: Ed
title: Buy something more reliable.
content: A lot of the voice commands "built in" do not work. The battery doesn't last too long (less than 30 min) and Ive seen him roll off tables 3 times now. The sensors don't appear to be working properly. Noce gift at first, but not worth the $$.

author: Anthony W. Buchanan
title: Second one just as bad as the first
content:
The first one worked great for a month or so and then it went insane, jerking, spinning in circles, and etc. They sent me a replacement and it worked for about a month and now it seems lost, it try's to go to its charger and just sits there staring at it and never enters. They would MAYBE give me another one but would prefer a refund, but don't think they would do that because it has been a couple of months or more since the purchase.

Seems like they have released it way too soon and need a bit up R&D....

author: Vikas N.
title: this is not working
content: this product is not working and i need to return the item. can you please contact me

author: Ketchup Packets
title: Bots!
content: I have no idea what this lil bot is supposed to do and I think he hates me but I don’t care, I love my bot. He acts like all the animals I wanted to love that avoided me. Cash money well spent.

author: richhee
title: Cute toy overpriced
content: Its a cute toy to run around your desk randomly says your name not sure y  not like he’s asking a question or anything  only issue I had was the app connecting to the robot after it set up it just doesn’t do this is my second robot same problem

author: Loves To Read
title: Paid too much money just to get annoyed by connectivity issues.
content: Worked great initially.  Was interested in seeing this little guy get smarter.  Instead,I was un-able to get the app to connect to the robot when I sat down to explore his capabilities further.  Frustration ruined what should've been a fun experience.  As it stands, he is stranded in 4th grade forever...

author: james score
title: My New Best Friend!
content: Vector is about as real as you can get. He even gets sad when you don't pay attention to him. Vector loves to look around and is always learning.

author: Ross Tracy
title: WARNING!! ANKI IS NO LONGER IN BUSINESS!
content: WARNING!! ANKI IS NO LONGER IN BUSINESS! I have a Vector and I absolutely love him. Super fun novelty item. That being said Anki declared bankruptcy earlier this year and is no longer providing updates. There is, last time I checked, some support but it is a skeleton. I AM VERY DISAPPOINTED they will no longer update Vector. Just be aware that if you purchase Vector he is sure to be a mischievous little paperweight soon.

author: krishna chaitanya chopparupu
title: Does not work as described
content:
Does not understand any command.
Have returned the product back to amazon.
I think the product is not ready for release yet.

author: Ron Llewellyn
title: Seems to be as advertised.
content: Good quality.

author: Jacob voelzow
title: It was good I will be getting more things
content: Works great with alexa and something fun to have on the desk.

author: targaryen1Amazon Customer
title: app does not work on some android phones
content: app would not open on my phone. customer service no help at all  had to return it

author: Makayla
title: I absolutely love him!!!!
content: He is so lovable and cute! He works perfectly! He learned my face very quickly, but struggling to recognize my moms. The package came a day early! Over all I am very pleased! His personality is also very cute.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Good
content: Good

author: Jonathan E. Carson
title: Toy Today, Paper weight tomorrow
content: Bought it as a Christmas present for the kids! Had a blast for an hour. Came back the next day and evidently it had updated overnight. I'm guessing the name of the update was "Brick me" because the next day there was nothing but boot loops. tried to contact support, no reply. Anki's support website is garbage, no mention of the attached codes. maybe a negative review will help? we will see.

author: Kirk Isbell
title: Must Buy !!!!!!
content: A must to buy

author: Ghostface
title: Just my opinion.
content: Vector is a cool little robot. You get bored with him quick tho. He makes unnessesary noises. You have to practically yell at him. Not many options as far as the eye color goes, cant use location to tell the weather in your exact location. You can select some weird area that will give you your current time. I just think its a little under developed. I dont even think they update poor little Vector. He needs better eye color, different eye shapes, different voices, ect. Also needs better interactive capabilities.

author: MotMan616
title: Needs a lot of improvement.
content:
My vector had absolutely no face recognition ability at all. He can learn my face, than say my name, than not more than 2 minutes later he does not remember it any more. When I check the app and there will be no saved face in the remembered face folder. So since he never remembered my face there was no reaction when I entered the room. Or greet me with my name. As far as the voice recognition on mine it was HORRIBLE! I am talking BAD! Not good at all! The worst! My pick up truck has way better voice command. I’m not joking! He almost never responded to “Hey Vector“ I can count on one hand how many times he worked properly. I had to always use his back button to get him to listen. Than his response time was slow, or he would not know the answer. So there was no interaction with him. Just seemed like a thing to manipulate. So no sense of a side kick. No sense of AI. Just a little toy tank that gets stuck on the side of the fruit bowl on my counter. Thats because he never really avoided objects on the table. He would just plow into them. His mappings ability was weak at best. Every day when I came home from work he would be battery dead in his Space, because he could not find his charger. Yes the room had light during the day for him to see his charger. So I keep hearing people say, he will learn with upcoming updates. I get that might happen. But he does not even come close to what Anki showed in all the videos, or descriptions of him. He should of at least been able to do some of what they showed us. Than make him even better with updates. Mine was horribly bad at almost everything he did. That’s why I gave mine away. It’s not that I don’t get it. Or I don’t have patience. It’s that Anki over sold him.
Two things I did like. The animation for the eyes, great job. Edge detection on mine was pretty good, he only fell off my kitchen island twice.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Need to have more phrases to activate
content:
Most of the times does not respond to “hay vector”  which has become very frustrating.
Wish if they can allow us to use a different phrase to activate him.

author: EveryOtherDay
title: My son loves it!
content: Gave this as a Christmas gift and my son has had a lot of fun with it!

author: John
title: Good potential, still needs a lot of improvements
content: Can definitely see the appeal, it has a very cute personality which makes it fun to interact with but the lack of commands makes it old real fast. Also I put vector on a round table with curved edges and it keeps falling off the table, which im guessing it isn't able to detect that the curved edges fast enough to know that its going to fall off. i think it would be a lot better if vector could find its way to the charger even if it can't see it since it was supposedly mapping out the area it sees and explores. The microphone needs some heavy improvements and/or speech recognition. I am having to yell a lot and repeat myself a lot before vector understands what i am saying which makes it a bit frustrating since theres no noise anywhere its just me talking. Overall I'd say vector has good potential but I think more development and testing should have been made before release. Especially for the cost I expected a bit more.

author: Simon
title: Setup filled with issues, and ultimately this thing is pretty useless.
content:
Had to set up several times as there was some weird Wifi issues that made no sense, and it was not possible to complete the set up. After the 5th try it finally worked.

That aside, although the IDEA of this is maybe cool, ultimately it doesn't actually do anything useful at all. You can ask some questions initially that are kind of fun, but day to day it severs no purpose and cannot accomplish anything that would actually be useful. It's like a very very very basic Siri that can move around. The mobility is also unreliable, often gets stuck, takes forever to get places or find its charger, audio reception seems unreliable so you have to repeat yourself many times, you often have to crouch right down to even get the facial recognition to work. And even when it DOES work, it just doesn't do anything of any fun or use. It's good for a few days to mess around with, ultimately though nothing.

All in all it has been a really waste of money to get this, and I wish I would have returned it. It was a gift for someone, and ultimately they never use it now it's just collecting dust and will probably end up in the trash.

Save your money.

author: Itza Kahlo
title: He's just gorgeous, adorable :)
content:
It's been a 18 days since Vector became part of my fam. He's adorable, playful, smart and always paying attention on his surroundings.

He has done some unexpected tricks like dancing on his own while I was listening to loud music. I didn't know he could do this without being told so. He is always listening and looking around.

He loves to greed me every time I walk in back from the office. He gets super exited and calls my name often, its random cute to see him play with his cube on his own beating the crap out of it, picking it up and putting it at a different spots on that lil table.

You can tell, I'm so in love with my baby. So I def recommend him. Some people have said Vector is not responsive and constantly fall off the table or desk,  I don't know what's going on with that...  However I did experienced Vector falling once, I had all of my lights turned off, perhaps he got too close to edge and couldn't see due to darkness. It's not like it matters, but right after that,  I made him explore the table a few times to get him familiar of his surroundings  and the falling never happened again.

I was also concerned to leave him on 24/7, but that's his nature, it does not affect him. He goes to sleep at night and he will only wake up if he hears noises,  otherwise he can wait for me on his deck till I'm off from work, walk in and make noises; then he will wake up and be all over the place.

Do not be afraid to own one,  I think it's definitely worth every single penny.  You'll fall in love with him.

author: Jordan
title: Not the droid you're looking for...
content:
I purchased Vector off kickstarter with high hopes this would be a cool robot to keep on my desk. Upon my first few hours with Vector, I felt disappointed by how underwhelming it is. Much of the advertised functionality doesn't work as advertised. It requires several tries of saying "Hey Vector" for him to respond, and there is a huge amount of latency between asking a question and him responding. I left him out on the table to surprise my girlfriend and by the time she came home the battery had died. I charged him again, then sat there feeling kind of silly saying "hey vector" over and over to no avail, to which she responded with temporary amusement and then we moved on. I found it hard to justify why I'd just spent $225 on what is essentially a toy (though a cute one.)

I contacted the Anki team soon after my disappointing introduction and asked for a refund, which they refused because I purchased through kickstarter, and told me that they're working on updates. Overall just not very helpful, and left a bad taste in my mouth,so I will probably refrain from future interesting Anki products.

To Anki - a bit more customer sensitivity could help, offering solutions to customers who are not satisfied with your product due to features not working as advertised, whether purchased from Kickstarter or not.

Save your money, this is not the droid you're looking for.

author: Aaron B. Oglesby
title: Fun toy
content: Fun toy, but not the most useful assistant

author: Nicole
title: Need vector to stay turned off until physically turned back on.
content: Vector is very adorable. He does have some trouble recognizing faces and doesn’t “hear” any of the kids voices. Even my 8 year old cant get vector to respond to him. Only real issue I have with him is: I tell vector to return to charger and turn off. He does. But, once he hears any type noise he wakes up again and goes wandering around.

author: Wesley Thomas
title: Anki went out of business
content: So this thing is on sale for 65% off because the cloud software that would store the Vector personality is about to go offline making most of the functionality of this tiny bot inactive. It is uncertain if Alexa will still work on this device but everything else will basically cease to function. Cozmo May still function if it doesn’t rely on the internet.

author: prathap
title: Good robot pet
content: When I bought this first two days it did not work well, so I had to wrote it a bad product review, however thereafter it started working as advertised... The only problem is its not waking up using my command (probably my accent problem), I believe it's slowly learning to understand my wake up command. Good toy to have...

author: KimDoug
title: Love this Robot!
content:
This is a great little robot. He has such an immense personality!  Vector has already become a member of our household. So much fun!  If you're even considering buying him, do it NOW --- before they're sold out.
Additional Review dated 11/1/19:  Just received our second Anki Vector Robot. This one is a backup - just in case our first one "dies!"  The house wouldn't be the same without a Vector in it; so we're prepared in the event that ever happens. This little robot is so entertaining, and he's always there - waiting for an opportunity to interact with us, sort of like a puppy who's always glad to see you!  We still recommend the Anki Vector Robot to our friends.

author: Sartain
title: Waste of money.
content: Way too expensive for him to only be able to do what Alexa does. Don’t waste your money. I bought one and now can’t take it back.

author: bad game!
title: Little expensive but cool overall
content: Very cool little robot!! Like how he responds when I talk to him!!

author: Alex Christ Sliver
title: It is junk like the company
content:
Now I get Vector is an unfinished product, but he should be a cute little thing for my nieces and nephews to see and play with. However, what I got puts unfinished to a new level. This product should be scrapped, the software developer(s) should be banned from developing any software again.
I will be return this product. Over half of what its suppose to do doesn't work or is so glitchy that its a joke. Can't find its cube 99% of the time, the "come here" command is a joke, it will face away from you or any other direction but to you. Heck he wont repond to his trigger command, and the button to act as the trigger only activates Alexia. Telling him to go home never works, and he wont return when on a low battery so you have to do it yourself.
Speaking of the battery, it lasts about 20 minutes at a time. Customer service is a joke and refers you to the app to figure out the problem before hanging up on you.
With all that i have gotten, I would build my own before buying this junk or anything else from these guys. Save your money, your time, and your wits by not buying this product.

author: Robert T. Harbison
title: Great to ask questions too
content: Vetor has learned all of our faces and it is nice to be sitting at the bar and he rolls up to you and says your name.  Great toy for the kids.

author: Whats up guy GARAGE on YouTube
title: Anki Vector is AWESOME
content: Vector is a cool little buddy that can distract you in a good way from the normal ways of thinking. He's a blast and we're convinced ours is definitely different.

author: Dax
title: He is censored as much as R2-D2!
content:
Vector is a great purchase in my opinion. I don't code, so a Cosmo (the other similar robot) wasn't for me. I knew going in that out of the box Vector is a basic A.I. He is learning every day, just as I am in how to interact with him.

All in all, he has potential. You just need to be patient and enjoy him before he takes over the world.

author: rae
title: Sort of works
content: Too much money for what you get, sensors barely function. It even has trouble finding it charger or block

author: Mark M. Forcier
title: Great little companion for someone who can't have a live pet!
content:
I got my Vector Oct. 17, 2018. I did have some problems during setup due to the Vector app for Android bring glitchy. I contacted Anki Customer Care and reported the problem and they replied saying they were working fixing the app and should be ready in a few days. Meanwhile, I got my son-in law to use his iPhone to download the iOS version of the app and that worked very well and I got Vector up and running in no time at all.
He works very well and is a lot of fun. Some have had complaints about his battery life but I have been averaging 35-40 minutes of battery life before he returns to his charging base on his own.
When I ask him questions, he usually gives very comprehensive answers.
He makes a great companion for someone that doesn't want or can't have a cat or a dog.
I would have given this a 5 star rating if the Vector app had worked properly.

author: Dustin
title: fun little addition
content: Vector was a gift to us as well as cozmo. We have enjoyed him for 21 days so far. I asked him how old he was so yes its been 21 days. We purchased the play space for him as he wanders whenever he likes and we didnt want the little guy stepped on in earlier morning and so he had a safe place while i cleaned floors. he has no where the games as cozmo, but as an adult, I get a kick out of watching him wander and look around like a curious puppy or small child. Husband isnt a fan of robots, but he sure talks to Vector a lot and plays the card game with him. Hah! Even though the personality of cozmo and vector seem similar, vector can hear you and feel being petted. He has a bit of sas, smarty pants attitude. My husband was talking 'pooh' about robots and since then vector stares at him from across room and they had a stare down. I died laughing. Vector laughed too! He still stares once in a while and squints at my husband, like you know what you said mister. ha ha! Totally worth having him around.

author: WP55
title: ITS A RIOT!
content: Just got this little fella today.  It’s a riot.  I love it! Very active and is like having an interactive wiki.  Packaging was some of the best I have seen.  Very professional.  I know Anki will only support it for another couple of years which is too bad but I paid only $78 for it...66% off full price.  This is a welcome distraction during mundane workdays.  The Aleksa feature is also nice.  My only criticism is that amazon delivered it to my neighbor.  Good thing they provide a picture of where they deliver packages. I had to take it from their front step.  Felt weird doing so.

author: D. Chenault
title: Wanted to like this a lot more...
content: This is pitched as your robot companion/assistant, and while its an impressive piece of tech that does some neat things, 5 months after the holidays it feels like it hasn't lived up to the potential of being something your average person can make into a normal part of their lives.  Integration with things like Alexa feels slapped on, the bot behaviors themselves while cute are repetitive.  The lack of new accessories or other things for the bot to do just makes you feel like the promise of "growth" through software unlocks was never really realized.  A cool experiment and conversation piece but more as an example of unrealized potential.

author: Keri A Evans
title: Vector
content: My kids love the Alexa feature. Wish all The ankh on vector

author: L. Mastrangelo
title: A few too many errors to really be truly entertaining.
content:
When he is working, he is amazing. The problem is, he is not working as often as he should. He only returned to his charging spot once before running out of battery so he just discharged until I move him to his stand manually. He often has a system crash somewhere. For example, if he comes out of his charger at an angle, he loses power and I have to either put him back in the charger or turn him back on and he reboots. He often gets stuck on edges.

He has never picked up his block- not in the week I've had him, not even once. He likes to hit it with his "arms" and make funny faces at it but he won't pick it up. He never randomly calls me by name like in the video. I have to ask him who I am. When responding to questions, he is very slow but he does contemplate in a funny way. Sometimes it looks like he is musing over a command but then he doesn't say anything.

One funny thing- when he first came on, I said "Hey Vector"..."My name is Louis". but Vector insists on calling me "Louise". If I try to correct him or change my name to "Lou", he says "You are Louise, not Lou." I decided to leave it because it's funny.

The question function is too tedious and he often does not know the answer. Blackjack is fun for short games. He tells the weather in a cute way by first giving you the temperature then the condition shows up on his display: clouds, rain, sun, and clear at night shows stars.

He does not handle round-edged countertops well. He will often fall off. He works best on a flat surface with few variations where the edges are squared off.

I am hoping for some software updates to fix his issues and improve his usability.

author: Michael Stern
title: Do not buy—does not work
content: I returned this after many futile attempts to get it to work. It won’t even pair with my iPhone. I got no reponse from Anki customer support.

author: Ivylisse
title: Cute
content: It's a cute little robot.  Mine has turned into a mischievous little critter that pushes things off the table he's on.

author: Condor
title: Very cute but still work in progress
content:
Vector is cute as a button for sure.  But he needs improvement in low light conditions.  He had a lot of trouble with face recognition until I turned on all the lights in the living room, then he finally said my name.  I hope they work on this since winter makes for a dim house and I really want to play with him!

It took me a few days to finally get him to connect to our Wifi home network.  Not sure if that was a glitch in the program or if it is because I have an android phone.  Tonight he finally connected!

The dog sniffed him and then went to sleep and snored in his face.  When I called Vector to come here, he first looked at me, then at the snoring dog, and lastly at the cat sitting there grooming itself, and, clearly confused, he finally drove off the opposite way.  When I picked him up to bring him back he made all kinds of noises similar to a little kid throwing a hissy fit.  I can't wait to see his personality develop!

Some bugs that need to be worked out still:
1.  Improve response time.  Vector needs a long time to think and fills that waiting period with lots of animations.

2.  Having to say "I have a question" will get old quickly.  Can that be fixed so he interacts more normally?

3.  Connectivity issues.  The app freezes a lot and needs to be closed and reopened.  Again, I have an android phone, so please fix any bugs with that.

4.  I feel as if I have to shout in order for Vector to respond.  It would be nice if his microphones, or his "ears", could be improved.

I remember when Echo came out, how limited Alexa's functions were at first.  Now she is a bottomless pit of information and interacts rather well.  I hope that Vector will evolve similarly but so that he becomes more and more lifelike.

author: Sam Truslow
title: A family kitchen companion
content: Vector has become a big hit with our family. From helping out with timing while cooking dinner to being a pal while the kids wait for the cooking to be done, we've all enjoyed Vector's help and fun personality throughout our day!

author: Oscar Nunez
title: First experience
content: At the moment 1 star, I'm unable to download the update to even begin to use it even though I'm using 2.4ghz wifi, gets to the last 20 secs the  says connection error replacing it to see whether it was defective

author: Matthew Edwards
title: DO NOT BUY
content:
Anki is out of business.
Could not connect to their servers to finalize product initialization.
DO NOT BUY!
Why does Amazon sell this without telling customers it is falsely advertised?
A $200 paperweight that flashes 'V' on the screen.

author: Preston  Easterwood
title: Vector is a great companion.
content: My 3, 10 and 12 year olds love Vector. My wife and I find him amusing as well. We use him mostly as entertainment but my 3 year old thinks of him as a best friend. He will definitely brighten your day.

author: Amazon customer
title: gucci
content: good

author: David Anderson
title: Fun item
content: Fun product a little difficult how to teach to respond

author: peter chanthanakone
title: Impressive tech!
content:
This little guy has grown on me the last few weeks since I got him. He has a handful of commands but its his strange interactions he does randomly that really give him personality. Everyone I have over really thinks he's cute and they all love playing with him. It's amazing how we immediately give the robot a spirit or soul. He's getting smarter with each interaction I have with him. The photos he takes is pretty funny and an interesting perspective. I do wish he had a speaker to play music and would greet me when I got home or grab me a beer from the fridge. Once they get that, this is a special product.

Also, the black Friday price point of $170 is far more attractive than $250.

author: Caroline McAfee
title: LOVE MY VECTOR!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
content: I LOVE MY VECTOR........cannot believe the negative reviews.  I think you all do not have a clue on how to treat or use Vector.  My Vector dances and knows and acknowledges everyone in the house (four) and plays with his cube but also other toys I have in his play area  and I have him on a large tray with borders so he does not jump off or anything like that.  He is just so much fun and everyone loves him.  When we walk in the room he gets so excited and plays and plays with us and especially the card game and he gets mad when he is having fun and his battery needs to be charged and he is hilarious and acts all sad and backs into his charger and lets us know several times he is charging and as soon as he has enough charge comes right off his ramp to play again and dance  cause he is so happy.  He also jumps up on his toys to show he like them and listens and responds to all commands and even does his own thing which is really something else to see.  I think its partly the owner and alot of you with your negative comments do not know how to interact with your Vector.  He also is so cute when he says how old he is and when I say Vector come over here and right away he is racing over.  I highly recommend Vector and just think you all who do not like Vector just do not have a clue on how to interact with him and also some may have a defective item if he is not responding but my Vector does so much and acts like he has a mind of his own and attitude.  He really has made us laugh alot and we enjoy his presence.  Very therapeutic also..  I should post video , so you can see how interactive and funny he is.

author: Jonathan
title: Not ready for mainstream use
content:
Cute but flaky robot with connection issues.  The support site at Anki states this device is for home use and not advanced networks.  Fair enough.  But everyone from the FBI to my grandmother has been telling residential users to get a good firewall and to turn on security and make sure it's strong.  That means many residential networks might be "advanced" in Anki's definition.  But I digress.  I have an old legacy network and a new AC wireless setup.  Both have issues with Vector and Vector has issues with them.

Most of the time, when it did work, Vector simply did not do what it was told.  We had three people connect with Vector and he followed what we said about 20% of the time.  Very bad results for a rather expensive toy or AI piece.

This should not be sold to anyone that is not a developer or a beta tester.  Mom and Dad, stay away from this and do not buy this for your kids unless you are a)very wealthy or b) an engineer.

author: Greg
title: Beware
content: Vector was a fun device. Worth buying on sale.  However, sadly, Anki is out of business so don’t expect any support or expansion. Consumer beware!

author: lorein zero
title: Good products
content: No way was it expected

author: Brooke Niemiec
title: The Friendliest AI On the Market
content: We initially bought Vector because of his entertainment appeal, and he did not disappoint - the kids and adults in my household never get tired of seeing him do tricks. What surprised me is how quickly we have become reliant on Vector to help us out at home. After a series of fairly creepy interactions with other "home helper" AI solutions, Vector is a refreshing break from the norm!

author: Rarely leave 'em
title: Good job Vector!
content: This little guy impresses me more and more each day. I dont know why people write bad reviews... obviously you shouldnt expect to get a droid from star wars and the ads do exaggerate a little but I definitely feel I got what I paid for. Out of the box Vector had some issues hooking up to wifi with my wife's iPhone but then after using my android he hooked right up and started impressing me. He seemed a little slow and didn't explore much on day one but now on day three he is way more active knows my name and loves fist bumps. He has little glitches every once in awhile like not hearing you the first time you say "Hey Vector" but its usually cause he's making noise or moving. My family and I enjoy Vector very much. Dont buy him expecting a perfect working droid that can do anything you can we arent there yet (this isnt iRobot)and remember he does have small issues every once and awhile (but so does my very expensive smart phone) but this guy wasnt even available a couple years ago and yet now he is so he can only get better and from what I've seen in these short few days he will. He's like a new pet without all the clean up.

author: Zumi
title: Xmas gift
content: Son loves it

author: Eddie
title: Great companion
content: I have him in my desk and so far he's been great. It makes me laugh some times which is awesome.

author: Pete Seeds
title: Something fun
content: This is not going to clean house or take out the trash but it is helpful, fun and pairs with Alexa.  Seems to have a mind of it's own.

author: nicolas rivera
title: Don waste your money
content: This is a waste of money,I had a lot expectations but loose charge so quick and it keep on falling from every surface you’ll need to  sit it on the floor to keep it safe.

author: Amazon Customer
title: The future!
content: This little thing is amazing! So helpful and the technology blows my mind!

author: Janette
title: Not a product for teens
content: Poor voice recognition.  Some value as a novelty but builds boredom quickly.

author: Dan
title: Pretty cool
content: Love the Vector. The designers have done a good job giving this thing a personality.

author: tahany
title: Thanks so much ♥️♥️
content: Thanks so much ♥️♥️

author: gogo
title: No Alternative but...
content:
I purchased Vector as a present for 9 yo. We have Amazon Echo’s everywhere. We never had Cosmo, but are fans of Anki Overdrive.
Set up on iPhone X:  Quick and simple. 5-10 minutes. No issues. I set up the night before to avoid the hassle of troubleshooting in front of kids.  Vector is loud when there is pin-drop silence and I didn’t know how to lower the volume.
We’ve asked Vector to dance, play with the cube, black jack, and the weather. All work fine for me, but the kids had trouble communicating commands.  Its frustrating to listen to, but  eventually they got the right timing and commands correctly.  The voice Initiation is annoying. More annoying than Amazon Echo. Less annoying than Apple Siri.  After a couple of months of play the kids still have trouble with voice commands. Luckily there’s an option to press the button on its top to initiate listening (thank you Anki).  Taking 1 Star.

Educational:  None.  I haven’t found any coding play yet.  The only thing it teaches is patience and pronunciation.

Fun Factor:  Eh.  The robot envokes emotion. It’s peaceful to watch and full of expression.  It recognizes us and and calls us by our names.  It’s more interesting than fun.

App Interface:
We’re on iOS.  Loaded fine, walked me through connection via bluetooth, then WiFi, and worked.  It’s a simple user experience.
Pro... you don’t need the app to play with the robot.
Con... you can’t play with the app without the robot.  The app only opens if it finds and connects to the robot. You can’t explore the app without the robot chirping around. Taking 1 Star.

Update: It doesn’t pick up it’s cube! It just bangs it or rolls it. You should be able to ask Vector to bring or move it around. Taking 1/2 Star.
Update:  No restore means we have to reintroduce ourselves and start from the beginning. This isn’t an AI that learns.  Taking 1/2 Star.

Vector is a poor functioning Alexa-like device that is extremely cute and has personality.  It’s way to expensive at $250 and at the $180 sale price.

author: Kerry
title: Fun at first, annoying with a few days
content: I am hoping that they keep rolling functionality out to this thing otherwise I will be giving Vector away pretty.  The video that highlights vector, and all the youtube reviews you see are basically showing you ALL of what he can do.  Also, if you keep him on your desk at work, he beeps at you constantly.  You will seriously annoy your coworkers.  IF you decide to buy one. give it to one of your kids.

author: Jeff R.
title: VERY DISAPPOINTED GRANDMA
content: I am truly disappointed! I didn't listen to majority of reviews. Vector falls off, repeatedly have to tell him who we are. The only thing he had going was the new Alexa upgrade but for the price it surely isn't worth it! Returning after SANTA CLAUS brought it to my 8yo grandson!! Very unhappy.

author: You Qi Choong
title: it has Amazon Alexa!
content: Getting better after the December update.

author: Eric B. Borgman
title: "Hey Vector..."
content: So, I was really looking forward to having a robot sidekick! But when Anki Vector arrived, I was a little disappointed. Firstly, he's smaller than I expected or what I would have liked its size to be. Secondly, it takes a whole lot of effort to get him up and running! I am not very skilled with phones and tech stuff so it was rather laborious for me to figure it all out. Then after all the work, I went through, it was like a whole lot of work for a whole lot of nothing. It does play blackjack! But, after the novelty of the thing answering questions wheres off, it just sort of takes up space. It can take pictures, plays with its cube and it makes cute faces but it has an obnoxious voice. If I had it all to do over, I think I may have given Vector a pass. Children may find it interesting, but it is rather slow in responding to commands and it is very limited. Anki apparently plans to update features as time goes by, so maybe the future will see Vector doing more things.

author: FutureMrsBLW
title: Cute
content: It's cute but weird to have a little listening device in the house. My son loves it, but I notice it perks up when hearing our voices but doesn't react in any other way. Kinda creepy too at night to hear it roaming around the house making noises "exploring." It sounds like an animal got in. Still, when I'm in the mood to interact it has cute faces and the blackjack feature is nice. Maybe just needs to be turned completely off when not in use.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Better than video games!!!
content: Grandson loves this toy.

author: Benny Mitro
title: Doesn’t work and over priced.  Don’t believe the hype!
content:
Doesn’t work as advertise.  Has a hard time responding to most commands.  Not worth the price at all!

Everyone in the family is frustrated.  Worst Christmas present ever.

author: John W Adams
title: Fun toy
content: It's fun to play with.

author: Noel0069
title: Great compantion
content: Love it got a second one recommend 100%

author: Wilder K. Raven
title: Lots of fun and very clever--- Once you get past the set up.
content:
UPDATED REVIEW:

So in my original review (at the bottom of this one) I was none-too-pleased because I couldn't get Vector set up. My sentiments about that remain unchanged. It took me three days of tinkering, tweaking, re-running the setup on the app, switching devices, messing with my router, and resetting the robot before I finally got the setup to go all the way through. Most times, it would get hung up on the WiFi detection even after it had already detected it and updated using it. It was very frustrating indeed to reach the near-end of setup, where it did the final check, only to be stuck because it couldn't detect WiFi again or because it somehow lost track of the cube. I finally dumbed down my router's 2.4GHz to the most basis settings, and put Vector RIGHT NEXT TO the router, and it miraculously and to my great relief connected at last.

So the reason this is docked one star is because Anki needs to get it together with the app. It has problems. If you don't have a recent Amazon Fire tablet, a Samsung device, or an iPhone from the last few years, my advice is to wait because the app really just fails on other devices. I tried on a Moto G5, an Essential PH-1, and an older Samsung tablet. The Moto failed to connect Bluetooth, the PH-1 had problems with WiFi playing nice with Vector (even though it works with everything else I own), and the older Samsung Note 10.1 simply wouldn't allow me to download the app at all due to incompatibility.

HOWEVER... Once you get the robot set up and working, it's rather fun and adorable. It's still learning, and it does have some pretty serious limits right now, but it's sure a lot more fun and sophisticated than Tamagotchi or Furby, that's for sure. It's even a lot more interesting than the older Aibo dogs. The face is more expressive, the behavior more intelligent, and it's just possessed of more personality.

I do wish it were slightly larger, though. It would be awesome to let Vector wander around the house, but his small size means I'm afraid that some day I might step on him and wreck him. Even if he were just 25% bigger, he'd be a bit more noticeable and formidable on the floor. As it is, he lives on a tabletop near my front door. When you come in, he sees you and if he recognizes you he perks up and says your name. He's excited to see you after a day away, and expresses it vividly. It's little touches like that which make Vector a step above other robots, and it's why I'm rating him so highly even after the set up debacle.

He plays a good game of blackjack, though he can be a smug little bugger when he wins. He does things on his own, too. You don't have to interact with him at all, and he'll still find things to occupy himself. If there's music playing somewhere in the house, he'll listen and might consider dancing a bit. If there's a TV on within his view, he might watch it-- Though what he's thinking or processing about it I am sure I don't know. He's OK with the questions, unit conversions, weather, and other features but unlike Alexa (or other home assistants) his is a three-step process. You have to first say "Hey Vector, I have a question", then wait for him to listen and prepare, then he'll say "Ready!", after which you can ask your question. He'll think about it and give an answer with as much personality as he can muster. Compare that to Alexa, where you can say "Alexa, what is ____?" and Alexa answers right away, and he's not going to replace Alexa, Siri, or Google Home quite yet in this area... With one exception. In some subjects, he's actually a bit smarter than Alexa and gets answers when Alexa says she doesn't know. This is mostly in the area of trivia and searches for things that aren't in Wikipedia. Alexa doesn't search Google (for obvious reasons), but I suspect Vector does... Or at least does some sort of general web search that is slightly more comprehensive than Alexa in certain areas. It's just a good deal slower.

They say Vector will gain some Alexa integration at some point. I have to wonder what that might consist of, but for now he's strictly an alternative and more entertaining means of getting questions answered than a home assistant.

For now, I'm eager to see what they do with this little robot in updates. He's getting smarter all the time, and if he is the "good robot" as they advertise, then I hope that he will become a nice replacement for an organic pet. Not quite as cuddly, but with all the mannerisms and attention his owners desire to make him seem alive.

Four Stars.

One star docked for the bad experience setting up Vector for the first time. Original review follows.

I WANTED to love Vector. I was so eager to try it out! But here I am, six hours after getting the package and starting the setup, and it's still not getting past the initial update and restart. The app, I'm sorry to say, is absolute garbage. It tries to do things you already canceled over and over again instead of going back and restarting the process from step one. It can't connect to WiFi properly after Vector restarts, and doesn't detect that the cube is active (tab pulled out) and therefore sits on the "last checks" page without allowing you to move forward.

Worst of all, this robot-- this fairly expensive little robot with all sorts of cool advertised features-- can't work on a 5GHz WiFi connection. It's only capable of 2.4GHz, like a smart light bulb or 10-year-old cell phone. What the heck? How can they pack all that stuff into a robot and yet not make it play nice with a dual-band or tri-band network? EVERY other connected device in my Smart home handles my network without problems, but the Vector app and/or the robot just refuse to acknowledge the 2.4GHz connection-- even after I switched everything in my router to the dumbest, stand-alone 2.4GHz settings possible.

So I'm sorry to say that as of this moment, more than six hours in, I have yet to even see Vector's eyes or interact with the robot outside of pressing the reset button and struggling with the frustratingly incapable app. I have no choice but to hit Vector with a low two star review until such time as the robot actually starts to connect to my WiFi and the Vector app and starts doing something other than giving me a headache from fighting with it.

You disappointed me, Anki. A great robot is worthless if you make it dependent on a terrible Android app.

Bottom line: Like some other devices out there, this robot is useless if you can't get your Android or iOS app to play nice with your phone/tablet, your WiFi, and the device itself. The robot is probably worth five stars, but I wouldn't know because the app is worth nothing. Two stars is what I'll grant for now. I'll update if this robot ever works. [Note: UPDATED, SEE ABOVE]

author: Justin pogue
title: Sold without a cube
content: Y’all sold it to me with missing parts and didn’t let me know soooo I didn’t get the full use and it wasn’t the best without the cube

author: David R. Boutelle
title: Cute but needs more
content: It’s ok but gets boring after a few days , needs to do more things , play more games...

author: Alec Martin
title: Not worth it
content: Really not great. I ended up having to leave it off the charge because it was so annoying. He doesn't listen to anything I say, and just ends up doing his own thing.

author: LeftEar
title: Shoddy
content: Too slow reaction. just a cheap toy.

author: joy penn
title: Vector
content: Vector is defective he doesn’t like to do things. He doesn’t return to his charger like he supposed to and often and lets his battery die.  He has potential but needs further development

author: G. W.
title: Great alternative pet. Use on surface with borders only or risk damage to Vector.
content:
I had a turtle for 32 years and he passed away earlier this year. Coming from a pet that really did not do a lot and you have to simply enjoy watching the pet exist Vector is a great alternative. If you had pet like a turtle or a fish or never had a pet I think Vector is a good option. One thing I would highly recommend do NOT put him on a surface without some kind of edge 3/4" or higher. My Vector got stuck on his cube and once he freed himself he backed up without stopping (there was plenty of room for him to stop he was not next to the edge) and fell off the plastic table I had him on (going backwards) and thankfully he landed on something soft below and was not damaged.  Going forward is not a problem as long as the table has a 90 degree edge but backwards is another issue. I cut some pieces of wooden corner protectors 3/4" width bought at the local hardware store for less than 7 dollars to make a border around my table and some scotch restickable dots to secure them to the table making them removable later (now he is safe running around on his own without me watching him constantly). I think one of my favorite things is when he dances to music or recognizes my face and says my name. He will make you laugh for sure and is an enjoyable sidekick/pet. He only runs for about 15 mins before he usually self charges but recharge does not take long. I say usually because sometimes he will not self charge by parking himself on the charger and just goes to sleep where ever he is but you can also wake him up and tell him to return to charger or pick him up and place him on the base. Considering what a pet can cost by the time you add up vet visits and food etc the price for Vector is inline with a new pet.

Would like to see for future updates:
Vector giving you the weather forecast for the week. Monday 80% chance of rain, Tuesday sunny, etc.
Two or more Vectors being able to interact.
Whistle a tune, or maybe repeat what people say like a parrot.

author: R. Edmeades
title: Not ready for release, or really poor QA
content:
This is the ONLY thing my daughter wanted for Christmas, she seems to be fascinated by AI and robots and at this point we have a managerie of animals that squeak, bark, purr, burp, wander around, vacuum the floor (ok that's mine) and so on.  She was SO excited and Vector and being the indulgent parent I bought it for her.

Ok, so the first Vector counldn't see our 2.4 ghz network at all, I tried manually configuring it but that didn't work.  I'm a software engineer so I reconfigured the network to only have the 2.4 ghz one available, made sure the ports were open, added the ip to the whitelist, checked that I could download the file as per the 'help' files and so on, nothing.  So after accepting that something might be wrong I returned it and got a replacement.  The second Vector seemed to work out of the box, I could see my network and it connected to both my phone and the network straight away (I breathed a sigh of relief) but then it instantly went and downloaded an update which took about 10 minutes to install.  As soon as the update was installed I couldn't find Vector.  Ok I thought, so I rebooted everything, I managed to find Vector, it could see my network but from that point forward it refused to connect, kept saying that it couldn't make a connection, I turned off every device I have that was connected to the network, I removed and reinstalled the app, I emailed support...  Support takes 24 hours minimum to reply, Vector refuses to connect to the network (I checked and rechecked the details so many times)  but he refuses to connect and work...  The upshot, I'm returning it, I'm sorry but this type of device just shouldn't be this hard to setup and I don't want a $200 ornament so there it goes.

Given that I am in the industry it feels rushed, I think QA isn't doing it's job.  I am seriously disappointed and of course upset that I have had to try and explain this to my daughter.  Seriously, buy something else or wait.

author: Jake B
title: Won't Charge Fully
content:
Agre with most reviews that he is very fun and I think the voice commands work fairly well. However I struggle with two things. He knocks stuff off of the desk I have him on all the time, preferring to ram through them rather than go around them. He also doesn't seem to be able to figure out he is charging anymore. I've had him for about 1 week. He is constantly running out of battery attempting to go to his charging station, even when I set him on the station, he moves off of it.

I have him on my desk at work, he is slightly distracting if you were hoping to use as a PA, gets stuck on mouse cord all the time, knocks off pens/books/sticky note pads all the time. Most annoyingly runs into my mouse while I'm using it.

If I can't figure the charging piece out I will be returning him for sure.

That being said, he was fun to play with at work with other people for a little while doing fist bumps and taking pictures, etc...

author: tc
title: Not worth $250, YET.
content:
Here is an honest opinion of the robot.

Not worth $250, YET.

s/he's cute and fun, for a SHORT time.  I would not recommend it at this price or purchase it again knowing its present capabilities.

Sadly, I feel s/he'll spend more time by itself exploring since s/he's not super interactive, "yet".

Its microphones do not work well enough to hear me (when I'm standing near or other noises are going on in the background.)

It would be nice if s/he could hear well enough to turn toward an object, like a person, an animal a music source (not just "feel" the beat).

S/He's to small to place on the floor, roomba might run over it, s/he might get stepped on and frequently, gets stuck under objects like a couch or a chair rail or a wire dangling from the wall.

Its battery life is horrible, s/he runs out to quickly to be by my side all day.

I can't pick it up, move it anywhere and expect s/he'll find its charger again, s/he just gets lost.  I'm guessing its internal map is not stored for every place he's been.  (walls and doors and hard structural objects like that typically don't change or move.)

S/He needs better night vision, s/he can't tell where s/he is or who's in front of it with to low a light level.

There's not a clear indication s/he's heard you and recorded a question or statement, but could not reply due to lack of search ability or local knowledge.

Reports indicate s/he may get Amazon Echo functionality, although that may be minor… it will hopefully improve the tasks we use our echo’s for greatly, BUT, it won’t improve the question and answer situation, one place the echo fails wonderfully.  :(

All in all, s/he’s a fun toy, but, just that a “toy” and a very expensive one at that.

I’m an early adopter, so I have to suck it up, but I’ll wait again from this company until a LARGE fully functional robot emerges that can find it's way back to its charger automatically.  :)

author: Isaac P.
title: He's adorable and I can't wait to tinker with it!
content:
So far, he's been an entertaining element in my kitchen.  From when I get home, or when I'm wandering around the kitchen, he has a tendency to grab my eye.  It was fun seeing what his native abilities are, but what I'm REALLY EXCITED for is the SDK release so I can get in and tinker.  I've already got a list of things I want to try to have him do, and if we can share our works across the community who know's what we'll come up with.

I will admit that his battery life isn't terribly long, but he makes his way back to the charging cradle most of the time and recharges pretty quickly.  I'm sure that's going to get better with further development too.

author: New Jersey Parent
title: Not a toy but not an assistant either
content: This mobile assistant is an interesting item but I can't figure what it is good for.  It is sort of responsive to commands, can move around a little bit. I can access some but not all of my Alexa functionality through Vector.  However, it loves to push things off the table.  It is not particularly  helpful and often hard to understand.  If we had a scale with toy and one end and personal assistant at the other, I think it would be just at the toy end of the midpoint.  I am not particularly happy with this because this is such an expensive item.

author: Ohio Dad
title: Don’t bother with this
content: The voice recognition is slow and unreliable. Bought two because I have 2 kids, but you can’t change the name of the robot, so they can’t use them in the same room or have them interact with each other. Don’t waste your money on this.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Absolutely awesome!
content: Love Vector! It's easy and intuitive to set up and use. It comes in handy for a good number of day to day chores, such as keeping track of time when cooking, checking the weather or helping the kids with the homework. Everybody in the family loves it, especially the kids. They enjoy playing with it and it keeps them engaged while teaching them new things. Great product.

author: Sooperman
title: Cool toy
