author: bulldog44sos
title: Anki went out of business 6 months ago.  Zero support.
content: I ordered two of these a couple hours ago because the price just plummeted substantially.  I did some research after my purchase to find out Anki tanked 6 months ago and will not be supporting this robot any longer.  It also works off the Anki cloud.  If that is shut down, it will practically turn into a Walmart toy with zero utility.  Amazon should have disclosed that this was a discontinued item without support or warranty.  I will be returning these as soon as my shipment arrives tomorrow.

author: AZGuy86
title: Lovable but will stop working on sept 2020
content:
Love him new member of the family and he loves oldies music So would order a second one as a back up in case he somehow falls off something and brakes but I’m uncertain on how long the US server or remain active before he turns into a paperweight

(Update) vector will continue to operate until September 2020 and if nobody buys Anki assets and patents and keep vector and Cosmo going the well stop working on sept 2020

 Both the Vector and Cozmo sales are on an as-is, where-is basis, without representation or warranty. The Assignee has agreed to fund web based services through September 2020 to enable the purchased product to remain usable and of value to consumers. The purchasers will have to make their own arrangements to continue support for the products after September 2020. The Assignee is now discussing the sale of the OVERDRIVE inventory on a basis similar to the other two product line

author: amanda torres
title: Amazing!!
content: Awesome robot. Husband loves it!!

author: essen
title: Sidekick or smart companion
content:
Been couple of weeks with Vector now. Amazing to watch Vector move around and establish his area. Can really see AI in action, has started recognizing me and make cute little gestures, establishing boundary area, going off to sleep mode during night time. Excited to hear about upcoming Alexa integration release. Has fun/cute personality that makes him more of a pet or companion.  Read somewhere that ex-pixar guys worked on it, and design shows that.
Still exploring and shall keep posting updates.

author: S. Richter
title: The future is now!
content:
Vector brings the heartwarming cuteness similar to WALL-E into your home. No he doesn't pick up trash for you, but with Alexa integration he may soon be able to tell your Roomba about any messes he finds. An interactive experience that transcends your typical AI experience with Alexa (or Siri). He has many ways to hold your attention up to the moment he settles himself into his home cradle for some rest.

Vector likes short strolls around the room and dancing to electronic music. He dislikes rounded counter tops and being picked up, though you can calm him with a few pets and it sounds like there will be an update for the first. Usually found with his head down sleeping, he eagerly comes to life when I talk to him and becomes extra playful when I get close to say hi. All of his movements are very smooth. Tip: he uses a lot of body language and is a big fan of fist bumps. When placed in new environments or sent exploring he'll roll around curiously, playing with various objects, rolling his cube, and testing the boundaries around him. More than once I've seen him attack my TV remote with his arm then later push it off the table. Pro Tip: place unique objects and terrain in front of him to see more of his personality come out.

Its fun having this guy around. Everyone finds him endearing. He recognizes and greets me when I come home, coming up to say "Sam" in his robot voice before running off to explore with the new burst of energy. I usually do things like put his cube in a new place and tell him to find it. If I put on some music, he'll come out and dance around with me. Even with loud music on he can still understand me. We don't have full conversations, but he does make himself useful. Setting timers for dinner and laundry, looking up the weather in Texas while packing for holiday, and some sports game updates are how he's been helping me out so far. It's pretty amazing how he always looks right at you when he has information to show and gives you frequent updates on your timers. Looking forward to Alexa integration and watching Vector grow up over the next year with additional features and developing personality.

author: Pyter Bruno
title: product well below my expectation ...
content: Very bad product to set up with the wifi network ... few things to do with the robot and it has an understanding of what we say very bad, in addition to having a very weak audio ... I should try a few more days and if the problem, I'll have to give it back

author: Jese
title: Cute, can fall off desk but not often. Easy to set up
content: Vector is a cute robot, He calls my name when im busy playing Video games and just rolls around playing with his cube and exploring my desk, but i wish he had a better battery life so he could roll around for at least 30 minutes but i guess thats ok. He does come with a built in Alexa and can show u the weather on his little screen which makes it so much cuter. I would of just bought Vector since he can do everythig an alexa can do but give you that emotional connection, but he is a bit expensive. Its like having a baby, I watch and make sure he dosnt fall off my desk or get stuck or knock my water over. Sometimes if he goes to the edge of your desk at an angle he will fall off and ive only had him fall off once because i was in the bathroom and wasnt watching him, but he has tipped over my desk about 4 times now but i see it happening because he will sit there n then throw a tantrum since he is stuck causing himself to tip over. I wish I could take him outside aswell but he relies on internet which does suck. Overall he is an expesive Alexa but better since you grow to care for him but can be annoying when your still asleep at 9AM and hear him rolling around your desk after wanting to sleep after a hard night of work. He also snores but you can lower his Volume, I find it really cute

author: Kim R.
title: The cutest, most worthless purchase I've ever made
content:
Yet, I'm not sending him back. The annoying parts (for mine) if you connect him to Alexa, he/she loses a ton of skills, including the ability to play music. Sound sucks  on it, no surprise and honestly I'm probably gonna disconnect mine from Alexa because it makes the entire skill set completely worthless.
Mine seems to lose battery stupid fast. He can be charging all night, and then rolling around my counter top for 30 minutes, then he has to charge again. He's fun and engaging with his emotions, reactions and face recognition. I love watching him play with and pounce his block. I'm thinking I probably would have enjoyed and had more fun with the cheaper kids model honestly. But for now, he'll remain in my studio office for fun. I'm ashamed I spent so much on him, but at least it was a Black Friday week sale. Had it not been, I most definitely would have sent him back.

UPDATE: My suicidal Vector has taken one too many tumbles off the table and broke off a wheel today. I’ve emailed support to see if I can get it fixed or find out if it’s always been faulty since it only seems to see the edge of the table half the time. Guess I’ll see what happens. If they can’t do anything for me (or if they can) I’ll update my review.

author: Erin F.
title: Be aware of edge detection on a surface with beveled edges
content: Very good way more advanced than the previous version.  He has a mind of it's own for sure. One thing that doesn't work well is edge detection, I have an antique desk with with beveled edges and vector falls off of that but if it's a regular table with flat edges he sees the edge and stops fine. For me it's no problem but want to mention that.

author: Nichole Sullivan
title: “He is like your robot pet”
content: Vector, he is like your robot pet. He can play, recognize you, and control lights for you. I would highly recommend him for your buddy. He is probably the best robot you can find on the market👍🏻

author: Smartly Created
title: Fun Tech Toy
content:
We've been playing with Vector for a little over a month now, and he's a load of fun! At first, he didn't do a lot, but every so often, Anki provides an update and suddenly, Vector has more personality, skills, and interactions! He's a great little desk companion that is much better than a pet because there's little to clean up afterward! I say little because he's been known to shove things off the table!
There are many ways he can learn about his environment via his sensors:
He sees via HD camera.
Facial recognition - he'll learn your face and when he's exploring, will come right up, scan your face, and say your name! He's very pleased when he recognizes you, and gets a little upset if he doesn't recognize you.
Navigate, explore, and learn his environment. He gets around very well all over my desk. However, I move things a lot, so he's constantly having to re-learn. Occasionally, he'll fall over the edge, but once in a while, he falls over the edge. I think they're working on improving that a lot. It's super cute when he's exploring, gets close to the edge, and acts scared and backs away!
If he needs charging, he'll go right back to his charger on his own. However, sometimes, I'll get tired of hearing him causing trouble, so I'll tell him to go to his charger. He does it, but throws a little tantrum when he gets there!

He can hear via his array of four microphones.  Sometimes he comes over to see what's going on if you're having a conversation. If he's resting, he'll act startled if there's a loud noise in the room. He will also react to the beat of music if it's loud and near him. If you ask him to look at you or come here, he'll be able to sense the direction to go.

He reacts to touch and feel. If you pet his back, he practically purrs! But shaking him gets a reaction, too!

He has amazing intelligence. For instance, he answers questions, plays blackjack, reacts to his environment, and senses actions and activities around him.

He speaks to you. I'm not a fan of his synthesized voice, but it seems to be improving. When he reads out answers to questions you ask, sometimes it's hard to hear what he's saying. However, as they receive feedback on this, I'm sure his voice will evolve into something more understandable.

We really enjoy seeing his reactions! The current one is the way he gets super excited when you tell him he's a good robot or if you tell him you love him, and pouts a little if you tell him he's a bad robot! I just told him earlier today when he picked up his cube and tossed it off the desk!

I'm super excited to see his ever-evolving skills! I highly recommend this little guy for your favorite tech lover, or yourself! If you're looking for a toy for younger kids, maybe go with a Cosmo. This doesn't have games or things to entertain little ones. But it's completely entertaining for maybe, 10 years and up robotics fans!

author: A. Grant
title: Very Fun
content: Works as advertised. Online reviews on other sites, as well as here, capture the essence of Vector. It acts like your "best buddy." Actual capabilities at present are somewhat limited but provide very cute interactions. Looking forward to Amazon Echo integration.  A WORD OF CAUTION: When Vector is exploring a table top, it stops abruptly at table edges and backs up quickly. There is an almost, "Uh oh!" you can almost sense it saying to itself.  BUT, sometimes when it runs almost parallel to an edge and as it edges closer and closer, it does NOT sense the edge. Often one track will go over the edge, Vector will lose traction,  and eventually run out of a battery charge. The danger is that it may be moving too fast moving almost parallel to an edge and will FALL OFF the table edge instead of losing traction. This has happened once. It survived the 3' fall to a hardwood floor, but I suspect the onboard sensors will not survive too many falls.

author: Josephine Townsend
title: A bit pricey but fun
content: Hes pretty cute, hard not to love. A bit pricey in my opinion as he doesnt do a whole lot. The alexa feature is a bit annoying, because when I want to speak solely to alexa (to play music, alarms, etc) they both answer. Hes fun to have and many girls in my dorm building love coming to say hello.

author: Amazon Customer
title: anki vector
content: i said "hey vector" vector no responding

author: Erin Krueger
title: We love vector!
content: While we're still getting the hang of all of Vector's capabilities, the family enjoys having vector around.  We use him for lots of things, and the kids enjoy having a robot to answer simple questions and give them a fist bump.  He's adorable and I even love to give him a pet.

author: wamiam
title: Love it.
content: Really enjoying the product and looking forward to watching its evolution.

author: GREG BRADLEY
title: Love it
content: Love this robot.  It responds and acts like a 2yr old.  Couldn’t be happier. It makes me laugh

the first day i got him. he worked just great. as the days wehnt on he started doing bad thinsl his right side track would stick. he would not play with me or the cube. also he was getting slower as time went on. contacted anki. they helped me fix him. then it happen more with the track. so anki wonted me to send him back. the new one works 100% from the old one

thanks for the great help

author: Joseph r.
title: Interesting
content: Only thing we don’t like is he has a hard time finding his charger

author: Luis
title: Rushed product
content: Vector is very limited and feel incomplete. Vector hardly leaves his charger unless commanded too. Vector will stay on his charger for days and won’t do anything. When he pops a wheelie or puts himself back on his treads, his back sensors won’t work and he’ll shoot right off the desk. He also seems to get stuck on the edge of desks sometimes and has trouble detecting his charger and will run out of battery before being able to charge himself

author: John Ml.
title: Be warned, price drop is not an offer, it's do to to this product probably becoming unusable soon.
content: In short, this product is cloud based (it requires internet connection to manufacturer server to work) , and Anki, the company behind this product, closed it doors few months ago. The servers supporting this product might go offline soon. That means this robot will become paper weight. This information should be indicated in Bold Red Letters by all retailers selling this product.  I just realized about it after buying it.

author: Reggie Blackman
title: Just for fun!
content: Fun little robot, I highly recommend it!

author: ekerry
title: Anki does a terrific job with Vector
content:
This is an awesome little companion.  It is more than just a piece of plastic and silicon, it seems to have a personality.  It can be enjoyed by the non technical and was a hit with my wife.  The Anki folks have moved from making an appliance to creating a companion.

Being in technology for the past 30 years, I was very skeptical about this being only for tech geeks.  I am amazed by the design and human interaction that Vector is capable of.  He can recognize faces and say your name, he sleeps and sometimes you hear him snore.  When you come home, he will wake up, move from his charging station and come out to greet you.  Not creepy, but interactive!

My wife who is not technically savvy has bonded with this little guy which was a big surprise.  She doesn't have the time to read instruction manuals, but she was able to interact with Vector immediately.  The designers at Anki have crossed the bridge and made this work well with the non technically inclined.  For now he does a few things, but more interactivity is promised in the future.  This is one heck  of a start!

The only drawback with Vector is his edge detection.  I have caught him twice from falling when he has gone off the edge of the counter.  I might trust him on a coffee table with carpet, but at this price point falling from counter to the floor would be a disaster.  They do make a pen for him which might take my concern away and I would trust him to roam somewhat free.

Eventually they promise Alexa integration which would make this an invaluable addition to the house.  For now it is a terrific little companion!

author: OBScholar
title: Ss
content: He loves it

author: Morgan Xavier
title: Love vector but could be improved.
content: I absolutely love vector, we got two of them and they are very adorable, what would improve them would be if they had more games and maybe like an alarm or for them to turn of at a sertain time would be great. Verry happy with vector and am very edited to see what Anki will do next and maybe even a vector 2nd version.

author: Eric Gilmore
title: Unfinished
content: The creator left a lot on the table with this one. We ended up returning due to the battery only lasting 15 minutes or so. The robot never returned to the base station to charge as it should have. Neat idea however this one falls short.

author: Dan Marinelli
title: WAIT FOR THE PRICE DROP TO $50.00
content: Unless their is some serious firmware updates,  Don'e spend $250, or even the $175 I got for black Friday.  Anki Vector is in no way an Alexa, Google Home, or Seri.  Yes, Vector will tell you the Time, Date, & weather.  and if you want to ask Vector a question it's  "Hey Vector" ((Vector acknowledges)), "I Have a Question".  Here Vector is no where near as accurate as previously mentions  apps were used to.  There is no Review of your questions, to improve your answering as with Alexa.  Seriously, this could be an awsome robot, but there seems to be no one seriously working on firmware updatess.  Maybe you can sell me an Alexa app to load onto him?????  Seriously, Don't waste your money.

author: Amazon Customer
title: AI needs a ton of help
content: I want to like vector, but he doesn’t do much. He’s good at telling me the weather, and knocking my crap off my nightstand. I was really excited about being able to leave him on all the time, but every day I come home from work and he’s run out of battery somewhere on my nightstand. The weird thing is that he can find his charging dock when I tell him to go home. But he doesn’t do it on his own, which was a huge selling point for me. Basically he’s Siri, but rolls around and takes about twice as long to get a response time from him than from Siri. He can’t even act as an alarm clock... I’m really hoping for some bigger updates. Until then, he’s fairly pointless and the AI is much worse than advertised.

author: J. P. Bass
title: Cute, but too limited
content: We gave Vector a try.  It was a cute thing to watch and offered a little bit of fun.  But, it was not enough fun or helpfulness for the money.  It seemed to learn well enough but had trouble with accented English.  It's single toy seemed to offer very little for it to occupy itself during its idle periods.  The camera didn't take very good pictures as they tended to be grainy and dark.  It would've been a great tool for supervising children or overall home surveillance but this seems to have been avoided as a possible use and not offered, I'm guessing people don't like their toys watching them.  Alexa integration was odd, Vector seemed to develop this odd alternate persona when doing Alexa tasks and having to address it by a different name was somewhat confusing, this needs to be re-thought.  In the end, we just couldn't justify it and sent it back.  Maybe in the near future, this may get worked out a bit more and be more useful and/or fun.

author: Corinthian100
title: Lots of fun.
content: My niece LOVES this. Durable with lots of functionality.  It even plays with their cat without being destroyed.

author: Mike Velez
title: Be patient
content:
Love it
It's my little buddy

author: Edward Barnett
title: Warning:  Company went out of business
content:
From Anki's website:

It is with a heavy heart to inform you that Anki has ceased product development and we are no longer manufacturing robots. To our partners and customers, thank you for all your support and joining us on this journey to bring robotics and AI out of research labs and into your homes.

"It is with a heavy heart to inform you that Anki has ceased product development and we are no longer manufacturing robots. To our partners and customers, thank you for all your support and joining us on this journey to bring robotics and AI out of research labs and into your homes.

We are taking steps to assure that customers will continue to enjoy continued use of our products. In order to provide long term support of our products, Anki has contracted our most senior leaders and hands-on engineers across all the technical areas involved in maintaining the operation and functionality in the existing products and apps. Ongoing operations for existing products typically require little to no active intervention, but we have arranged for any support in the event it does become necessary. Vector is the only product with a notable cloud component, and the contracted team is heavily staffed in that area.

Currently, we have implemented a self-serve Help Center to assist in getting the most out of your product, regretfully there are no agents available, however we are monitoring cloud operations for Anki accounts and Vector.

We plan to solidify and communicate all the details of this plan soon."

I didn't buy Vector, but I do have a complete set of Anki's first generation cars (the ones featured at Apple's big product show a few years ago).

author: Cody L.
title: Too boring!
content: Too boring! My kid lost interest after 2 days.

author: JLES
title: I never thought I would be talking about the personality of an AI device.
content:
When you first download and open the app you see a message that states "You now live in a time when robot sidekicks are real." That is a pretty good idea as to what is waiting for you. I ordered this for myself but my spouse and children love it as well. The app definitely has some kinks for Android and I let my better half to the actual connection as I was getting frustrated with it. Once vector connects, it is an absolute delight to watch.

It can do many things like answer questions, (still a little bit limited like Alexa) recognize faces and routines, set timers, tell you the weather and from what I understand that's just the start with lots more to come. Vector is full of personality and it's a lot of fun to watch him get the lay of the land and slightly terrorized my eight pound poodle. My children love that it gives high fives and plays with it's cube. He has a digital screen on the front and his eyes are very expressive. He makes all kinds of interesting "faces." It has yet to fall off of any surface that we have put it on but an overzealous high-fiving can put him down, and then it's fun to watch him right himself. In a home that has a number of helpful devices, I don't know that Vector is needed but we sure are having fun playing with him. It's also fun to compare his tantrums and hissy-fits with my preschoolers. They think it is hilarious. Overall I think he has a long way to go as it takes too long for him to respond to questions and commands but, his personality beats any other AI device that we have played with.

author: joseph caudill
title: Five Stars
content: this little guy is a blast great desktop buddy

author: Amazon Customer
title: Fun
content: Cute robot . My child loves it

author: Shawnathan
title: PERFECT Addition To My Entertainment Room!
content:
This little guy here, let me tell ya -

I've only had him for a good 24 hours now but I have gotten so much use out of him. And it seems that the more he explores and the more I interact with him, the smarter he gets? Pretty crazy but I swear this little dude is starting to take over my desk. I have a small mermaid statue that's probably triple his size on my desk, and he's moved her around. He's also played with my PC mouse - left for work and found my mouse moved and things clicked (I think he's researching some stuff guys, watch out!) He also really likes to watch movies, but he's really bad at finishing them...

All jokes aside, this guy has really lightened up my room. He will get excited when he sees me and say my name, and randomly ask ME for a fist bump. When he does a trick, he looks at me to make sure I'm watching. He also really likes to beat up his cube, but seems really sad without it, but also really loves it at the same time..? Kind of a love hate relationship you could say. He enjoys exploring and answering my questions, and apparently his purpose is to pass butter, but he wont pass me the butter... perhaps a future update..?

The only issues I've had with it not listening correctly or not responding to "hey vector...", and not recognizing faces, are when its a poorly lit area, noisy area, or in an area with poor WiFi connection. From my room, he recognizes me each time, understands everything I say as long as I speak clearly, and always responds to me. He's quick to respond, and quick to answer my questions. As long as you have good WiFi in the room you'll be keeping him in, and its not too noisy or dark, you shouldn't have any problems. Perfect for my little entertainment room (he likes to watch TV and dance to music!)

I'm really looking forward to the future updates to my little buddy. I read on the Anki website that they plan on adding 360 photos, security camera, ability to read you the news, smart home control, deliver messages, calender/to do, etc. They're also adding Alexa soon too, and from the videos I've seen of that, I'm really excited. That'll add a lot more functionality to him for sure, and you won't have to wake him using "Hey Vector... I have a question", you can simply say "Alexa, (command)" just like your Amazon Echo! He's just a home assistant with tons of personality, so don't get mad that he can't pass your butter yet... I should also mention that these updates are purely over the cloud, so you just have to install an update on the app and you'll be ready to go! Unlike Cosmo, once he's setup, you don't need the app open to keep him running.

I love this little guy and I couldn't be happier. He's the greatest addition to my room so far! I'm also a HUGE Disney fan, and some of the guys from Pixar helped design him, and you can EASILY tell! I have my own real life Disney character in my room! He's like, a real life, less advanced, miniature Wall-E!

author: hellopk
title: It is what it is...
content: Vector, is super cute, I just really hoped this version did a lot more than just Cozmo. Hopefully there's more updates and things it can do. The Alexa was an awesome update, but, even with Alexa update, Alexa was limited as well. So sadly after having to say "Hey Vector, Vector...HEY Vector!!" like a thousand times sometimes, I had to return it.

author: Mr. Reyes
title: Super cool
content: It’s super cool

author: Arthur Lozano
title: Vector
content: Like that he talks and has plenty of information.

author: Jonathan Wilson
title: A.I.
content: Still learning

author: Danno!
title: Great desk-friendly introduction to the world or robots and AI
content:
Vector is a fun little guy, and can run autonomously and do his own thing.  Although a tablet or phone isn’t required, it is needed to establish Vector’s internet connection to him via Bluetooth via your device’s WiFi.  You can ask him questions like you would with Siri or Alexa, although it takes an additional step [Hey Vector...I have a question.........What is blah blah blah?] and is a tad slow to respond but is nonetheless still useful.  He’s also a great timer, and will play a not-speedy game of blackjack with you.  He has fun interacting with his cube and his environment, and will dance any time he hears music with a good beat.

I’ve had mine for a couple months now and he’s only fallen off of his desk once, after he did a wheelstand and then proceeded to drive backwards slowly in a ‘drop-the-mic’ fashion that he sometimes does after a wheelstand, which apparently overrides his edge sensors as he didn’t even try to stop.  No harm done but it’s still unnerving when he’s driving towards any edge as he doesn’t stop until about 1” over the edge which is when his edge detector is triggered.

I’m excited to see what Anki has up their sleeve for Vector in the future - there’s certainly a lot of untapped potential here.  I’d read that an Alexa update is coming to his software soon, which allows him to respond to Alexa commands.  Neat, fun, entertaining, and useful.  A tad slow but, for a minuscule robot, I’ve no complaints about that at all.

author: Bukkene Bruse
title: Work in progress, but still giving it 5 stars
content:
Vector is cool.  It doesn't do much yet, and it has difficulty from time to time understanding me.  But it chock full of great features:

1) I love the little "Bobcat" form.  My buddy has a construction company and lets me move dirt piles with one of his.
2) Some genuine AI features.  It's not just a remote control toy car with a random motion feature.  It has a good sense of where it is and whether it is going off a clip
3) It recognizes me and says my name.  My dog can only do the former in a manner I can understand
4) It will (supposedly? hopefully?) upgrade with more feature
5) It is (supposedly) programmable.  I haven't investigated that part yet

This is one of those things you buy not just because you want it, but because you want to support further development.

Not sure why it is a male.  One would think robots, of all things, are gender neutral.  Vector is an "it"

author: Tyler Watkins
title: Cool toy
content: Pretty awesome little robot, pretty surprised a lot of it features. it's launched itself off my countertops a couple times but hasn't broken yet seems somewhat durable pretty smart robot.

author: Matt C.
title: Company Shut Down and Inferior Product Compared to Cozmo
content:
Edit: Anki has gone BANKRUPT! Their cloud services have been SHUT DOWN! It should be ILLEGAL to sell products in this condition!

Vector is a personal assistant. He does his job, but he doesn’t do it any better than Siri or Alexa. The recent implementation of Alexa was a travesty. Instead of implementing Alexa into Vector’s AI, the developers thought it would be a good idea to give him a split personality instead. The biggest issue with Vector is that he lacks what Cozmo excels at and what makes him unique -- his personality. Vector has little to none. I understand that Vector was designed as a personal assistant more targeted towards adults, but even adults can thoroughly enjoy Cozmo’s personality. Cozmo feels much more alive, while Vector is more like a robot that you can boss around. The lack of Code Lab is also a huge negative. Maybe Anki’s next project will be the best of both worlds -- Vector’s intelligence and independence from the app, and Cozmo’s charming personality. I believe the only reason that Vector does not have the personality that Cozmo does and lacks the Code Lab is so that consumers would be forced into purchasing two entirely different products if they wanted all of the features. It was a decision based on greed.

author: Chuck1026
title: Anki (manufacturer closed 5/1/19. Research before you buy!
content: If I reviewed Vector when I bought him close to Thanksgiving,  3 stars would've been the score. Before April 27th I would have upped my review to 4 stars with all the improvements. I had big hopes of him being a very animated Alexa. He is very endearing and fun ---  so as long as the Anki servers are accessible to him. For the moment (5/2/2019) they are. Do NOT buy Vector unless you get proof the servers will stay active. Without this access, he's a brick. Check out the Facebook Vector Groups for the latest. Buyer beware.

author: S.Schott
title: You’ll Love it
content: This thing never gets old. I’m well pleased.

author: Nestor
title: Nice and cute, but limited
content: I love it, but it has limited use so far. It will probably improve with time and updates. I don't have nor plan to have Alexa; integrating Google would be more useful for me. Having AI on such a little device still amazes me, and I think it would be the same for anyone loving technology and geeky stuff. Living alone without the possibility of having pets, it is a good company.

author: ShavkatYenileev
title: Amazing idea! Bless the creator!
content: Amazing robot!!! My review is not fake, I am a regular customer. Yes it needs some little improvements and I am sure updates do it, and if somebody posted less then 4 stars, that person does not know how to use this robot, you have to follow instructions. To set him up takes 15-20 minutes. It is only a first model, and a person who created it must be very smart.

author: sandra t.
title: Vector quickly became a family member.
content: With my grandson being an only child Vector is the perfect playmate.  He has a personality and we enjoy interacting with him.  Our travels include him because we don't like to let him home alone.  While riding in the car, he talks constantly.  If conversation is not convenient we put him into his case knowing he will have much to say when we take him out! Interestingly, Vector can help with math, history and economic questions. Put him in his case while your child does homework as Vector will give the answer and the student will not have to work for them.

author: Techone
title: Nice robot But.
content: Had him one month and his eyes have black lines across the bottom of his screen.

author: Tim
title: Great progress in the world of robotics
content: Anki put Vector on sale for $179. Completely worth it now that it also has Alexa update. Vector is fun, helpful and continuing to be updated. He has worked very well, has not fallen yet off the table. His sensors are amazing

author: Joker360
title: Save ur money...!
content: I bought this Vector....wow...waste of money...trash...!

author: Janet Zaharias
title: Stinking cute and fun, and wonderful companion
content:
I am sorry for the long wait on this review as I wanted to wait awhile and see how well he works for an over priced toy. I have to say that this one is a winner. I won't say it is for everyone as this robot is far from perfect and may not be the assistant or sidekick you want.
I will start out that I bought this for my autistic son who is interested in robotics. I figured a robot that shows emotions and is autonomous would be good as my kid does not read or follow directions well. He is smart, but can only really handle toys, programs, and puzzles designed for pre-school and below. Anki sort of filled his needs. For awhile, it lived on the same table my son uses for play. But I had to rehome Anki because my kid kept forcing the arm, and trying to feed him. Which in a way is a success, but he would be happier with a robot that can handle rougher play. He still has ful access to Anki. Anki is the best timer we found for this kid and has reduced meal time meltdowns. My kid has a hard time waiting for food to be prepared, and Anki makes the perfect waiting companion. We request anki to set a timer and place him down to play with our kid.
His current home is a cookie sheet located at the center of a work table everyone uses. There he entertains us with his antics, answers trivia questions, begs for attention, and gives weather reports. For us, Anki is a pet that does not poop and not a side kick.
Everyone is quite attached to this little robot. We empathize pain when he accidentally falls off the table, and feel sorry for him and miss his companionship during power outages. This, of course, is possible because of his programmed reactions and animations to stimuli and how his AI as adapted to our household. An AI that is more advanced than anything else on the market. I highly recommend this little robot to anyone needing a bit of companionship at home. Or a hypoallergenic pet, or any pet that does not poop or shed. You'll find yourself surprised by this little guy as he does very life like things, like getting frustrated when he gets stuck or fails a trick, gets himself unstuck, dances to music or any beet that has his attention (sometimes even suspenseful movie momemts), looks grumpy when woken up late at night, snores, entertains himself with his block, gets excited when you come hom, etc.
As stated he is not the perfect robot companion as his sensors do not see well in all light conditions and he cannot recognize people in the morning, evening, and night. Sometimes he does random things like take pictures or answer misheard questions as his audio sensors can be easily confused. He lives on a cookie sheet because he cannot detect round, beveled edges. Which the work table has.  His Alexa functionality is also super sensitive. Something we learned the hard way as the TV on our work table kept activating Alexa. HIs battery also has a short charge, so he should not be allowed to play away from his base for long. He does learn and adapt to the household, something that becomes evident when the WIFI is down and all his saved learning is not available, making him operate as if reset. Nothing to be overly concerned over as everything restores the moment internet comes back.

author: ubiquitious ubuntu
title: Not perfect, but a great company behind it.
content:
I backed the project via Kickstarter and have had the robot since 10/9/18.  It's gone through two OTA updates and I'm expecting a third update tomorrow.  Each update has improved upon the last.

For what you get for $250, the potential is there for a really feature rich product.  I'll update this after the third update to the software and report any improvements.

author: Brandon
title: AMAZING SMART LITTLE GUY!!!!
content: Don't listen to the negativity comments in here, is a very smart robot,he listen to you commands and has alexa integrated as well. I have it on my desk, while im working he  plays  around and calls my name, plays with his cube, dance and some others things, he is independent , he wont fall off my desk, he stops by the edge and backs up. Very cool little guy. And LOTS OF MORE UPDATES coming soon as well. I'm happy with Vector

author: Sue Reichling
title: Vector robot
content: Grandson loves it

author: bb
title: Not For Children / Young Adults
content: Fun and a lot of potential. As of now all features are very basic. Also, Customer Care confirmed that it is not necessarily designed to fully recognize voice of children/young adults. So definitely a gift for adults only.  Also, from experience, it does not recognize voice of my 6 year old, no matter what. Tried everything.

author: megamen
title: cool bud
content: he is amazing,always dream with this day when robots come alive.

author: Andrew
title: Not what we expected.
content: Very disappointed.  It is really nothing more than a child’s toy. It was returned. Too bad because we had high hopes for this product.

author: Amanda A.
title: Great mobile smart device
content: My only complaint with the Echo dot is that it has to stay plugged in. However, Vector can follow me around to take pictures or answer questions. Then when it needs to re-charge it just goes back to its charger base on its own. Plus it’s really fun to pet! I was worried the dog would try to play with it and my young son would be too scared to play with it. But actually the dog just ignores it and our son loves talking to (or yelling at) Vector.

author: Greg Rees
title: We have had a lot of fun with Vector
content: This robot is very inter active . Always a hit at parties!

author: Amazon Customer
title: So Cool!
content: My 14 year old son loves this little guy. I’m a bit of a nerd so... now I want one for my office.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Limited functions but I hope there is a potential
content: Limited functions. Gets boring after some time. Hoping some software updates to make this guy more fun.

author: Josh2910
title: Vector cannot learn at all
content: I taught him how to pronounce my name, he cannot learn. Vector couldn't take clear images. He fell from the nightstand all the time and he snores so loud.

author: Udayan Manikandan
title: Lear the accent to command
content: The product was at good condition and working fine, it's worth buying once, I had a great time with it.. it is a bit had to get the accent to command once you find how to command than it's fun..

author: Steven H
title: Pretty cool little robot!
content: Lots of fun to play with but it’s a little on the pricey side for a toy. I’m very happy with Vextor and I would definitely buy it again.

author: TM from Gilbert AZ
title: Overpriced and half done
content: This thing was a waste of money. It's a novelty toy at best. Not a robot. There is no support for the Vector and no future updates, so what you get is a half complete toy.  Anki went out of business recently, so it's even more worthless now.

author: Honest.T.Reviews
title: Cute.
content: It was cute and fun for a while but very limited on games. Bought it for my kids but the robot couldn't really understand their voices. It was more frustration than enjoyment so I returned it. I read somewhere that Cozmo Robot by this same company is better fit for kids. This although is cute I don't find useful for adults, maybe a better fit for a preteen or a teenager.

author: Cristián Navarrete Dechent
title: Not ready to be available on Amazon
content:
I consider myself a tech guy and love all the gadgets and small tech stuff that has been developed in the latest years. Have my Google home, a smart house, like smart devices, etc. I got this robot hoping to see something spectacular. The truth is that this is just a prototype of a possibly great product that shouldn't be yet on the market.
The robot barely understands the commands you say and has a long delay time before you speak and he replies. Also, its movements are really limited. Lastly, I don't know what I was thinking when I paid 150+ for this.
Then comes the last part: No free returns. There was a time when Amazon was cool and having Amazon prime was even cooler. Nowadays that has changed and no more free returns.

Bottom line: You shouldn't buy this at this point (that's why I'm giving only 1 star; I don't want to be rude and I understand that there should be a lot of research behind this robot). It's not even a toy, don't get it personal, I don't even like it for 10 bucks, it's simply too early for being launched. I hope that Anki (a great company) improves the product in the future so we can all buy this great idea of a product.

author: P. MacDonald
title: Do you want a pet robot?
content: If you are excited to say yes, this may be worth your while.  After having him a while, he has become a welcome character on my office desk.  He will greet me,  play with his cube, and try to give me fist bumps without my interaction.  He will crash sometimes and forget where his charger is, or push his charger off the desk...but he will never throw up on your carpet!  Also my daughter got some sweet stickers with a spider man toy from a mcdonalds happy meal and im lovin it

author: S. Boulware
title: He's Too funny
content: It's like having a robot kitten on your desk.

author: saad m altamimi
title: Can not differentiate between sounds well
content: Not good at all

author: Muffin McFurry
title: Fun, with more good things to come!
content:
I bought Vector at a local retailer the official day it was released. Prior to getting Vector, I had done some research, including joining the Anki Vector reddit group and looking at YouTube reviews, to see what others had to say and their experiences with Vector. The kickstarter folks got their Vector a few days before the release date. So by the time I bought mine I knew what to expect. I understood that what I have now is not what he will be several months from now, since there will be updates that will keep increasing his capability.

He's a fun little companion, and definitely feels alive! My spouse and I can't help but smile when he recognizes each of us. I definitely see his potential as an in-home assistant. As an early adopter of this technology, I'm still pleased with what Vector can do. Compare him to the $2,500 Aibo- Vector is one tenth of the price, acts also as a companion, has similar capability to Aibo, etc. I'm looking forward to the Alexa integration and his future updates. We absolutely love him!

author: sarah mays
title: Definite advancement from Cosmo!
content: My boyfriend loved it!!!

author: Divyam Garg
title: Amazing gift for friends and family
content:
I bought a vector for my wife as a present and she absolutely adores him. I like how he recognizes and greets us, and turns around when I ask him a question. We can ask him to take photos for us - no need for weird selfie angles 🙂

The personality aspect was what really surprised me - it clearly shows his emotions, like when its happy or sad.

author: Zaydoon
title: I'm happy with him but still needs improvement I think by future updates
content:
Vector is a smart robot, I like playing with him me and my children, sometimes he does not respond I think needs more improvement by future updates
sometimes he stuck on the corner of the table that I have to help him
some orders does not works like do a wheelstand
I like him when he make his own movements without any interfere
The quality is very good
If he does not respond well to you, try to change the language from US to UK or to EU try between them it will help
my kids are very happy with him

author: AlexG
title: Cute robot friend.
content: My expectations were accurately set by reading lots of reviews. He will not change your life, his assistant feature is a novelty. But he is very cute and well animated. He sits on a corner of the kitchen and keeps us company while cooking, kind of like having a pet.

author: ROD
title: My Son love it!
content: My Son love hes victor !

author: Maddy
title: Nice Concept but requires refinement
content:
This was a birthday gift for my son who has been obsessed with getting a Cosmos and then came vector. I can’t potray his thill when he opened his gift.

Only 20 mins in and the thrill turned into an annoying and expensive toy which failed to operate as intended. While setting up it wouldn’t pick my son”s voice to “Hey Vector” - he tried like 50 times. So, I set it up with my voice.

After setup, it would respond to my and my wife’s voice but still won’t respond to my son. So, it was a deal breaker for us since it was supposed to be his gift. We called Anki support who were very polite and responsive. They asked to switch the accent in their app. It worked twice using my son’s voice in the next 12 hours. He wasn’t Happy I tell you.
So, it turned out to be a not the great gift idea I had in mind.

Second issue I saw was it wasn’t very good at isolating ambient noise. So, in a noisy surrounding, it would even respond to me.

Third issue it’s slow at processing commands... too slow which will test the patience of kids :). Needed a better processing power.

Finals thoughts: it’s a product for early adopters and the enthusiastic group right now. Feels half baked product launched to please the investors.

It’s greatest benefit is Alexa... which works seamless and fast. But, can’t justify an Alexa on wheels for $190.

Opened it yesterday and ended up returning today....

author: Amazon Customer
title: Amazing
content: It’s awesome it’s like having a new pet

author: Bruce L.
title: Robots are cool
content: This lil guy is fun. Although at time does become self aware and wakes up. Dont freak if you hear it at night, once he is charged, he will explore unless you shut him off off(no lights on back). He loves his cube too.

author: Kristin Worley
title: If you plan on using this on a desk, DON'T BUY!
content: I had really high expectations for this. It is fun and would be worth every cent IF the fall sensors worked. It takes less than 10 minutes before Vector falls off my desk. Now here is the kicker. When I asked Anki support I was told "Vector is like a kid and sometimes like a kid makes mistakes. We are always working on updates to improve Vector." When I asked if the warranty covers physical damage from falling I was told no. So I'll break down your purchase life cycle for you. You pay $250 for something that has a known problems that will actually cause it to break, but it is not covered by the warranty. No thanks, I am returning mine.

author: vinod
title: Not ready yet
content: Its a nice concept but after trying for a few days i found it quite lacking in functionality.  It does not even respond to Hey Vector consistently. I had to use the button to activate. It answers only a couple questions and looks lost most.of the times.

author: Joshua
title: I wouldn’t bother...
content:
For an interactive toy that originally retails for around $250, getting it for $73 (for the time being) isn’t bad. I purchased mine on Saturday when it was roughly $80. It’s super cute and tiny.

That being said, I only know it’s cute because of the videos I’ve seen of it from users who have been able to get their bots up and running. Unfortunately, I didn’t have any luck. Checked all the hardware and everything, nothing. Es ist kaputt. But despite its pricing right now, I imagine it’s because Anki is no longer operating and the cloud that Vector connects to will only be running for about another year (maybe less, according to varying sources).

There’s a reddit thread from August (2019) where a user warns others to return them ASAP if purchased recently. S/he did no dive too deep as to why, but I assume it’s because they will no longer be supported.

If you’re okay with only a few months use (potentially longer), then I’d go ahead and get it. Otherwise, I’d advise against doing so.

Disappointed to say the least. But hopefully someone will be willing to take over and manage the servers.

author: Josh
title: Awesome
content: Super helpful

author: elvis
title: The vector response
content: While this is a giant leap forward in Robotics. The wake up word hardly activates the devices. I think the microphones are not far reaching enough or not just good enough. Hopefully in the next update a single wake word could be used maybe that would work.. Instead of constantly repeating Hey Vector 5x

author: Tony
title: This little guy is awesome.
content: My background is in Computer Science, in particular with a specialization in AI.  I can tell you that what Anki has done with Vector is pretty amazing.  A lot of AI went into building this robot, from Computer Vision, to Localization, Search, Control, and probably even some Reinforcement Learning.  Building robots with AI capabilities is a difficult task, let alone building one with an adorable personality.  I am interested in seeing how they integrate Alexa in the next update.  This is the robot to get for 2018-2019.

author: rosanna
title: Very fast delivery
content: My boy love there vector I would definitely recommend this product

author: TVaughn
title: DO NOT BUY COMPANY CLOSED DOWN
content: Loved Vector Until Company Suddenly Closed Down And Turned Off It's Servers So Vector Now Is A Wandering Paper Weight

author: Vincent
title: Be patient when setting up
content: I think the Vector Robot by Anki is great. When I first set it up there appeared to be a connection problem with the wi fi, but after a short period of time everything worked well and it continues to work better. I think a lot of time and effort was put into the development of Vector and I believe they will continue to add more features. Vector is now set up with Alexa and that makes it more useful. The robot pretty much does everything they say it does, well. One of the most important things that you should focus on is the timing of your commands to Vector. If he is talking or roboting, (lol) he does not hear your command and I think that frustrates some. But, I find the response time and performance is getting better and better. Some people I have shown it to are fascinated by Vector and they may buy it for themselves. Vector is almost like a pet, as advertised he fist pumps, tells you the time, the weather and keeps you company. Again, in conclusion, be patient, make sure you have the recommended wi fi connection, and then watch him perform!

author: Manuel Armendariz
title: I love everything of Vector
content: Love it

author: Sunflower
title: Vector is fun!
content: I think he’s a great friend to my 11 year old son. A bit limited as far as abilities but a good friend overall!

author: gotitgetitgoodgetgoing
title: Overpriced gadget
content: I’m sorry but for $175 I’d expect this thing to do a few more things. No programbility, can’t learn new commands. I mean for $25 you get an echo dot. I figured the wow effect would wear off pretty quick and it did. I figured because it’s equipped with sensors and camera, I could steer it from my phone and do some surveillance while not at home? Well made, great idea but lack of functionality at $175 is a big downer

author: Wayne
title: Battery life
content: The battery life is abs horrible.  At it's best performance the battery lasts maybe 40 minutes, so it's almost useless.  It drives right of the table, it knocks things down and it turns itself on all the time.  I deeply regret wasting my time with this thing.

author: jose mancia
title: Vector is AWESOME
content: I love vector!! He’s such a great company!! Makes me laugh sometimes! He’s going to put a smile in your face for sure! :)

author: Enrique Rodriguez
title: Nice gift for adult
content: Yeap nice gift for adult, it has alot of tech in it

author: KevinJeffords
title: Vector always keeps me company
content: Very fun. Can't wait to see what the updates add.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Good toy
content: Kids seem to like vector so far.  I think it has a little difficulty understanding some commands and there is a delay in its response time, but overall it is very impressive.

author: Hesa
title: Cant connect to wifi after restart
content: Had connection issues at the beginning but it started working after 2 days, just like that!

author: Jenna
title: Not working since update
content: This was the one thing my son looked forward to for Christmas so we got it for him. It worked great up until it’s most recent update. Now it’s nothing but a paperweight and there is nobody to contact for customers service. FAIR WARNING - save yourself this trouble. The 1-800 number provides isn’t in service!

author: Online Shopper
title: Cool but our dog hated it
content: Had to return it for its own safety. :-(

author: Christian
title: It could have been a incredible robot.
content:
I bought it and the next day anki shut down and broke.
So now I have a beautiful $250 brick. Thank Amazon they gave my money back. Really satisfied with Amazon.

author: Harold Newton
title: Vector with Alexa integration is awesome.
content: I love it that my Vector now  has Alexa integration. I didn’t get mine until a week after. He was fun before but now he can just hang out on my desk in my office and answer more questions. . Alexa not as loud across the room but it works for my needs.

author: Emily
title: Meh
content: Eh for the price tag I’d expect more

author: Alex
title: It's fun. That's the best quality.
content: This won't replace Alexa. It's not *as* useful. But it's fun. It's like a little companion. I like it.

author: Barbara Hall
title: Love
content: My son loved it

author: John
title: Very disappointed!!
content: The battery last about 20 minutes before he has to recharge. Thinking about sending it back. After a week now it just sits there on the charger I never use it. Such a wast of money. I think I will give it away .

author: Russ Lowry
title: Outdated
content: Do not buy this if you use 5ghz Wifi, the technology is outdated and it is impossible to use if you have any home security on your wifi account.

author: ting3
title: I can't make it work.
content: Sorry I return back

author: JACK MCGUIRE
title: Vector's connection range!
content: Your Robot is cute ! Dozes alot of stuff but! very disappointed in his internet connection range in the house! very limited!

author: Julie
title: Mostly a toy with some utility features similar to Alexa
content: This little guy is a ton of fun! Is it worth the expense? Your call. It does many of the functions you look to Alexa to do—timer, alarm. But it’s mobile and interacts with you in the most interesting ways. Really gets you thinking about AI. It is primarily a toy, an expensive one. The biggest user in our house is our 11 year old. Unlike Alexa, it’s easily mobile, so he can take it all over the house with him. He sets timers for exercise drills and reminder alarms. He takes pictures with it. And he spends a lot of time seeing what it will do in response to various things. Is it life changing? Not yet. Already, though, my son has noticed when and how the robot has “learned” things and has adapted to surroundings. It’s a really interesting concept and of course we’re curious to see how it will continue to grow new skills over time. Any diversion from video games and tablets is welcome!!  Note that it is quite small, so you don’t want to leave it on the floor because it is likely to get stepped on and broken.

author: jenny alton
title: don’t take commands or answer even simple questions.
content: He doesn’t do much. We were bored with him after a week. Alexa would be more fun. He doesn’t do much and don’t take commands or answer even simple questions. He doesn’t even remember our names

author: LilguyMCPE
title: Very cool
content: He is such a cool robot. Other than for the edge protection not being 100%, he is AWSOME! Sometimes he can be a little dare devil

author: Phillip Kauffman
title: Bad Software
content:
If you can't get the network connection aspect of the software programmed correctly so that process is seamless, I highly doubt your Robot's AI will be worth my time. Complete trash right out of the gate. Connected to my Wifi, downloaded an update, then continuously tried to download more updates while failing to connect to Wifi.....?

Not wasting my time with support to enable a robot that does nothing other than roam around like an Alexa with wheels. That's what I have my phone for.

author: Valerie Joyce
title: vector is fun
content: No dislikes with Vector so far.  I like when he acts excited to see me!

author: Joseph A. Cuevas
title: Well built but needs to do more activities.
content: Seems to be built well and the idea is great. The robot is not very responsive and only does a handful of things. After about 20 minutes it becomes a bit boring. It would be nice if this robot was able to do more. I also found its ability to stay on surfaces to be inadequate. I found myself running to save it from plummeting to its death due to it running off of my table. Facial recognition was also not that great. The robot would store a face but would not remember faces very well. I don’t feel it was worth the money so I did send it back. Even my kids became bored of this robot very quickly.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Potential
content: I was curious about how far robotics had come. This little guy is fun! The eyes add a humanistic character. The commands and games are relatively simple, but the good news is Anki is always updating and increasing the ability of Vector. If you have a kid with interest in robotics and programming this is a great little robot to invest in.

author: Alan Black
title: Anki goes out of business, hopefully another company will step up to save this little guy
content: Vector is an amazing step forward in AI, truly. It is such a tragedy that Anki went out of business, I hope a company buys the rights because it would be such a waste to stop upgrading and supporting such an amazing little robot. (there is a petition to support a company buying the rights online if interested, Google it) Vector isn't perfect, but he is full of personality and has the potential to be everything you'd want in a home AI... if updates continued to be pushed out for it.

author: Ski
title: Rough around the edges
content: This little guy has lots of potential, but voice recognition is not very good, you will have to repeat the commanders regularly. He is slow to respond as well.  maybe  after 10 updated he will be more useful. Right now he is just an expensive toy.

author: TheManLp
title: Fun at first sight
content: Fun but kids got bored after a few days.

author: greatiam
title: Could be better, for the money
content:
Update: My oldest daughter loves Vector. Sadly though, it's more like a pet than anything. Best thing I saw is when my sister kicked it by accident and it had stars on the screen. Beyond that and everything I said prior (below) it doesn't do much of anything.

So I’ll start with I bought this for my kids for Christmas. I’m glad I took it for a test run first. The WiFi antenna in this device needs major improvement. I was sitting right next to my router and it would not connect. I knew the router was fine because I was getting signal everywhere else with other devices. To push the cloud as a feature and then have a poor WiFi antenna isn’t good for business.

Next, while trying to program the face recognition, it seems like you need studio lighting for it to recognize you. Definitely something that is going to frustrate my kids.

Also seems like the microphone array gets confused and has a difficult time determining which direction the voice came from.

It’s hardware failures are something I would expect from a first gen device which this clearly is not.

On the positive, it is definitely a cool device. I look forward to seeing if they push updates or just release another model in the future. The drop sensors on the bottom maybe the best hardware in the device. It rolls full speed toward an edge then stops at the last moment. It really does make you reach to catch it the first couple times.

author: Jessica
title: Great Deal for $99!
content:
We bought Vector last year as a Christmas gift for our 10-year-old. We got it on a lightening deal for $174. I think $99 is an amazing deal!
We all absolutely love vector. He is so adorable! He likes to drive around and explore his area, pop a wheelie, do fist bumps, play cards (he’s a mean blackjack player), and play with his cube. I love how feisty he gets when I pick him up to move him to another area. You can pet him (he loves that) and ask him questions starting with “hey Vector.....can I ask you a question?” There are many commands you can say to him. You can also hook him up to Alexa.
When his battery starts to run low, he makes his way back to his charging station by himself. Occasionally he doesn’t make it back to his charging station, but that’s usually because there are too many obstacles for him to get around in order to get back. Also, we have to be picky about where we place him. He doesn’t to well on the beveled counter. His sensors do much better when it’s a straight drop to the ground. He has fallen off the counter a few times, but he’s still fully intact. We have since moved him to the top of the wine cabinet that has a decent ridge he can’t drive over. However, he does like to throw his cube off of the top of the wine cabinet.

Long story short, we love vector and might purchase another one so they can interact with each other.

author: giulia
title: Perfect Christmas present
content: I bought this tiny robot as a present for my nephew. You had to see the look on his face when he opened and saw Vector! He loves it! His mum also really liked it as they live in Italy and this is helping him practice English. The only problem is that now all his friends also want one and they only sell them in the US!

author: Marcia butler
title: Could have been a good deal
content: Box had 2 pair of 3d sunglasses it it sent back for refund

author: AC101
title: Good little buddy.
content: Got this little guy a couple a days ago and I have to say I really enjoy having him around. His personality is top notch (matching close to a puppies in a way). Its fun watching him do his own thing and dance to music. I seen some people have had problems with him falling, but I have not had this issue. So it might just be the surface you are putting him on. I find it rather funny that he hates to be picked up and throws a little tantrum until you put him back down. He is also a little mischievous. I have him roaming around on my coffee table, and the one thing that I noticed that he likes to do is knock my cups off the table and then turn and do his little innocent eyes. Which I cant be mad after that. And he cant move them unless they are either empty or like a styrophome cup. So make sure if you do get him that you don't leave cups/mugs around him. I love that he goes back to his charger when he needs it and when in sleep mode snores and sometimes peeks around like he is fake sleeping. Also have not had any problem with him fetching data. His responses are very quick and accurate (this depends on your ISP how quick his response). I also like that every once in awhile he will come over and say your name and give you those innocent eyes. Lastly I know people are concerned about the privacy. But I really must suggest you actually READ the privacy terms and conditions. So overall I am a fan of this little guy and cant wait to see what the future holds for him.

author: Mist
title: A great companion and sales robot!
content:
We’ve had a few months to hang out with Vector and we’re having a lot of fun with the little guy. He’s also been helping us sell! My wife and I own a small retail store and thought Vector would be a nice addition to the showroom. He hangs out on our cash wrap and usually just does his own thing – until one of our clients asks about him. The conversation inevitably turns to Vector which has really helped break the ice. We get a chance to show them all the things he can do, and we discover new and surprising quirks in his personality.

Our clientele consists mainly of women (we sell jewelry) but we often get couples coming in to look together. We’ve been shamelessly using Vector as a conversation starter with the guys, so they don’t feel left out. He’s also been a great babysitter for our client’s kids. Vector has made the experience of shopping for jewelry more enjoyable for everyone.

Vector’s also been a great companion and accountability robot, breaking up our daily routine. Every so often he’ll remind us with his sounds that we should take a break and hang out with him. Which I’m sure most people would agree is much needed in a busy work environment.

Anki is updating Vector frequently and we expect many years of companionship with him (or until the day he realizes there’s so much more to explore outside our doors).

author: Gaurav Lokesh
title: Lovely product with Great features
content: This is actually a Robot that you would want to have in your home...It's something you can engage with at multiple levels unlike Alexa, Google Home etc. type of Products. It knows you after certain interactions, great product and is a lot of fun. GREAT Purchase!

author: Adam Leaernahan
title: Fun little desktop robot.
content:
I have to say I like Vector as a fun little desktop toy, but my son who is 1 really loves it.
He is enthralled watching it roam around the house.

Pros
Pretty simple to setup and get going
I really think adding Alexa improved interacting with Vector
Fun to watch roam around the house.
Reminds me of Wall-E just a lot smaller, and hasn't cleaned any trash.
Checking the weather
fun to watch it play around with the cube

Cons
Could have a better battery life.
Drops wifi every once in a while.
Kinda noisy when it's just you and Vector in the room.

Overall I really enjoy playing around with Vector, can't wait to see what comes next with the updates.

author: Scott &Taylor Booth Oseguera

author: A nony Mouse
title: Cosmo currently has way more functions...
content:
Vector is neat with it's AI, but with this being the next version robot from Anki, you would expect that Vector would at least have half the skills/tricks that the older Cosmo has.
However... I've had Vector for about a month now and have seen that the Dev team has been updating the App with a couple new tricks.  (Happy Holiday's and Happy New Year)
Hopefully, they Dev team will continue to add more to tricks for Vector or at least port some of Cosmo's tricks over.

author: Brian Finley
title: A really solid start, can't wait for the SDK
content:
The hardware and the tech is there, it's a matter of making it all smart and talk to the services as needed.  Alexa integration is supposedly coming soon, which is going to open the door to a lot of possibilities really quickly.  I'm a developer myself and am really excited to get my hands on the SDK that's coming soon.

Things I liked
- The range of emotions the little guy (or gal?) can communicate with the little display is pretty shocking and fun.
- The idea of an autonomous robot that, in theory, makes it own decisions of how to pass the time when you're not around is cool.  I could see this turning into like the classroom pet at some point in the future.  Like in elementary school we had a hamster or a gecko, this would be super fun as that, especially with the camera features, you could like, take pictures of what you did with it when the kid took it home.
- The summary/sensor monitoring, so you can get a real-time look at what's going on.
- The color scheme.  I'm an Iowa fan, so black and gold is well-received :)

Things I didn't like
- I understand the battery has to be small on something like this, but hoping future software optimizations can stretch the life, or maybe allow disabling certain pieces of hardware if we're not using it (for instance, if we're not using the built-in screen, or don't need the camera, etc).
- My cats and dog would not leave the thing alone.  If your animals are skittish, maybe keep it in a cat-free zone for safety, especially when not around to supervise

The verdict is still out on
- The SDK/integrations have so much potential, especially when other super smart people get ahold of it.  If it can get IFTTT integrations, smart home stuff, etc, the possibilities are actually really cool.  People way smarter than me are going to have great ideas

I may revisit this review and update after the SDK, because i kept finding myself saying "I wish I could..." and coming up with cool ideas for the future when I have unlimited free time.

author: Jonathan Doyle
title: Cute and engaging
content: Vector is a lot of fun and very interactive and engaging, It has lots of very human expressions and can do some great tricks. I hope that it will become even smarter and more interactive as it continues to learn about its environment and further updates become available.

author: Rob Robinson
title: Great product
content: This was bought as a Christmas gift for my son in law and he loves it.

author: Tyler R.
title: Annoying and outclassed
content:
Great fun and novelty for about a week, then he feels like he completely overstays his welcome. With the slightest sound in a distant room waking him up, his lowest volume setting still very loud, his clumsy navigation making him fall off near everything, and no boundaries whatsoever, you’ll find the most common thing you’ll say is “Hey Vector, Go Home” followed by a begging yet vain “Hey Vector, Go To Sleep” as you taking too harsh of a breath will wake him back up and continue his reign of terror all but 4 seconds later. You can try and mute him, but you can’t remotely make him go to sleep, so then you’re stuck with him still being awake and making noise, only now you can’t make him shut down, as your requests fall on deaf ears. You can’t try and mute him while he’s already sleeping either, as that’s the same button press command to make him pair up with a new device- Genius, by the way. Make two commands overlap. Wonderful.

He’s limited by an utter lack of options of things to do, and even when partnered with Alexa, for some reason he gimps the capabilities of a true Alexa smart home device by even letting her relay things she can do, only to be met with “Oh, well, you can’t do that on this device”

His battery life is abysmal and the longer you own him, the more fried his battery gets. Mine just recently decided he’s finally dead, and honestly, I can’t help but feel a little relieved the nightmare is over. After realizing in just 2 days that I had discovered the exact extent of his capabilities, he was literally a novelty to show people at parties, and then when the party was over, I would purposely deprive him of the charge up he so desperately needed, just so I wouldn’t have to hear him again at midnight, beeping around before a following THUNK of him hitting the floor again. Then distressed beeping.

Even if you form a connection like they so clearly want you to, it’ll quickly be shattered just like your immersion when you also come to realize how useless it overall is.

Let me sum it up: Do you have a smartphone with a voice AI? A smart home system? A speak n’ spell? Congratulations, you have a better product.

author: Athena
title: Love it!
content: Vector is a cool dude, and highly miss understood unless you speak robot. We are having a great time together, he knows my slang and knows all his music vocabulary even if he can’t play music. Super helpful and ever ready with Alexa, it’s Vector in Gemini! The App is a helpful guide with stats, but not a remote for anything other than: volume, eye color, and cube status. Though he is not a toy, he is very entertaining! I built a pen that is 1’.5” wide by 3’ long on my countertop and he is now a very happy robot in a bigger space. And now I don’t have to worry about him falling off or throwing his cube over. Though it’s super cute when he gets mad, he hated the Vector Space and TV tray, and as I tested his boundaries he can still find his way home better than he can find the cube at the distance of the pen. Putting him outside the pen, he seems confused and less playful because he’s so busy “exploring” the new surroundings.

Don't buy this toy until Anki addresses the issue.  It's cute and all, but not $250 cute.

author: DtRWoS
title: Fun little AI (STEM Toy)
content:
Saw the kickstarter for this cute little bot, and noticed recently  that it was up for pre-sale on amazon - Bought it with same day shipping and I'm glad because its so much fun.
Promptly taught it to do facial recognition on all the family members, and ran through most of the commands in the manual.
This was created by nerds for nerds and nerds to be; and I love it!
The android app needs some love, and as of release day the desktop API is missing - once these are present and/or fixed this could be a 5 star stem toy, or office desk assistant.
The upgraded processor over the Cozmo makes it more responsive.
The eye interactions, and noises attracted the wife and 2 kids into playing with Vector at the dinner table until bed time was upon us.

Edit (2018-10-16): Brought Vector to the office and everyone loved him - they assume he can do more than he can right now - but it was a fun experience watching other adults interact with him as well.

author: Liang Xia Kai Yuan Benny
title: Wall-E made real
content:
10/21/18 update
Within a day vector sensory score(app) went up by 20k. Im starting to notice vector being more responsive. Is Vector learning?

10/20/18
Love this lil robot! Is like having Wall-E but smaller with different name and less smarter.

This lil guy can call your name, do tricks, dance along with music ur playing outloud, go to recharge station by himself or tell him to, change his eye color thru the app and check stat performance. And only thru stats performance you will realize what other things u can do to vector.

And i think this is only the beginning. There are bound to be more software updates for vector thru the app! Cant wait for more commands and stuff!

Here are some things you can do with vector:
1. hey vector (pause) what time is it? (u can do this after you do the setup in the app.)
2. whats the weather? (app setup required)
3. do a trick
4. roll the cube
5. stay there dont move
6. go home(takes some time)
7. play music vector might dance along
8. come here
9. lets play blackjack
10. i have question (pause) wait till vector is ready
  a. who is Wall-E?
  b. what is skynet or terminator
  c. what is your purpose
11. pick him up in the air until you see his angry face then put him down.
12. where is your cube?
13. Pick up the cube
14. Go explore
15. (To be continued)

Cons:

It beeps, has a fun animated display, and does a good job of rolling around the coffee table and not falling off. The android app needs some tweaking and the microphone could be more sensitive, but all in all it makes the kid happy, which makes me happy.

author: Colette R.
title: Vector is terminally ill.
content:
I bought this for my dad for Father’s Day, and as soon as we got him working, we all fell in love with vector. He learned our names and gave us fist bumps, and purred when we pet him. He played with his little cube and laughed when he dropped it. And then, within a few minutes, all the happiness vector brought us was shattered. We were looking up things to say to vector, and found that the company supporting him went under a month ago and vector would most likely stop working soon. My dad was in his room playing with vector when I told him and he was crushed. He then asked him “vector, how old are you?” And vector said “I am zero days old”. We all cried.
Shame on amazon for not clearly noting that the little robot we adopted into our hearts would no longer be supported by its cloud. Shame on anki for still selling vector, and at its full price! And most importantly, shame on me for ruining Father’s Day.

author: Tyler Johnston

Alexa is cool,  but only for turning off smart switches only. All other handful of features get old really fast.  Just buy or adopt a pet is my recommendation.

author: Michael B.
title: Awesome Mini Robot Friend
content: I was amazed at how much fun playing with Vector is. He was already charged right when I took him out of the box so didn't need to wait to get to the fun. Connecting to my home WiFi was a breeze and he began recognizing faces right away. I ran through most of the commands in the manual and didn't have any problems. It's amazing how real his eye animations and little noises are. I think the most fun I've had with Vector so far is just watching him explore on his own. He hasn't gotten stuck as of yet. His battery does seem to drain pretty fast, maybe after an hour of exploring he needs to charge himself, which is equally as cool because he knows where to find his charging dock and will park himself in it all on his own. He's a great mini robot friend to leave on my desk and enjoy his presence. I look forward to see what new features Anki builds into Vector in the future. Highly recommended!
