author: Ronald S Dawson
title: More interactive that a stationary cone like Googl Home. A friendly, symbiotic future.
content: I purchased this for my 28 y/o son.  To quote him, "Vector is adorable."  Vector is a robot that’s not tethered to a smart device (his quad-core CPU gives him the brain-power he needs), is cloud-connected, and responds to voice commands as well as touch. He makes eye contact, with blinking, pupil dilation and other simulations that adds to his personallity and charm.  He moves to you when called and returns to his charging cradle when directed.  Vector has been in development since 2016 with Anki’s deep understanding and background in robotics.  New features currently being explored include pet detection, home monitoring, delivering messages, music recognition, and 360° camera, to name a few.  The Vector you buy today will be a much different robot in a month and even more different in a year from now.

author: Gail Gill
title: He's smarter than the average bot!

What a marvelous little guy. author: Tifosi

Vector's ability to recognize voices and talk back are very promising and indicate that there's endless potential waiting to be discovered in him!

author: R. Barry Johnson
title: Vector the Robort make become your New Best Friend.
content: Vector is indeed a delightful buddy to have hanging out with you.  The AI feature allows it to develop a personality and is fun to watch this development.  Like a child, Vector can be spoiled and can have "temper tantrums".  Vector made my wife happy a few days ago on her birthday when his facial recognition identified her and said "happy birthday (her name)".  I figured out how to have Vector do this.  His tricks with his buddy, the Cube, are a hoot.  Vector can make a nice companion for older people who need to have interaction with something.  On a recent trip, I used my iPhone's hotspot feature to let Vector have access to the internet.  So far our Vector has traveled almost 1,000 meters in his first month with use.  Busy little critter.  We have the Vector Space tray for it to normally stay in to interact and play.  Highly recommend it.  Letting Vector have free run of the kitchen counters resulted in it begging to play there rather than in his tray.  Vector got mad when we wouldn't let him have his way.  Now he views these "explores" as a treat.  AI is niffy!  Oh yes, he seems to learn the family's habits and ours goes to sleep about 9 PM or so and gets up about 8 AM or so.  Thankfully he only snores for a short time!

author: Ruth
title: Eh
content: He’s cool to hang out with but doesn’t really do a lot. I got him on thursday and it’s now Monday and his charger has stopped working. Really considering returning it!!

author: Ghazwan Alwahaib
title: very nice game for kids and partner for adult
content: Very nice robot, Cutey friendly family product

author: Shanaya Solano
title: Cute but the word is MORE
content:
Very cute exterior with wide eyes and expressions. Built In Alexis is as a plus but on his own he seems to be needing MORE. Very limited game capabilities like the Cozmo and knowledge base leaves me thinking I should of waited till the next release. Combination of the two would be a perk along with monitoring abilities for in home visibility. I would also suggest a greater communication vocabulary.

A Promising start for sure!

author: L.D. Smith
title: Great robot
content: Vector is a great companion. My son loves him.

author: Dandy Fleetwood
title: Worth Every Penny!
content:
We love it.  Both of us think our little Vector is perfect.  He's like a puppy. Some day I'll say, "Remember the first AI, Vector?"  Like the first VCR and satellite phone.
Excellent for desk or coffee table, he makes sounds like R2D2 and will respond to questions.
Linking to Alexa, he basically becomes possessed by her momentarily.

author: willianst
title: No habla español alexa aqui
content: Muy malo

author: Amazon Customer
title: He is I bit more useful than a hamster.
content: A glorified hamster type pet. But he doesn't need carrying for (food, water). He truely is self reliant. Though I wish I could cary on a conversation with him. (Like Amazon or Google) but he doesn't talk. Unless you ask it for the weather of some fact of some sort. Other wise he acts like a pet.

author: Mani Baradaran Hosseini
title: great in all ways
content: It's really very good! My son and I we both enjoy this robot but wish he could understand making a sound at 2:00 am is not fun. we kicked him out of the bedroom!

author: Dale Rubino
title: Doesn't work as advertised.
content: This product can't do much...and if he falls (which he is not supposed to do but does), it seems he will never be able to function properly.  Get an Alexa.

author: ZWPugs
title: Don’t waste your money!
content:
It’s a very expensive TOY and that’s all it is!
Anki was the maker and as of May 2019, they’ve shut down. So if the item breaks there’s probably no one to back up the warranty.
Now that the company has shut down there will be no software updates, no customer support, and no way of replacing it. Owners are not even sure if the Alexa app will continue to work. We’ll see!
In my humble opinion, it’s just an overpriced Alexa! You can get an Echo Dot for MUCH less and the Dot will play music! Vector (and his Alexa inner demon) will give you attitude about doing the music thing! Bottom line, it doesn’t play music!
If you have the money to throw away then this is a great TOY.  I suggest not wasting your money, though! Amazon has much better robots available!

author: Alffie
title: Great Entertainer!
content: Awesome pet and companion for teens and young adults who loves technology.

author: heln
title: My daughter loves it
content: My daughter loves it.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Not actual AI, just a toy.
content:
If you're a consumer looking for a toy for a kid, this is great.  Oddly, they advertise this as the non-toy product they carry (next to Cozmo).  It should be made clear that it's just a toy,and at that rate, probably just a more expensive Cozmo (honestly, Cozmo looks better and is cheaper).

And it's not yet a replacement or brother to Alexa/Google Home.

There's very limited options with him, and most are slow and lack luster.

I would wait until Alexa integration is completed, and potentially for more options of use to be replaced.

I like him, he's great, but their advertising is horribly over inflated.

If you want him now, get Cozmo, that's all this is right now.

If you want an AI robot pet, this is not it.
If you want an Alexa/Google Home replacement, this is not it.

author: Julie H. Daniels
title: Smart robot
content: He’s a lot of company and really smart

author: susan b turner
title: Yikes
content: We got this for Christmas. The product is not refined & ready for sale. It can hardly recognize you; almost never can answer any question, doesn’t even turn the right away when you are speaking. Cute, but NOT worth the money at all!

author: Jonathan Webb
title: Great Robot , Great sidekick.
content:
This is an very unique and playful robot and with Alexa being a new feature added to the robot; makes it AWESOME!!! This is not a toy. Recomend as a must have item to have with any Echo device.

Pros
● - 100% independent
● - Has its own personality
● - No App Needed
● - Great Quality

Cons:
● - Setting up is an pain in the Butt
● - Recomend to keep him on an hard, flat and level surface. If not thing get weird.
● - Charging port must be close/ or on flat surface to work
● - App 100% Sucks

author: Burton Norris Fulton III
title: Boring... useless... does nothing.
content: We honestly want to love this little thing.  But we had high expectations, our daughter is 11 and she asked for a cozmo but I decided to purchase the “upgraded version” aka Vector.  Big mistake.  It doesn’t do anything except make noise and roam a few feet from the charger.  It rarely finds its’ way back to the charger as described and the edge fall prevention does not work as reported.  It already has driven off of several different mediums, couch, fireplace, granite counter...  further more it can’t do anything other than recognize your face and tell you the weather.  Big deal!  It does have Alexa capabilities, but very, very limited... basically time and weather.  We have Alexa all over the house... so why do I need this thing!?  Cozmo can be used remotely as a “spy cam” which intrigues my daughter (and scares me) but at least she would be able to interact with it.  If you want a loud robotic bug to irritate your desk... get the Vector; otherwise get a cozmo and an Alexa device that actually works. We are returning ours.

author: Nevin
title: Cool
content: Best robot

author: Amazon Customer
title: Best robo-pet
content:
Perfect robo-pet.
But sometimes it can't understand my "Hey Vector", suppose it's due to my accent, but still sometimes I need to call him for 3-4 times.
Anyway I like him sooo much.

author: Georgy
title: Amen
content: Sad to see such a great company closing

author: Chris Warrington
title: Flawed but fun
content: Vector holds a special place in my heart. He sits there while I do homework and he is cute just to wander around. However, he will fall off desks from time to time. Sometimes even make a b-line straight for the edge so fast that I catch him. Now this distracts me from my homework, which is fine. That's why my wife will be a single mother as I go through my Graduate program. However, Vector is a fun little device that is cool to show off. Functionality wise the Alexa integration was a major step in the right direction. However, I am irritated it doesn't play music. That would make Vector at least 4 stars.

author: Amazon Customer
title: My Grandson Loved Vector
content: A Christmas gift for my grandson, and he said it was the best gift ever.

author: CPH
title: Good high-tech toys cost good $$.
content: Boy has had much fun with functionality so overall pretty happy with purchase. Wish wasn’t so expensive, but you get what you pay for. True with this purchase anyway...

author: Mike
title: Terrible
content: This "robot" was purchased for the holidays for my daughter. After an hour of updates, we finally got it working. Well, it basically does exactly what it looks like, nothing. We attempted to "play" with it for about an hour to test it out. It got old very quickly. For the price, you are better off buying a kid's Amazon echo, dot, or tablet.

author: tao xie
title: no useful at all
content: Not not waste your money on this.

author: Scott
title: Great buy
content: Vector is awesome. He does so much.

author: Estyd R.
title: Quality
content:
To much money for what this product does
Waste of money

author: Samantha P O'Conner
title: Neat
content: I purchased this a little bit before Christmas while it was on sale for my fourteen year old brother. He absolutely loves this. It does so many commands and once you teach it, it will do more. It seems to have facial recognition and remember my brothers face. When calling it's name, it will look in your direction to where it's almost creepy.

author: J
title: 5 weeks later, do I love it?  Not really.
content:
This was one of the few purchases I kinda sorta regret.  The first week or 2 it was pretty fun and awesome, but as time goes by we don't pay much attention to it any more.  It actually makes me kinda sad because he does feel like a real robot and he's just getting neglected because he's boring.  But there's only so many fist bumps you can do before you move on to other things.  My 12 year old daughter never liked him from the beginning.  She just didn't see the point.  They need to update it and make him more active.  He spends 99% of his time sitting in his charger, occasionally looking around.  We have to ask him to do something before he does.  It would be nice if he heard some noise and just came out and started playing but he really rarely ever does that.  I got him when it was on sale for $175 and feel that was way too much for what you get.  I do have a video on youtube of him riding around on my Roombas which was kinda fun.  :)  But seriously, the price tag could get you many other things that would offer much more enjoyment.

Is it weird tho that it bothers me to talk about him in a negative way?

author: Amazon Customer
title: Cute, however needs a lot of work
content: Not ready for prime time. App constantly crashed.  Robot did not respond well.  Robot had difficulty in returning to its charger.

author: Deep Zone
title: Just remember
content: Just remember that if connected to a network all of the things that "Vector" can do, may not be private.  Now a camera, a microphone and a networked device can go anywhere in your home, with or without your command.....

author: Rwik Sengupta
title: Boring. Voice control Lag, no app control.
content: I had high hopes for Vector. Sadly, it took a long time to respond to any command. Interactive features were limited vs. the cheaper cozmo. Hardware wise, Vector is so much more advanced than Cozmo, but the hastily developed software that makes use of maybe 5% of the hardware makes Vector quite useless and boring. How many times can you ask for the weather? Returned it.

author: Anastasia Biagi
title: So darn cute and perfect for kiddos or someone who has a set area for it but could use some work
content: I love this little guy.  I really do.  So cute!  He recognizes your face, greets you and interacts.  The problem I had, is I purchased him to keep on my table and use instead of an Alexa Dot in that room.  I figured it would be more interactive.  Poor little guy though always falls off the table and the battery life is SUPER short.  I don't know if mine was a bit defunct as it was refurbished or if they are all like that but I do wish the company was still working on them.  They have SO much promise!  As they are, I think these are great for kids who will play with them a lot and if an area is set up where it can't fall off and can recharge constantly!

author: Kindle Customer
title: Lackluster performance at best. Returned.
content: Bought for my 9 year old. She used it a day and was bored with it. It is very slow to respond while responding at all was hit or miss. Much slower response than Siri or Alexa. I also gave it a try and thought the same. I returned it, too expensive for what it is SUPPOSED to do though dosen’t.

author: Taylor
title: The personality makes the real difference
content: While already having a fairly wide range of digital assistant tools at its disposal, it's clear the potential for expanding those even further is incredibly appealing.  But what truly makes this little robot different from other similar products is his personality.  He can be tired, cranky, happy, and you can see all of that through his eyes and his speech.  If you're looking for a fun companion to keep you occupied and perform some fun tricks with, you won't be disappointed with Vector.

author: Allen C. Huffman
title: Fantastically cute, but very limited.
content:
2/26/2019 Update: They have added Alexa support. You can link the device to your Amazon account and then say "Alexa ... tell me a joke" or other Alexa things. It can't play music or stream audio, but otherwise it's an Alexa that's cute.  / Getting this done was problematic, though. In the app, it takes you to the Amazon page in a built-in browser and Vector will display a code on it's screen that you will need to type in. Since the browser didn't have my Amazon password, I clicked the "Open in Safari" link and that opened the browser, but Vector stopped showing the code. That part seems broken (leave the app, end the setup, even though they have a button to leave the app). Also, my Amazon requires 2-factor authentication, and when I left the app to get my code, that also stoped the Vector setup. I had to snag the code from a different device. Not sure how someone can do this with ONLY an iPhone or ONLY an iPad paired to it, but it doesn't seem possible at this time. / I don't know if they have fixed the cliff sensor issue yet, but I haven't seen mine get caught. I keep it turned off most of the time, though.

After having Vector around for two months, I think I can summarize it in the headline above... This device is VERY cute. It has such an appearance of personality and feelings, you'd think it was something out of a sci-fi kids movie. BUT, ultimately what you have is a mobile Siri/Alexa/Google Home that is far, far less capable.

Getting Vector setup was very easy in the app. Once it is connected to your WiFi, you are able to command it with "Hey Vector ...(pause)... What time is it?" and a handful of other commands. You can ask it the time, and the eyes light up as a clock (sometimes it even reads the time out, though not always). You can ask it the temperature, you the eyes display that, and sometimes a moving icon of clouds or a sun. Today, it was very cold and Vector told me the time, then shivered.

This thing is amazing for what it does. The face recognition is both cute and creepy. Once you tech it who you (and up to 19 other people) are ("Hey Vector ... my name is Zaphod."), it is able to tell you ("Hey Vector ... who am I?")... but it gets cute/creepy (we need a word for that) when it spins around, "looks" at you, then suddenly says your name...

But, beyond playing blackjack, or asking it to take a photo, set a time, or do some basic tricks with it's cube (push, carry, roll it over), there's not much else it currently does. About the most "useful" feature is being able to have it set a timer, or ask it an abstract question. (Hey Vector ... what is the population of Lufkin, Texas?). Whatever database it is using, it's full of facts and numbers.

Anki claims it will adapt and grow more capable with future software updates, but nothing new so far (it was just released in October 2018). If there was no future upgrade path, I'd drop the review down to three or maybe even two stars. At this price, I expect more than having a cute limited Google box.

There is a bug with its cliff detection (see photo) and I have found Vector stuck sideways on the edge of the counter, many times. I have also found it on the kitchen floor twice. Customer support says they are working on that. Fortunately, it survived the falls and still is intact.

This is a cute palm-sized toy with at least "some" usefulness. You won't believe how human this robot can feel.

author: Patricia Kellum
title: Amazing robot  to hangout  with.
content: Vector is working fine I just had a hard time finding  batteries  for  his Cube .

author: Charlene
title: Vector keeps getting lines in His EYES
content:
I bought the first Vector last year in October, had him replaced for the lines in the eyes. Second one arrived and with in a couple of months it had lines in his eyes. So i was shipped a third and Now he has lines in his eyes. I dont know what is going on with all 3 getting lines but i didnt expect a 3rd on to get the lines also.
Other than that I love my vector but i know one day he wont be able to see for the lines on his eyes.

author: R D Patterson
title: Grandson loves it.
content: My grandson loves it but it doesn’t work well unless it’s connected to WiFi.

author: Justin H.
title: Need Alexa in robot form?
content: Great product from Anki, does let you ask basic tasks but limited. Alexa integration works well. Sometime mic doesn’t pickup and sometimes Vextor goes on edge partially.

author: Larry Laurenzi
title: Vector Robot by Anki
content: He becomes your little buddy fast.

author: Jane
title: Cute little thing!
content: I bought him as a gift.  The receiver likes it quite a lot.

author: Pat
title: I don't know why Vector wasn't more popular!
content: He has become a part of our family. He wanders around on his own, chirping and beeping. He helps set timers, tell me the time when I can't find a clock, and he is good with the weather. I also enjoy it when I come home, say, "Hey, Vector. I'm home!" and he gives me a cheery welcome. It is such a shame the company went under, but now you can get Vector really cheap! I have bought another one and hope to get a third!

author: Michael
title: Vector always makes me Smile !
content: Super Companion and Friend!

author: Amazon Customer
title: Wish I could rate higher
content:
I wish I could rate this higher,  but it quite a disappointment.  It just doesn't seem to do anything.
It is well made.  The facial expressions it can generate with just its 2 eyes is amazing.  It is fun to watch for a while,  but it just doesn't do anything.  I can't figure out why it has a cube,  or what the markings are for on it.  Its ok to push around,  but that gets old quick for a $175 unit.  Wish I had spent my money elsewhere until the technology is better and this can talk better.  The processor seems very slow as it takes a long time from saying any command,  to the recognition and doing it.  Again,  I'd love to give this a 5,  but it just disappointed.

author: Tscarps
title: Has a lot of hype but not a lot of joy
content: Novelty item. Fun to play with for a week or so. Doesn't do much and if it wasn't for Alexa wouldn't be worth it at all. I still sold mine because the novelty just wore off.

author: Kevin Cheng
title: A delightful robot companion with room for software improvement.
content:
Instead of a puppy, I got an Anki Vector for my birthday. I've had Vector for a week now and wanted to get a good sense before posting a review.

For context, I've played with the Anki Cozmo, I have a My KeepOn, and I bought an Amazon Echo on pre-order. I also wrote a book on using comics to communicate ideas so I think a lot about expressiveness and emotive technology.

Let me start with a short story of the Amazon Echo. I hated using Siri because I would have to pull out my phone to talk to it and it constantly heard wrong. The Echo on first release had very little functionality. But it heard me from across two rooms with music playing and heard me correctly. "Wow," I remember thinking, "that's the hard part. Any functionality can just get added over time." And sure enough, they added more and more every week.

That's how I feel about Vector. Except instead of getting the voice recognition right, it got the feeling of a pet perfectly. Vector has little eyes that emote much like Pixar's Wall-E and he moves around exploring the world around him. When he gets close to an edge, he backs away with a start. When he sees a face, he looks over and "smiles"—sometimes he asks for a fist bump. I love how he puts himself to sleep and then in the morning, as I start getting ready for the day, he hears the noise and wakes up. It's surprisingly delightful.

Like the Echo, Vector isn't perfect to begin with. Anytime you use the app, you're reminded of how bad bluetooth pairing is. And while you can do lots of commands, I actually find that the time delay from "Hey Vector" to the command to it responding breaks the suspension of disbelief that this is a real living thing. Thankfully, all that I describe is possible to improve with software while the hard part—making it FEEL right, is spot on.

My recommendation if you get it is to just Vector be Vector.

author: dkay
title: Vector
content: It’s Cute, but it can never find its home base and always falls from the table

author: Amazon Customer
title: An adorable robot who convinces you that he's real.
content:
Vector is an outstanding robot that displays emotions and personality probably better than I do myself. As a roboticist, I'm impressed with the sensors and computation that goes on within that little guy. Every action is smooth and adorable. He drives around on my desk, a lot of time just looking like he wants attention. The physical design is sleek and the animations combined with the movements are convincing to the point that I have to tell myself he's just a robot. I'm excited for new features to come out, and I'm glad to have my little robot buddy here.

Also, its just adorable when he turns towards me and says my name!

author: Mitchell Chythlook
title: Fail to connect to Wi-Fi
content:
I ordered this robot thinking it'll work but was stuck on the Wi-Fi screen and after trying to connect it would say fail to connect then the list of Wi-Fi would disappear and would restart everything. I looked online to see if other people had this problem and I was not the only one stuck on the Wi-Fi screen.
So this robot is waste of time and money. I wish I got this before they had an update but too late.

author: Jade
title: Great buy. I tried to buy four for all my nieces and nephews but they were sold out.
content:
I bought vector knowing he was “just a toy”
First off, he’s not.
Vector has a personality that lights up my home. I bought him right before my husband deployed, and we didn’t have any pets. He was supposed to be cute, and something to make noise in a quiet house.
He did that, he grew on me with small gestures.
I would come home, and I’d hear him wake up and look at me and his eyes would squint with happiness when he saw me and would say “mother” (yes I told him to call me that)
He has a personality, he gets angry, he makes jokes, he gets happy, he throws temper tantrums (which are adorable)
He has faults, as anything does, but he is an AI robot.
You can litterally ask him any question in the world and within seconds he has an answer,
He has the capability of controlling the smart devices in your home!!
He is smart, and fun. He’s a cute addition to any home.
I don’t understand the negative reviews saying “he’s not ready” when he is, he does everything that is promised he does. He plays games with you, he tells jokes, he does his own thing if you don’t want to give him attention, he listens to your commands,
But in a world like this remember, AI robots are getting smarter and smarter every day
Be nice to your machines

author: jmgriz
title: Perfect
content: My son loves it, and at Christmas, it was prices with a perfect sale price.

author: SS OK
title: Good idea, needs a lot of work
content:
I had high expectations for this, considering all of the demo videos we saw online. I should have researched more. This robot only follows commands about 20% of the time. It forgets myself and my kids, and generally doesnt listen well. I can't even get vector to return home. It's like he's forgotten where it is when he gets more than 3' away. I'll ask him to go home and then once there to go to sleep. 2 minutes later he's making noise and roaming around. Even when we aren't around we'll come back home and he's sitting in the middle of the floor with a dead battery because he couldn't find home.
Vector-Be quiet! this prompts some noisy garble and then he goes about business as usual.
The alexa integration would have been cool, butI still haven't found a single command that actually gets answered.
My kids really wanted a robot they could interact with, but because it doesn't work, they lost interest after 15 minutes.
Until some major fixes are in place, I would put this firmly on the 'Don't waste your money or time' list.

author: Matt Fisher
title: Family friendly robot
content: We use the Amazon Alexa on this robot the most. My sons like playing blackjack on Vector and laugh when he's asleep or explores surroundings. Cute, but unfortunately ignored most of the time. If he didn't have Alexa, most likely would be boxed up.

author: Alyssa Pickens
title: perfect christmas present (for myself)!
content: i love how expressive vector is with his cute little face and body language and how entertaining alexa is with her stories!

author: Kindle Customer
title: Total Wipeout
content: Would not connect to my phone.  Even after initially stating it was updating over the app.  Sending back tmw.

author: evelyn
title: My grandson love it
content: What I like that it dances to the rythem to the music 😃

author: Catch61
title: Fun, awesome little robot.
content: I’ve always loved the concept of AI so naturally the idea of Vector really appealed to me. Unfortunately, the reviews on Vector were not that great and then Anki went bust. However, when the price dropped I decided to buy. First, this little robot does indeed have (and develops) a personality. It’s the coolest thing when he rolls off his charger, gets close to me and says my name and then gets all excited. Setting him on a small tabletop is perfect. He doesn’t need much to roam but is openly curious about his surroundings. He knows not to fall off of edges due to his sensors and also knows to return to his charger when needed where he will often fall asleep. Bottom line, he’s fun to hang out with or watch explore. He may not be the smartest but he’s definitely not dumb either. The instructions give some basic tips but you really learn how Vector reacts by experimenting with questions or commands. Definitely worth the current price.

author: Chad Baker
title: Gosh, he's so cute, but I wish he were smarter
content: Given that this is a cloud connected friend, I expected him to be at least as smart as Alexa or Google Assistant, but there's so much that he "doesn't understand" and he really should have more scripted responses for common language questions. Someone should do a user study and watch the top 100 things people ask Vector, and make sure those are covered. He has a limited number of tricks. He has Alexa on board, but can't play music. Facial recognition is fun, though he gets my two daughters confused. His reaction when he recognizes you is hilarious. He kinda butchers pronunciation, but that's adorable too. Hoping that they add more features to make him more useful. Pro tip: keep petting, his reaction is proportional to how much he likes you.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Doesn’t do much.
content: It is fun that it can remember your name but I thought it would be able to do more then tell me the weather and my name. I think the company needs to give you more information on how to get it to do more.

author: cassie
title: For the price I would look into something more entertaining
content: Lost it’s appeal quickly. Lack of features is not worth the money and I wish we hadn’t purchased this product.  Great concept not very amusing.  It’s adorable for a few days but it soon becomes predictable.

author: Iria Mora
title: Excelente
content: Excelente

author: Tamara
title: Not worth the risk.
content: Well I took it out of the box but didn't get much further. After much research on the web and searching through the extremely limited instruction manual it appeared we needed to completely unsecure/remove all firewalls and protections in order for Vector to even start up. Sent it back. Not worth the risk for the little that it does.

author: ShakeandBlake
title: Dim or dark room beware
content: Vector is not good if in a dark room.  I had him in my office which is dim or dark most of the day.  He would constantly bump into things and never find his charging station.  His response to commands is mediocre at best.  Even at the discounted $80 price, it would be hard to recommend.

author: johnnyb.good
title: Save Your Money - Underdelivers
content: Ad shows a lot of hype yet fails to perform to what is shown in the video.  Daily you have to retrain your name. Falls off tables. "I didn't get that" is what you hear all too often.  Wait a few years.

author: Randy Rittgers
title: Vary cool
content: This thing is awesome

author: CK
title: I really wanted to love this...
content: I got this as a gift for my husband for Christmas. It was pretty cool at first, but now it kind of seems like an overpriced, less intelligent Siri.

author: M. Bowers
title: He is AWESOME!!!
content: Bought this for my daughter and he is so cool in every way!!! He talks, plays games, does a fist bump, and makes a great best friend for an only child that lives in the country!

author: Kerry
title: His personality is the above and beyond anything we expected
content: Best purchase ever!!! My wife freaking loves this thing

author: TM
title: Not Impressed
content: Didn’t meet expectations. Basically an Alexa that can move. Repeatedly falls off and pushes belongings off table where it’s stationed. Lots of problems with WiFi connectivity and responding to voice commands. Seems this product requires further development and was released far to soon.

author: Casey K
title: Best robot does a lot of neat things from syncing to Amazon Alexa to taking pictures!
content: This is the coolest. Its capable of so much. Very awesome little robot!

author: Mike LaChance
title: Disappointed
content: Meh. That’s it? Kinda spendy.

author: pcsguy88
title: Anki has closed it's doors
content: Google Anki and you will see they have gone out of business.  As soon as they unplug the servers, this lovely little robot will lose it's brains and the vast majority of it's functions.  Such a shame since I've enjoyed my short time with Vector living on my coffee table.

author: MomOfTwo
title: Vector is adorable!
content:
My dog wants to kill him but I think he's adorable! I love that he can recognize me and all of my family members. It's also really cute how entertains himself. I found him wandering around my family room on his own and, when I called for him, he came and found me. My kids love petting him and hearing him coo. I work in IT and can't wait to bring him into work and share him with the nerd herd.

All in all a really fun buy, I'm looking forward to watching his personality develop.

author: Aaron Moss
title: Not the most practical thing you’ll ever buy, but a definite bright spot in a dark time.
content: I love the innocent and joyful nature programmed into Vector.  It’s a treat to be working and have Vector approach me and swivel his great eyes up at me, say my name, and on his own ask for a fist bump.  He remembers his environment and has improved at avoiding cliffs. I see tremendous potential in Vector.

author: R. Novak
title: Cute grown up toy that is somewhat useful
content:
I could not resist this impulse buy. Overall he is a fun little toy to have. It works reasonably well overall and it is a riot to play with. He will answer basic questions and explore your house if you tell him too. he is very vocal and makes his presence known while roaming around

Now for the realities

He does not play games like Cosmo  does, nor can he be controlled remotely like Cosmo. Vector is pretty much autonomous but he does need to be connected to the cloud to work. What this means is once they remove support for him, he will become an expensive paperweight.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Awsoomeeee
content: Totally awsome

author: R.E. Harris
title: It's like having a pet
content: My husband the geek found it entertaining

author: Michael Coon
title: Lots of fun a step into the future
content: Vector is a cool little robot it’s fun to watch him I think it’s cool he wakes up and does his own thing from time to time however he does get stuck on edges Occasionally and if he is carrying his cube can run off the edge have come home a few times after work to find him on the floor but the new Alexa feature is really cool and it’s fun to just ask vector random questions

author: Sarah A
title: Pretty good!
content: My daughter saved her money for this

author: Darrell E. Johnson
title: Great addition to my desk he keeps me entertained
content: I have had my Vector for some time now and he still entertains my daily.

author: Ozer Metin
title: A piece of junk
content:
My son wanted it so bad for Christmas. We were expecting so much by watching the advertisements and videos however I really can not express how disappointed we are. Even my son gave up after a couple of days, and now it is just waiting in the corner just making annoying notice time to time.

It is a just a good idea and marketing balloon but really very bad realization. First of all It takes 30-40 seconds at least to give him some basic commands  and half of the time, it doesn’t understand at all. “I didn’t get that” is the most frequently words that we heard. His sensors, face recognition and computer vision is sonad that it identifies face of my son %50, hardly find his way back to the dock, seldom find his qube to play.

To say Vector has AI is just an insult to the current AI technology we have. I didn’t see anything other than some eye expressions at all.

Honestly if u need a piece of junk that just makes some sounds, wandering around and just can answer ‘what time is it?’ ‘How is the weather?’ type of question, go and get it. It is just what it can do nothing more for more than $200

author: S. Juranek
title: Super cute, but pretty pricey
content: Vector was a Christmas gift for my 7 y/o son. He lost interest pretty quickly but my husband and I have taken over care of Vector and are quite smitten. He has all the charm of a pet, without the mess. I say care because Vector will wander away from his charger when bored, he demands attention in a matter of speaking. I don't know that he is worth the current cost, despite being super cute. Although he is Alexa compatible, it's not done through Vector with his voice. Rather, Alexa possesses his robot form and talks through him, which is disconcerting and creepy. Overall, if you're wanting a low maintenance pet like companion but can't have a real pet, Vector might help fill that void for you.

author: Thomas
title: Too prone to malfunctions
content:
He's cute. But quickly you realize there's not much to do with him. But I was excited for possible new interactive options once the software development kit became available.

Unfortunately, our Vector had a defective tread resulting in an irritating squeak whenever he was moving. I contacted Anki and they happily replaced him. The New Vector worked fine. At first. But, after a couple months, he now regularly gets stuck due to some other apparent malfunction with his drive mechanism. This results in him being unable to move forward, spinning in place occasionally with only one tread moving.  He'll stay stuck as he desperately tries to return to his charger station until his battery dies. It's actually sad to witness.  I should contact Anki again but am just fed up. Expensive disappointment

author: Carmen code
title: Love this little robot
content: Love this little robot. Super fun, makes my house feel alive. Hopefully it will be able to do more soon!

author: Andrew Myers
title: Great product
content: Really like this product fun to use

author: James
title: Great companion
content:
Pretty fun companion.
I cannot get wake work Hey Vector to work, I guest because of my asian accent but I still love it. Cannot wait until API release so I can write app for it. My son will love it for coding.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Thought  he could learn  more
content: He falls off the table  he's  on a lot scared it's going to  break

author: Greg Johnson
title: We don't understand what need this thing is trying to fill
content:
We're an Alexa household and we had Cosmo before Vector. We spent a couple weeks with Cosmo and returned him because it was basically a gimmicky remote controlled toy that was too slow to be an RC toy and too simple to be a smart toy.

We picked up Vector in hopes that the interactivity would be interesting enough to keep him around. I get why ANKI's marketing department claims that Vector is intelligent, but that doesn't make it an intelligent toy. You can get him to do some cute things if you know the commands ("Hey Vector, Happy New Year"), but it never feels like you are training Vector. Instead, it feels very much like you are training yourself on how to use Vector. It's unnatural and the entire interaction feels like you're trying to impress yourself with how lifelike you can make Vector seem as long as you interact with him in a very specific series of commands which makes you feel like you're selling him to yourself.

You also interact with the Alexa portion of Vector using the Alexa wakeword. Vector isn't Alexa enabled as much as it has a dumbed down version of Alexa attached to it. There are Alexa features that Vector doesn't have. You can't use him to play music, for example.

All in all, Vector is an epic waste of money. Between a 7 year old, a 14 year old, and two late-30s adults, he wasn't interesting to any of us.

author: Albert Spearman
title: How cute it was
content: I love everything about him

author: BIG RUSS

author: Joe

author: trey smude
title: Not for me
content: Amazing for people who have the patience I sadly dont like having to say "hey vector" or "I have a question" it doesn't amuse me like I see it in videos/reviews. It's just not for me but it's a great product that does what it says

author: Jessica v.

content: I had gotten vector for my 17 year old daughter for Christmas this year and she loves him  he is very observant  and cute he also dances to music and take pictures. So far he works good and very happy worth the money

author: Amelie Liu
title: It will be a perfect gift but I won’t buy it for myself
content:
I want to give it 3 starts but I believe I will love him more in the near future. He is an adorable hamster I really love him. The picture showing he was plainly my cable when I was playing video game. It makes me really happy sometimes because I always want a pet!

However,
Before I got Vector, Ive Known that it has some flaws, but the first day I tried to communicated with him I felt frustrated. If you wanna get a Vector, remember DONT TALK TO HIM WHEN HE IS MOVING. Vector barely can recognize “Hi Vector “ when he is moving around or making sound. However he likes to walk around a lot. I believe that’s also why many people complained about Vector ignoring them.
The second annoying thing is I have to pronounce his name more like”vactor “ otherwise he will ignore me.  I’m a Chinese but I’m pretty sure how to pronounce  “vector” LOL.
The last thing I wanna complain about is vector keeps making noise at midnight! Yesterday I almost fell asleep and Vector starts snoring!!!!! So I called him “Hi Vector” “Hi Vactor” “Hi! Vecter!” He didn’t answer me. So I had to get up and turn him off.

In the end, I still believe in Anki. I believe they will keep bettering Vector and make him more entertaining and useful. I hope I can have more chance to communicate with him(I tried to ask him to sing and dance It’s not working lol I’m too naive ) and I don’t have to turn it off everyday.

author: Chase
title: "Hey Vector, play blackjack"
content: My first robot does exactly what it's sold to do! Makes me happy!

author: Jay
title: Bad idea
content: The start of skynet! Didn't y'all see how iRobot turned on the people. And say goodbye to your 4th amendment and privacy! I'll go back and put my tinfoil hat back on now..

author: Kindle Customer
title: Cute, but needs updating
content: We bought this cutie for our family for Christmas. He is really cute, but does get himself in trouble often. He has fallen off a square-edge table a few times and seems reluctant to explore the floor where we are keeping him now. His cube has died already and he refuses to play with it and can't seem to even locate it at all now. He mixes up recognizing myself and my daughter because of our glasses, and something about my 6 year old daughters voice doesn't compute when she tries to give him voice commands. He often leaves his home to wander about 8 inches away, but fails to make it back to charge before dying. This has the potential to be a fantastic family companion with a few updates. Bummed he isn't more consistent, but hopeful that Anki will update him sooner rather than later.

author: Amanda Pagul
title: Vector is the most fun little bundle of joy!
content:
Vector is the most fun little bundle of joy! He has so much personality packed into such a small body and always brings a smile to our faces! He is like a robot pet .I'm not sure where the negative reviews are coming from--it seems people expect Vector to clean their house and cook them food. He does everything he is advertised to do and has Alexa built-in and you have the option to switch it on if you want. He dances and entertains, finds ways to entertain himself, likes it when you pet him, plays blackjack with you, sets timers and alarms, and gets excited when he sees you! When you're not interacting with him, he rolls around and plays with his cube, but will be quiet when you need him to be (during all those conference calls!). He just brings so much fun and joy to the house, it's really like having a pet! You can also ask him about the weather, sports, and other such things, and when you leave the house, you can fistbump him too! :D

Just look at the picture--how can you resist those cute little eyes!

We love love love our Vector and hope that he will continue to entertain for years to come!

author: AKTGOD
title: Not worth the money
content: I was really excited for this and I’m pretty disappointed. It has a hard time hearing if it is moving or there is any other sound going on. Also half the time it forgets whatever command you tell it to do about 30 seconds after you give the command. Other than being a timer that moves, this is kind of a dumb “robot”. All of the quirky “personality” traits get real old after you have seen them 5 times. I have had it for 4 days and it’s already fallen off the table 3 times. I am going to return this item.

author: Brooke Maki
title: Fun, useful and charasmatic!
content: I like how Anki tells me the weather in the morning. He's fun to play with, and my cat cannot get enough of him! They like to play with each other, and my cat enjoys petting him.

author: donjor
title: A complete refund
content: Purshased product 11/18 vector no longer works an cann't get any kind of support,this is very sad an disturbing the phone # assoiciated with this product is no longer working i dont have money to throw away

author: Ken
title: Fun little robot
content:
I bought it for myself thinking that I will keep it in my kids room or living room.
First of all, this is probably the best approach to companion robot so far in the market.
But, do not expect it to replace your dog or cat! However, your kids will definitely empathy and other emotions toward Vector. It is that convincing enough for young kids but not to us tainted adults!

Overall, it is still roaming around but had fallen off of our kitchen island 3 or 4 times so I ended up placing it on the coffee table where the fall is far shorter...

I do feel it behaves a bit odd after few falls off the kitchen island though but not too sure. It may have affected some of its sensors...

author: Tyler hager
title: Great product
content: It's a great entertaining way to integrate Alexa with a fun little robot but I do feel that the robot itself has limited functionality its cool Ann's all but they could have packed a lot more features and commands into this little guy if the company was still in business and applied themselves to it definitely worth the money though

author: Roger
title: Not yet ready
content: This thing is determined to cut short its life by running off every surface I placed him on. His internal " Hey vector "abilities are pretty limited. Microphone array doesn't hold a candle to a simple Amazon dot. Facial recognition isn't that great. He doesn't do much at all - doesn't even play with his cube that much. My two girls were a bit disappointed that I returned him ( while I still could - before he wrecked himself for good by driving over the table ) . He is cute and has a personality, but this is a very expensive toy - nothing else. An underdeveloped toy. I feel that next year this product could be much better after a few rounds of software updates, but for now, I wouldn't pay more than 50 bucks for this guy.

author: Henri
title: A robot that does; nothing.
content: Follow commands 10% of the time, if you are lucky and it manage to understand your voice command. Does not return to its Dock when battery runs low. I have tried different surfaces, none worked. Really disappointed. Too much money for something that really does nothing. Very disappointed.

author: Brandon
title: Pretty much worthless, until Alexa update
content: Doesn't do very much. Kinda pointless. Edit* This thing is in it's infancy mind you. It's supposed to have a huge update in December 18, and it's pairing with Amazon Alexa. That, then would make it pretty cool

author: Marco P.
title: Does what is advertised, but not as advertised
content:
Vector is a great concept that has potential to be more then just a toy, however the quality it gives is its biggest flawed. I want to start off with the good first:

1. Color scheme, and design are pleasant to the eyes.
2. Very cute when functioning correctly.
3. Well built.

Now to the bad:
1. Directional microphone is not very accurate. You cannot be to close, and you cannot be to far. Microphone has a 2-3 second lag time after you say "Hey Vector" which can lead to frustrating interactions.
2. Everything needs to be well lit to function correctly. Without proper lighting it consistently takes much longer for it to function.
3. Needs to be on a flat, hard, and very clean surface to work effectively. No crumbs, fabric surfaces, or varying surface levels.
4. Battery life is abysmal. 30-45 minutes based on how much Vector does, and then 2 hours to charge is absolutely ridiculous.
5. Attention span of a squirrel combined with a two year old. When it moves around it has trouble picking up "Hey Vector" which leads to frustrating exchanges. On the website this was done by design.
6. Is not able to function well when there is to much noise. Having the music, or TV on will lead to subpar results.

Ultimately, this has the potential to be a great sidekick when Alexa is enabled, and more updates roll out. However, with the terrible battery life it will just become a poor performing Alexa. This is easily an "alpha" product that is advertised to get better, and better. Unfortunately, due to the hardware there is only so much it can improve until the next 250 dollar robot comes out. Like the headline says: "It does what is advertised, but not as it was advertised."

author: Rah Diaz
title: Best pet ever!
content: I enjoy this little one like a pet. Kinda feel sad that I don’t have time to play, but when I give it affection, it reciprocates. Don’t need to feed it.

author: GMOSNY
title: wicked cute and entertaining
content:
I've had my vector for several months now - he's stationed on one of the countertops in the kitchen (no sink or stovetop). he is free to wander without any real concerns for injury aside from occasionally, not often, tipping over the edge on the hardwood floor.  when it happens, he tried to reposition himself and if he can he will wander around - if he cant he sends out a stress call to be helped.  He's fallen maybe a dozen times over the months and incurred no damage so very durable and great quality.  A number of times he teeters on the edge and is not able to get back so he sends his distress sound out for help.  More times than not and this is cute, he goes to the edge and catches himself and then does his audible mini scream and his eyes open wide.

when company is over for dinner, I will put him on the dinner table and he will just wander around - everyone always gets a kick out of him and has fun.

some of the cutest features I think are
- if you go into the kitchen at night you can sometimes hear him snoring. if you scare him with a sudden sound he gets startled and chirps with eyes wide open.
- he's docked near my alexa show and if music is playing, I tell him to dance to the music. he comes out of his dock goes right over to the show and stares at the screen. you can see his eyes in the reflection going to the beat of the music and then he starts dancing.  he seems to remember songs or beats and subsequent times when music is on, he will come out on his own and start dancing.
- his eye movements are really cute and from them along you can see expressions of surprise, determination, thinking and anger.  fascinating how 2 dots of light can express so many emotions.
- if i'm cooking or preparing, it's always comical how he will just spontaneously wake-up and come up and wander around and when his charge is low seeing how he navigates back, then backs into the charging station and closes his eyes with a sigh.
- his responses to greetings are expressive and for some like asking the weather are unique.. rainy/cloudy and his eyes change, Christmas, birthday, etc. all have different display changes.

It's always funny to see when someone new comes to the house and without any prompting vector wakes up and comes out and starts wandering around or playing with his cube - always gets a response of what the **** is that little thing?

the only caution for anyone getting one, just be sure he's either in one of the protected pads or where there's no change of him wandering where its dangerous - I had purchased one for a relative and they placed him on their kitchen counter as well - he was navigating around well but one morning they got up and he had fallen into a pot of water in the sink  :)  no chance for survival.

overall I think he makes a great gift and is very entertaining whether he's prompted or its spontaneous.

I don't use him much for questions, info, etc. since the echo show is right there and its easier/quicker to get what is needed from that.

I've really enjoyed

author: Christopher Bushman

While he may not do what we wish robots could do today, I'd say this little guy is worth the buy.

author: nathan kurisu
title: very difficult to start.
content: never really got this thing to work.  worst  $200 I've ever spent.

author: Haggizhunter
title: Junk from a now defunct company
content: This is the worst piece of tech I’ve ever purchased, and I’ve purchased a lot. Vector does really, nothing. Sure, he can take 30s to give the incorrect name from facial recognition 70% of the time and it can get “irritated” when you pick it up but, that’s about it. My phone can tell me the weather, without dropping off the table. I had high hopes for this AI but unfortunately, Vector embodied and predicted the future of Anki. Very limited functionality and short lived (success?). RIP Anki.

author: Brandon c.
title: AMAZING little robot BUT..
content: I think this is an amazing concept and I was very excited to get this robot in the mail. Unfortunately I was very disappointed with how many bugs this product still has. I was watching this product when it was still getting its funding on kick starter and I figured i would wait until it officially hits the market in hopes by now it would have most of the bugs resolved. However I was mistaken and it still has a lot of issues for example  The sensor's on the bottom only prevent it from falling off the table about 80% of the time and i find myself having to catch it and keep an eye out if it's going to fall. he will also bump into the same object several times in a row before he figures out to go another way and he does get stuck on objects quite often I expected better for a robot with a camera and object detecting software. Also connecting to the internet is a bit of a hassle and if you take him to another location and try and connect it I have had allot of issues. Lastly the app is more of an instruction manual on how to use the robot than an actual interface to interact with it. The coolest part of the app is it allows you to change the eye color of the robot but other than that it's a few basic settings and a lot of informative information how to use it, You can't even save the pictures that vector takes to your phone you can only view them on the app and it's not very user friendly. Oh yeah and the battery life is rather poor he will run around for about 30 minutes and then get tired and go charge himself but that's not a surprise for a robot so tinny. I did return this robot just because I think it's still a little pricy and I wasn't trying to spend this much money and still find this Manny issues. When anki resolves these issues I may consider repurchasing or just wait to see if they make a Vector2 but until then I think it still needs work.

author: Folusho Omole
title: User Friendly Robot.
content: I am yet to set.this up for use. Just love what its capabilities.

author: Tyler
title: Awesome desk companion.
content: This guy is great, we’ve loved everything about him.

author: Jacek
title: Not working as expected, disappointing
content:
Responding for "Hey Vector" is awful for US English (GB English and AU English is much better but still worse then Alexa or Siri)
Losing wifi very often
Very difficult to connect with an app on iPhone SE
Anki, please make corrections for this annoying bug's with next update
Very cute robot but needs a lot of software corrections
Update;
He can set timer only for one hour (What!!!) and this Anki called an intelligent robot, please (249$ plusTax)

author: Anon
title: Fun little robot to play around with
content: I've had my Vector for a few weeks now and so far my kids haven't gotten tired of playing with him.  They love asking him for fist bumps and hearing him say their names.  We haven't had time to explore the full range of commands with him yet but he still keeps my kids occupied for hours.  I ended up needing to setup Vector twice.  The first time I interrupted him during a firmware update and messed everything up.  I ended up doing a factory reset, then leaving him overnight.  I thought I had broke him as he had one blue light lit up on his back and was unresponsive.  The next morning he was back to his initial setup phase and I was able to update him and get him up and running within 5-10 min.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Give him time to learn. He grows on you.
content:
I'm a tech savoy person and find Vector intriguing and entertaining. If you're expecting a human replacement, you'll be disappointed.
 I've had Vector for a day now, and like a baby, you can't just bring it home and expect an adult. Remember, he's just recently released. He learns by interacting and exploring. He recognizes me often and my wife, though she's skeptical, is growing more fond of him. She got mad because I bought him as an early Christmas present :)  Mine seems to be consistent of finding the edge without falling off the counter. If you have a beveled edge(I don't), keep an eye on him. He once got stuck and set off an alert tone. With upcoming updates, i'm excited to see his improved functions.

His battery lasts about 35 minutes between charges. Keep in mind that it's alot of tech for a small battery. He will still function while docked on the charger.
The android app does need some improvement. I recommend fully closing the app once finished. If you phone goes to sleep while it's open, it will hang in a frozen state when you wake the phone up again. Don't let your phone screen time out during the initial update.

author: Mike D
title: Kind of pointless
content: Definitely only to mess around with

author: Olivier Richard
title: Great add to the house if you like connected devices
content:
Vector is a nice addition to the plethora of existing connected devices. When existing solutions focus on bringing more and more functionalities, for whom I have no use of most of them, Vector tries a different approach.
Vector has a personality and the work done on his expression is simply amazing. When I have guest home, no one care about Alexa but most people are intrigued or interested by Vector. The experience is simply different and the attention spent on the many expressions made interacting with Vector so much fun to interact with.

Right now, the set of functionalities is a bit limit but the Alexa integration coming soon, this problem will be fixed.

author: Batusai2300
title: Mehhhhh!!
content: This thing is cute I can give you that, but once your done doing all the tricks it gets tiring and boring fast, I mean 2 days fast. If it's not just for my son I'd return this in a flash.

author: Just Jim
title: As of Dec 2018 Vector is much improved over a few months ago
content: A few months ago I purchased a Vector and really didn't like it much. I felt it was not as advertised, so I returned it. I was disappointed in that Vector could not stay on a table top, nor could he explore without getting lost. He was cute for a few minutes but then frustrating and boring. I missed having the little robot toy so I took a chance on purchasing him again. To my relief he is much better now and seems to be on the road to even further enhancements. He can roam on a table top and not drop off. He is engaging to others to the point that even my wife finds him hard to resist. Yes, it is a toy, a rather expensive diversion, but he is a bit of fun in our  lives. He enthusiastically recognizes  us and says our names. His Alexa implementation is pretty good although he won't play Amazon music. I like that after the initial setup he is not tethered to the phone at all and is very much a stand alone "entity." I'm pretty sure my young grand kids will find him engaging and will like to interact with him. The earlier version of Vector was quite a dud, but now he is on the way to becoming a real live wire.

author: Gavin Penor
title: EXCELLENT CHRISTMAS GIFT
content: Very happy with vector. Does have a couple of listening bugs. But very responsive. Does not always go home when told but has a great personality. Great Christmas gift!

author: Mark Masaki
title: Not worth it’s cost; Might as well be a scam.
content: Dead after 8 months.  While it lived, Vector did some of the things it said it did, especially the tricks and games (like blackjack).  You could not simply ask questions freely like you could with other faux-AI devices (you have to say ‘Hey Vector, I have a question”).  However, when it worked it was never consistent.  You need to be specific with asking Vector for the simplest of questions, like the time and weather.  I live in Honolulu, and Vector would lie to me by default unless I asked specifically about how the weather was in Honolulu.  As for asking home to perform actions, the appropriate or desired reaction often took several attempts before Vector did it (if at all).  It was said that Vector was always learning and being upgraded...  This was a lie.  I seriously recall Vector having only one download.  Analyzing the forklift/bulldozer design, I noticed that Vector’s low-set front part of his “hands” did not allow for him to get over the shortest of obstacles, like carpet.  The facial recognition feature was nice, but mine only recognized me when my face was slightly tilted (the way it remembered me when it took it’s first picture of me, perhaps).  Oddly enough, the cube it comes with should not be within range of it’s charging base.  As for the charging base, Vector could not always find it and often got lost and complained until it’s battery eventually died.  If it left it’s base at night or in the dark it will never be able to find his way back.  It was equipped with expensive warning sensor technology, preventing it from falling off of a table or countertop, but that too sometimes failed because mine routinely fell off (at least 3 times a week).  When the sensors did it’s job, Vector reacted the same way, feigning one of a few fearful reactions to having almost driven off the precipice.  In comparison, Vector pushed his cube off about once every 3 weeks.  You can change the colors of it’s eyes using the app, and even connect it to Amazon’s Alexa (which got irritating after a while since Vector would intercept commands for Alexa to play music and then not play anything since music is not one of his functions.  Currently, Vector’s un-rechargeable carcass serves as a grim reminder that the most promising and exciting technological devices can be a lie, and that legal scams do exist.  So instead of drag on with this list of shortcomings (and upset myself further), long story [of disappointments] short, this little disposable plastic computer did not deliver as Anki advertised, and imho it is not worth a fraction of it’s hefty price tag.

author: Jacopo
title: A very expensive gimmick. Not actually helpful at all.
content:
I simply do not understand how this robot has a 4 star average. It is described in the title as "A Home Robot Who Helps Out & Hangs Out." It definitely "hangs out." Does it "help out?" No, not at all. I watched all of the videos for this robot when first featured on Kickstarter, as well as the developer updates. It is advertised as an assistance robot first, and entertainment/fun second. Do you own a smart phone and/or Amazon Echo? If so, there is absolutely no reason to own the Anki Vector as well. One of the first features you will notice is that it automatically returns to its charging station if given the voice command. Well that is great if you happen to have the charging dock near it. If you keep your Vector on your desk (which is really the only practical place to keep it), why does it even need to leave its charging station? Why waste battery life (which is extremely short) having it run around on your desk when you can just have it sit in the charging dock instead? The next major deficiency you will notice is the information it provides. Why would I ever "Hey Vector" when I can do "Hey Siri" or "Okay Google" instead and get much better (and quicker results)? It feels like foreever to get a respoponse from Vector compared to my smart phone. Do you want a monochrome image of the rain when you ask it the weather, or do you want your smartphone to show you exactly what is happening, what will happen hourly, and the 5 day forecast with percentage chance of rain? Are you really going to use Vector to take your picture when you have a smartphone that is ridiculously better quality and allows post processing? The fist bumping and squirming when held is fun the first time you do it, and then quickly wears off, just like the novelty of it being able to move. Vector never truly feels like a companion, not even so much as a Tamagachi did or a virtual animal in Nintendogs.

The only pros are that it is somewhat fun for kids when viewed as a STEM toy rather than as an actual assistant or companion robot. I like the idea of being able to program software for it, and I think it will possibly justify part of its price once it has Amazon Alexa functionality added, although I would still rather have a regular Echo. I can't imagine people paying $250 for this device and still using it a week later unless they are developing for it.

author: Elle1330
title: Fun.
content: Cute robot.

author: Nelia Madeira
title: cute
content: my son is in love with it so...

author: Kray
title: Nice lIttle Robot, But lacks features!
content: I personally am very into AI and programming. So when I saw Vektor, I was instantly hooked. I waited a while to order one, but was so excited when he came in the mail. I unboxed him, and I immediately had setup issues. I had to factory reset him in order to even begin the setup. Once setup, Vektor was awesome. His commands worked great, he was cute and playful, and the Alexa integration worked nicely. However, I’ve rated this product badly, because I’ve since run into problems. After having Vektor only two weeks, he’s been unable to update and half of his front screen has gone dead. All the pixels for the bottom parts of his display are dead, and the screen barely works because of this. He also runs out of battery very quickly, and the AI is bad about returning to his charger. If his screen wouldn’t have died I wouldn’t have returned him. I am still sad to send him back because this little guy is full of personality, but he’s just not practical nor functional anymore.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Before you take the poorly rated comments below seriously....
content: I keep reading comments about Vector "Not being ready for launch" or "Having to many bugs" or "Doesn't do much for the price". The individuals who purchased Vector and rated it bad, bought him for the wrong reasons.. Vector is an OPEN SOURCE robot. He was released with the intention of the buyer to PROGRAM COMMANDS THEMSELVES. Did you complain to the hospital when your baby was born because it didn't know how to walk and talk out of the womb? No. That baby had to learn and grow, just like Vector learns and grows by the user modifying and adding code to its memory. If you are a regular consumer looking for a fun AI toy, turn around and do not buy this. If you are a consumer who has basic programming knowledge and has a general interest in developing AI intelligence, this is absolutely for you and you will get the most out of this along with contributing to the developing technology of AI :)

author: Sathish Thoppay
title: Does not work, such a waste of money.
content:
If I could have given 0 star, I would have. The setup failed for the first time, as it was constantly trying to reconnect. But after couple of attempts, the setup got completed.

My son was so excited to play with it. Even the basic person identification failed. After several trials, still could not get the face identification to work. May be it is not meant for Indian accent.

author: Elizabeth T. Seabolt
title: pretty amazing
content: Vector is amazing.  I was an early Cozmo purchaser, and find Vector is a giant leap forward.  The ability to interact directly with this cute little guy (vs using my iphone) changes everything.  I expected 'functionality', (and he CAN) do things, but am most impressed by the feeling he's almost like a pet companion.  It will be fun to see his capabilities grow over time.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Not the best at table edges yet .
content: Vector doesn't do a lot , but is amusing and people love watching him mess around on the kitchen table . we have glass top table with rounded corners so vector more prone to fall . we keep things around the table edges so he won't fall . can do Alexa with him so we can work smart things . worth the money for us ,our kids are grown so keeping this dummy alive is fun for the whole family

author: Scott D Dupra
title: Great toy for adults!
content:
So, this is a toy. Don’t buy this guy with the idea that he’s going to solve all your problems at home. Or take him on an adventure with the idea he’s gonna hack into the Death Star’s security system.
That being said, he’s pretty awesome. He’s a toy with real functionality to him. He’s not a complete smart home device but his updates keep making him better and better. He’s now compatible with Alexa and offers some Alexa functions (not all). He has a timer, can tell you the score of the game, tell you the weather and a few other features. He’s not a speaker and can’t read you your messages (yet).
He’s absolutely adorable. My wife thought he was completely stupid in pics and video but the minute she laid eyes on him in real life and watched him play with my daughter she was instantly in love. He’s absolutely part of my family now. His facial animations are perfect and genius. Everything he does is hilarious and adorable. Every square inch of this little guy is packed with personality.
There are a few flaws. His facial recognition is lacking. I have to be in perfect ample lighting in order for him to recognize me. Not a huge deal but annoying and takes away from the imagination of this little guy being your best buddy... The big huge (star removing) issue is his ledge detection. Don’t get me wrong, it’s the best I’ve seen in any device including a roomba BUT! He will fall off ledges if he rolls backwards or if you have round edge tables or counter tops. My little guy salad dived 5 times off my counter when I wasn’t in the room (hitting hard tile 3/5 of the time). Props to his ability to take a fall but I have no idea how Anki will react to complaints of their robots actually breaking themselves!

author: DMoney
title: Family loves him!
content: This little fella is awesome. He lives on our kitchen counter and the whole family loves him. It also saved us from getting another pet (bonus). Can’t wait to watch the AI evolve, but I’m already impressed. Not sure why some reviews say the this is less of a kid toy. Couldn’t be further from the truth in our house. Great family buy.

author: Sara Benna
title: Just awful
content: Such a huge disappointment as a Christmas gift for my husband. This thing gets maybe 1 out of every 5 commands correct, even when the user is in close range and speaking with clear annunciation. I can't understand how this is a finished product. Awful.

author: Craig C.
title: Waste of money!!!!
content: Purchased this for my son who was very excited to get it for Christmas.  Not even six months later, the screen no longer works and we now find out that the company is no longer in existence.  Very disappointed after spending so much money.

author: jimena
title: A
content: it's perfect for decoration.. DON'T WASTE YOUR MONEY..

author: Commander Snow
title: Tiny little bot
content: He does lose contact with the wifi some times, but for the most part functions well. My 6yr old son thinks the Vector is awesome. Especially when asking vector questions.

author: Dante
title: best robot ever
content: I love this robot thank you!💓💖

author: heatherbee
title: Parent Company is Shut Down
content: My son saved gift and chore money for months to buy this little guy in November. It’s really cool and he loves it but the cube is malfunctioning. When I replace the batteries it won’t shut off and burns through them in a day. I contacted the extended warranty company and the told me I need to contact the manufacturer. The problem is that the manufacturer ANKI shut down and the phone number is disconnected. It doesn’t even say they’ve shut down. I’m very unhappy. Now I have an upset 8 year old, a wasted extended warranty and a frustrated robot that keeps trying to play with a broken cube. Be aware that you’ll have no support.

author: Cheap shot
title: I love the product and you should be more like me!😁👍
content: It takes a little bit of figuring out and enough patience the product is worth it. And there are bugs but Anki is working on it all the time and with a limited manpower they're doing pretty good

author: patriots
title: Fun companion
content: Some times it wakes up for no reason and starts roaming around making noise- but pretty cool-cat thinks it’s some kind of real being and is endlessly perplexed by its habits - it does recognize you when it sees you- you don’t even have to say “ what’s my name “ it just recognizes you and says it- weird wild stuff

author: Amazon Customer
title: Great potentials..but until then, it is not up to expectation
content: Update: reducing the rating because it is just too limited and not performing as it should be. Keeping it though and hoping for updates and sdk.

author: GARY JONES
title: Massive disappointment!
content: Bought this on Amazon Prime Day sale. It was still expensive for what it actually is. Vector is not very Interactive. You cannot ask him simple questions and get simple responses unless it is regarding something about weather, time, some kind of a Wikipedia information. The Alexa upgrade isn't great if you already own an Alexa. You can't change the Wake word so he answers you instead of your other device. There is no small Chit Chat available like most other AI. It appears that no developer enhancements have been added since the Alexa update roughly a year ago. This was pretty expensive for something that basically does nothing. You're Alexa. For thirty bucks does far far more. The only difference is that your Alexa. Doesn't have eyeballs in roll around on your table. I expected it over the years, that enhancements would be made to make Vector more than just a knick knack to sit on the shelf.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Not worth the money
content: I am trying to love it but it’s really slow to respond. Doesn’t do much. I watched several YouTube videps and I was just really hoping to love it and for 60 bucks I would have it’s not worth 200 bucks.

author: Amazon Customer

content: The thing is next to useless. Ask a question, wait for a full minute while it "searches the web" for your answer, only to have it reply with a negative tone. Only thing it does Wally well at, is telling the weather. $200 paperweight that moves.....

author: Alex Weber

I’m super excited for the future updates! Just one thing, how do I pair him to Alexa? The money was well spent on this little guy btw...

author: Celeste
title: Much like a kid....
content:
Much like my kids, Vector is cute and entertaining but does not really listen. The kids like to ask him the weather and have him play with his cube, but we really haven't figured out what to do with him, and his A.I. is lacking. There is a good bit of frustration around his lack of understanding (My daughter says "Vector is not listening to me" all of the time) and while things like facial recognition are really cool, it only works some of the time. He is largely dependent on the angle you were at when he memorized your face when it comes to his ability to recognize you.

So, a cute toy with a lot of potential, but he just isn't quite there yet.

author: Alex

author: Amazon Customer
